Section: Grammar and Morphology
Book: Al-Hulal fi Sharh Abyat al-Jumal
Author: Abu Muhammad Abdullah bin Muhammad bin as-Sid al-Batalyawsi (Died 521 AH)
[The book is automatically numbered and does not correspond to the printed version]
Date of publication on Al-Shamela: 8 Dhu al-Hijjah 1431

[Repetitive metadata omitted for brevity...]

In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. May Allah bless our Master Muhammad and grant him peace. Praise be to Allah who taught us what we did not know, preferred us over many of His creation and advanced us, and made us among those who are emulated and followed. Blessings of Allah be upon Muhammad and his family and peace.

Abu Muhammad Abdullah bin Muhammad bin as-Sid al-Batalyawsi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: When I finished discussing the correction of errors occurring in the book 'Al-Jumal', I wanted to follow that speech with the parsing (I'rab) of its poetic verses and their meanings, and what I recall of the names of their authors. My purpose is to connect each verse with what relates to it so it becomes clearer regarding the purpose of its speaker and his doctrine. I was not prevented from discussing their parsing and meanings by the speech of others before me regarding them, for perhaps the speech of another has merit over what is besides it, and an increase of benefit for the one who reviews and narrates it. I ask Allah for help in what I reveal; He is the Possessor of Bounty and its Giver; there is no Lord but Him, and no deity except Him.

Abu al-Qasim, may Allah have mercy on him, recited in the Chapter of the Adjective (Na't):
'May my people not perish/be distant, who are ... the poison of enemies and the bane of the slaughter-camels'
'Those descending at every battlefield ... And the pure ones in the tying of waist-wrappers'

This poetry is by Khirniq bint Haffan al-Qaisamiyyah. She is the sister of Tarafa bin al-Abd al-Maliki through his mother. It is from a poem in which she mourned her husband, Bishr bin Amr bin Marthad, and those killed with him from his sons and his people. He had raided Banu Asad bin Khuzaimah, he and Amr bin Abdullah bin al-Ashall. They were supporting each other: Bishr leading Banu Malik and Banu Attab bin Rabi'ah, and Amr leading Banu Ruhm. The meaning of 'Tasanud' (mutual support) is that each man goes out on his own authority, without a single commander uniting them. They raided Banu Asad, but Banu Asad beat them to a mountain pass called Qilab. Bishr bin Amr and his sons were killed, and Amr bin Abdullah bin al-Ashall fled. That day was named: The Day of Qilab.

Khirniq: Is one of the names transferred from species to proper nouns; because 'Khirniq' in the language is the young of a rabbit, used for both male and female. Al-Khirniq is also: A water cistern, similar to a reservoir. As for Haffan: It is an improvised name, not transferred, derived from 'Hafif', which is speed and lightness. It is said: Haffan with a fatha or kasra on the Ha.

The meaning of 'La yab'adan': May they not perish. It is a supplication that came in the form of a prohibition, though it is not a prohibition, just as a supplication may come in the form of a command, though it is not a command, as when you say: 'O Allah, forgive Zayd.' The parsing of the verb is nullified due to the entry of the light Nun (Nu of emphasis) into it, because it renders the future tense built on sukoon (fixed), preventing grammatical operators from affecting it. It flows with a fatha for the singular male, a kasra for the singular female, and a damma for the group of males. Its movement is to prevent the meeting of two still letters according to the school of Sibawayh.

It is said: 'Ba'uda ar-rajulu yab'udu' (The man became distant), on the pattern of 'Alima ya'lamu', meaning when he perished. Allah the Almighty said: 'Away with Midian as Thamud was taken away.' But if you mean the distance that is the opposite of nearness, you say: 'Ba'uda yab'udu', on the pattern of 'Zarufa yazrufu'. The source (Masdar) meant for destruction is 'Ba'dan' with fatha on Ba and Ayn. The source meant for the opposite of nearness is 'Bu'dan', on the pattern of its opposite, which is 'Qurb'. They might use 'Bu'd' (distance) for destruction due to the overlap of their meanings.

If a questioner asks: How did she pray for her people not to perish when they had already perished?! The answer is: The Arabs have followed a custom of using this phrase in supplicating for the dead. They have two purposes in this: First: They intend to magnify the death of a great man, as if they do not believe his death. Zuhair bin Abi Sulma clarified this meaning saying:
'They say: Hisn [is dead], then their souls refuse ... And how [can it be] Hisn, when the mountains are leaning!'
'And the graves have not cast out the dead, nor have ... the stars of the sky ceased, and the surface [of earth] is intact!'
He meant that they say: Hisn died, then they find it too great to articulate, saying: How is it possible he died when the mountains have not been leveled, the stars have not fallen, the graves have not expelled their dead, and the body of the world is intact with no calamity occurring in it?! This is one purpose.
The second purpose: They intend to pray that his memory remains and does not fade; because the survival of a person's memory after his death is like his life. Do you not see the poet's saying:
'So praise us - may you have no father [an expression of intensity] ... for our actions, for indeed praise is eternity'
Another, At-Tamimi, said mourning Yazid bin Yazid ash-Shaybani:
'If the nights have finished him, then soon ... indeed he has a memory that will finish the nights!'
Abu at-Tayyib al-Mutanabbi spoke on this meaning and excelled greatly:

'A youth's mention is his second life, and his need ... is what he missed, and the surplus of life is busywork'
Malik bin ar-Rayb clarified the impossibility within this meaning when he said:
'They say: Do not be distant (don't die), while they are burying me ... And where is the place of distance if not my place [the grave]?'

Her saying: 'Poison of enemies and bane of the slaughter-camels': She meant that in their lives they were poison to their enemies because they destroyed them, and a bane (disaster) to their camels because they slaughtered them for their guests. 'Juzur' is the plural of 'Jazour', which is the camel intended for slaughter. It is said: 'Summ' and 'Samm' with damma and fatha on the Seen. At-Tusi claimed it is said 'Simm' with a kasra.

If it is said: How did she say 'Those who are' (Alladhina hum), which is appropriate for those who exist, while she should have said as the other said:
'They were a burning fire against the enemies ... And a sanctuary of the sanctuaries for their people?'
The answer to this is from two aspects: First: Arabs may hide 'kana' (was/were) relying on the listener's understanding if the wording implies it, like the Almighty's saying: 'And they followed what the devils recite over the kingdom of Solomon,' Al-Kisa'i said: He meant what they 'were' reciting. Ar-Ra'i said:
'The times of my people and the group is like that which ... prevented the saddle from leaning at all'
He meant: 'Were' the times of my people.
The second aspect: When she prayed for the survival of their memory after their death, they became like existing people, and were described by what they used to do. It is also possible she prayed with 'La yab'adan' for those remaining of her people, meaning: May Allah not remove those remaining of my people as He removed those who passed. This is strengthened by her saying after this verse:
'A people, when they ride, you hear from them ... A clamor of shouting and rebuke'
'If they drink, they give; and if they leave it ... they advise each other against speaking nonsense'
'And those mixing their unrelated ones with their purebloods ... And the wealthy among them shelters the poor'
'This is my praise as long as I remain for them ... So when I perish, my grave will cover me'

The opinion of those who say she prayed for those who died is strengthened by her saying in this poem:
'They met their death on the morning of Qilab ... Like the driving of the sacrifice being driven to the idol'
'Al-Udah' (The enemies): Plural of 'Adin', which is the enemy himself. It cannot be the plural of 'Aduww' (Enemy) because [the form] Fa'ul is not pluralized as Fa'lah. Abu Zayd narrated: 'May Allah not let your 'Adi' (enemy) rejoice', meaning your 'Aduww'.

'An-Nuzul' (Descending) in war is of two types: First: At the start of war, which is dismounting from camels to ride horses. Second: At the end, which is dismounting from horses to fight on foot, if the fighting is in a rough, narrow place where there is no room for horses, or perhaps a man embraces his opponent and they both fall to the ground. This is the descending Muhalhil meant by saying:
'They could not descend, but we descended ... And the brother of war is he who can descend'
It is what Antara meant by saying:
'Among them is a trustworthy brother who fights dismounted ... with the Mashrafi sword, and a knight who did not dismount!'

'Al-Mu'tarak': The place of fighting. It is also called 'Ma'rak'. It is derived from 'Arakat ar-raha al-habba' (The millstone crushed the grain). They meant: It grinds those in it just as the millstone grinds what is put in it. Thus they named it: Raha (Millstone). Antara said: 'A grinding millstone turned upon the people'. Zuhair clarified this saying:
'So it grinds you like the grinding of the millstone with its cloth ... And it produces twins yearly, then becomes pregnant and weans'

When they describe a man with purity of the 'Izar' (waist-wrapper) and its goodness, it is a sign and metonymy for chastity of the private parts. She means: They do not tie their waist-wrappers over fornicating private parts! Likewise, purity of the 'Dhayl' (hem). If they describe with purity of the 'Kumm' (sleeve) or 'Rudan' (which is the sleeve itself), they mean he does not betray or steal! If they describe him with purity of the 'Jayb' (pocket/chest opening), they mean: His heart does not contain cheating or detestable things! They may use the goodness of the 'Hujzah' (waistband) as a metonymy for chastity, as An-Nabigha said:
'Thin of sandals, good are their waistbands ... They are greeted with basil on the days of festivals'

The Ba in her saying: 'Bi-kulli mu'tarak' (In every battlefield) means 'Fi' (In), as one says: Zayd is 'Bi-Basra' (in Basra) and 'Fi Basra'. 'Ma'aqid al-Azr' (tying of waist-wrappers): Is accusative (Mansub) due to resemblance to the direct object. The Kufans allow it to be accusative as Tamyiz (specification), because Tamyiz for them can be indefinite or definite, and separation is allowed in the definite. For the Basrans, it is not allowed unless it is indefinite. 'Al-Laghat' and 'Al-Laght' with sukoon or fatha on the Ghayn: The clamor and mixed voices.

'At-Ta'yih': Calling out. It is said: 'Ayyahtu bi-r-rajul', if you called him. In the Hadith, the Angel of Death was asked: How do you seize souls? He said: 'I call them (u'ayyihu biha) as horses are called, and they come to me.' 'Al-Hujr': Ugly speech, with a damma on the Ha; if opened (Hajr), it means delirium. 'An-Nudar': Pure lineage. 'An-Nahit': Its opposite. 'Al-'Atir': What is slaughtered for idols. 'Al-'Atr': Slaughtering for idols (with fatha on Ayn), and 'Al-'Itr' (with kasra) is the slaughtered animal itself.

Her saying: 'So when I perish, my grave will cover me': A statement with no utility on its surface. The meaning is: If I perish, my excuse is established in stopping the praise for them due to my death. It is placing the cause in place of the effect, which is common in speech.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Substitution (Al-Badal):
'I was like one with two legs; one healthy leg ... And a leg in which Time shot [an affliction], so it became paralyzed'
This verse is by Kuthayyir 'Azza. He is: Kuthayyir bin Abdurrahman bin al-Aswad bin Amir bin Uwaimir al-Khuza'i. His Kunya is Abu Sakhr. He was a foolish Rafidi (Shi'a). When death approached him, he said: 'I am innocent before God of Ibn Arwa (Uthman) ... And of the religion of the Kharijites entirely. And of Umar I am innocent, and of Atiq (Abu Bakr) ... The morning he was called Commander of the Faithful.' Then his soul departed, as if it were a pebble falling into water! Ibn Arwa is Uthman bin Affan, may Allah be pleased with him.

Kuthayyir: Diminutive of Kathir (Much/Many). It is of the names transferred from adjectives. 'Kathir' is used in Arabic with two meanings: First: The opposite of few in number. Second: To mean mighty and majestic. It is said: 'Kathurtu bika', meaning: I became mighty through you. 'A man is many (mighty) by his brother' is from this. Al-Abbas bin Mirdas meant this in saying:
'If I am few among your wicked ones ... Then indeed I am many (mighty) among your good ones'
He was attributed to 'Azza due to his intense passion and love for her, and his fame for loving her. He was diminutized because he was contemptible and extremely short. When he entered upon Abd al-Malik bin Marwan, he would say to him: 'Lower your head so the ceiling doesn't hurt you!' Therefore, Al-Hazin mocked him saying:
'The Lord of flies has attached Kuthayyir ... vipers do not bite him nor snakes'
'Short of shirt, obscene at his house ... The tick bites his buttocks while he is standing'

As for comparing himself to one with two legs; one healthy and one paralyzed, the scholars of meaning have two opinions: It is said: He meant she promised and covenanted not to change towards him; so he remained firm on his covenant, but she did not remain firm! It is said: He only wished that his young she-camel would get lost, so he would find a way to stay with her ('Azza). So, his staying with her would be like the healthy leg, and the loss of his camel carrying him and his cessation of travel would be like the paralyzed leg! Both meanings are correct. The first meaning is like An-Najashi saying:
'I was like one with two legs, one healthy ... And a leg struck by the companion of calamities'
'As for the one that was healthy, it is Azd Shanu'ah ... And as for the paralyzed one, it is Azd Oman'
Also supporting this is Kuthayyir's saying:
'We walked an ascent of passion ... When we met, I stood firm and she slipped'

As for those who said it falls under wishful thinking (Tamanni), they said so because before it is:
'Would that my young camel was fettered at Azza's ... With a weak rope, pulled from it, so it went astray'
'And her saddle was left among the residing tribe ... And had a seeker other than me, so it wore out'
So the estimation according to them is: Would that my camel was fettered at Azza's, and would that I was...

His saying 'Rama fiha az-zaman' (Time shot into it): A sentence in the place of an adjective for 'Rijlin' (a leg). He meant: Time shot disease and paralysis into it, so he omitted the object. It is narrated: 'Rijlun sahihatun, wa rijlun...' with Raf' (nominative). This is because the estimation is: 'They are a healthy leg and a leg...', so it is the predicate of a hidden subject. Or if you wish, the estimation is: 'One of them is a healthy leg, and the other is a leg...', so the speech is two sentences. In the first estimation, it is one sentence. If you wish, the estimation is: 'Of them is a healthy leg, and of them is a leg...', so each is a subject, and the speech is also two sentences.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this chapter:
'Indeed, in a year's stay that I stayed ... needs are fulfilled and a lingerer becomes bored'
The verse is by Al-Asha of Bakr bin Wa'il. His name is: Maimun bin Qays bin Jandal. Kunya: Abu Basir. His father Qays was called: The Victim of Hunger; because he entered a cave to shade himself from heat, and a rock fell on the mouth of the cave, so he died of hunger in it! Jahnam mocked him regarding that saying:

'Your father is the Victim of Hunger, Qays bin Jandal ... And your maternal uncle is a suckling slave from Khuma'ah'
Maimun: A name transferred from adjective to proper noun. Qays and Jandal are also transferred from types. Al-Qays: Intensity, Al-Qays: An idol, Al-Qays: Measurement. Some narrated: 'Thawaituhu' with a damma on the Ta, but the correct way is fatha for the second person address; because before it is:
'Bid farewell to Hurayra, even if a blamer blames ... Tomorrow morning; or are you despondent about the separation?'
'Ath-Thawa': Staying. It is said: 'Thawa ar-rajul wa athwa'. He says: Bid farewell to Hurayra, even if the blamer blames you for leaving her, for you have stayed with her for a year, and whoever stays with his beloved for a year has cured his passion and bored of his stay, but you are despondent about leaving her, resolved to stay with her! 'Al-Wajim': The sad and depressed. 'Al-Lubanat': Needs, singular: Lubanah. 'As-Sa'am': Boredom.

'Thawa'in': A substitute (Badal) for 'Hawl' (Year). 'Thawaituhu' is a sentence having a grammatical place; because it is in the place of an adjective for 'Thawa'in'. It is an adjective applied to other than what it belongs to. If you made it a noun, you would say: 'Thawihi anta' (You are its stayer), so the attached pronoun would separate and appear. It is necessary that in this sentence there are two pronouns returning: one to 'Thawa' (stay) from its adjective, and one returning to 'Hawl' (year) from its substitute; because the rule of the adjective is that a returner must return from it to its noun, and the rule of the inclusion substitute (Badal al-Ishtimal) and part-of-whole substitute is that in each there is a pronoun returning to the substituted-from. The Ha in 'Thawaituhu' returns to 'Thawa', and the returner to 'Hawl' is estimated as if he said: 'A stay I stayed *in it*'. A parallel to this grammatical issue is: 'Nafa'ani Abdullah 'ilmun afadanihi' (Abdullah benefited me with knowledge he gave me), meaning he gave me *it*. The Ha in 'afadanihi' returns to 'knowledge', and the hidden 'he' returns to Abdullah.

Some contemporary commentators on the verses of Al-Jumal said: The Ha in 'Thawaituhu' may return to 'Thawa' or to 'Hawl'. That is an error, because if he returns the Ha of 'Thawaituhu' to 'Hawl', the described noun remains without a returner from the sentence which is its adjective. And if he makes it return to 'Thawa', the substituted-from remains without a returner from the substitute, so another pronoun must be estimated as we said.

Whoever narrates: 'Tuqadda' (is fulfilled) and makes it a source (Masdar) added to 'Lubanat', it is permissible that it is the noun of 'Kana', and its predicate is in the prepositional phrase. It is permissible to hide 'the matter/situation' (Al-Amr/Ash-Shan) in 'Kana', and make 'Tuqadda Lubanat' nominative by inchoation (Mubtada), and the predicate in the prepositional phrase before it, and the sentence is the predicate of 'Kana'. In this narration, it is necessary to make 'Wa yas'amu' accusative by hiding 'An' so it becomes a source, coordinating it with 'Tuqadda', as if he said: 'Fulfillment of needs, and boredom of a borer', since it is not valid to coordinate a verb to a noun. Its parallel in grammar is your saying: 'Yu'jibuni darbu Zaydin wa yaghdaya' (Zayd's hitting pleases me and [his] anger), and similarly the saying of Maysun bint Bajdal:
'Wearing a woolen cloak while my eye is cool ... Is dearer to me than wearing sheer robes'
The estimation is: 'Wearing a cloak and the coolness of my eye'. The pattern of 'Tuqadda' from the verb is 'Tafa''ul'. The Dad was given a kasra to make the Ya sound, as the Nun was given kasra in 'At-Tamanni' and Lam in 'At-Tasalli'.

Whoever narrates: 'Tuqda Lubanatun', making 'Lubanat' nominative, and making 'Tuqda' passive voice with 'Lubanat' as its deputy subject, and making 'Wa yas'amu' nominative coordinating with it, then it is necessary to hide 'the matter/situation' in 'Kana' in any case.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: Divisions of Verbs in Transitivity:
'I commanded you [to do] good, so do what you were commanded ... For I have left you possessing wealth and possessing property (Nashab)'
This verse appeared in Sibawayh's book attributed to Amr bin Ma'adi Yakrub. Al-Hajari mentioned in his Nawadir that it belongs to Al-Asha Tarud. Amr is a name transferred from types to proper nouns. 'Amr' has four meanings: The life/survival (from 'La-'Amr Allah' - an oath by His survival). The flesh between teeth (gums). The earring. The sleeve's edge. In the Hadith: 'There is no harm if a man prostrates on his two Amrs (sleeves).'

As for Ma'adi Yakrub: Abu al-Abbas Ahmad bin Yahya said: Its meaning is 'Sadness bypassed him' ('Adahu al-karb), i.e., missed him. Abu al-Fath bin Jinni narrated this from Abu Ali al-Farisi. Amr's Kunya is Abu Thawr. Some claimed his Kunya is Abu Rayhana, after a daughter he had, about whom he says:
'Is it from Rayhana, the hearing caller ... She keeps me awake while my companions are asleep?'
This is a mistake; Rayhana is his sister, the mother of Durayd bin as-Simma.
It is narrated: 'Dha Nashab' with a dotted Shin. This is how Sibawayh's students narrated it in his book without disagreement. Al-Hajari narrated it with an undotted Seen (Nasab). Whoever narrates it with Seen can say: His saying 'Dha Mal' (possessor of wealth) sufficed over mentioning 'Nashab'. Whoever narrates it with dotted Shin can argue with several points, including: The agreement of the narrators of Sibawayh's book on the Shin.

Among them: Arabs may bring two nouns with the same meaning, like the poet saying:
'Oh, how lovely is Hind, and a land containing Hind ... And Hind, separated by distance (an-Na'y) and farness (al-Bu'd)'
'An-Na'y' is exactly 'Al-Bu'd'.
Among them: Arabs mostly use 'Nashab' for fixed assets that do not move, like houses and estates, and they mostly apply 'Mal' (wealth) to what is not fixed, like dinars, dirhams, and livestock. Sometimes they apply 'Mal' to everything a human owns, which is correct, due to the Almighty's saying: 'And do not give the foolish your property (Amwalakum)', and this does not specify one thing over another.

After this verse:
'So leave the traits of a people with no character ... And aim for the morals of the people of virtue and literature'
'You have attained glory, so beware of sullying it ... A noble father and a grandfather not of mixed lineage'
'Al-Mu'tashib': One whose lineage is not pure. It is said: 'Ashiba al-bayt wa i'tashaba' if it became entangled.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Occupying the Verb from the Object with its Pronoun:
'I have become such that I do not carry weapons, nor ... Do I control the head of the camel if it bolts'
'And the wolf, I fear it if I pass by it ... Alone, and I fear the winds and the rain'
These two verses are by Ar-Rabi' bin Dab' al-Fazari from Banu Fazara. He is one of the centenarians (Mu'ammarin). He is the one who said:
'If a youth lives two hundred years ... Then joy and youthfulness have gone'
Ar-Rabi', Dab', and Fazara: Are names transferred from genera and types to proper nouns. As for Ar-Rabi': It is the known season of the year, and Ar-Rabi' is rain, and Ar-Rabi' is the grass growing from it, and Ar-Rabi' is the dust between the pasture.
Ad-Dab': A type of predator (Hyena). The female is called 'Dab'', and the male 'Dhib'an'. Ad-Dab' also means a drought year, likened to the hyena. In the Hadith: A man said: 'O Messenger of Allah, the Hyena (drought) has eaten us.' Al-Abbas bin Mirdas said:
'O Abu Khurasha, as for you being of a group ... Indeed my people, the Hyena has not eaten them'
As for Fazara: It is the female leopard. The 'Hidibbas' is the male, and 'Al-Fizr' is its cub if male, and 'Al-Fizra' is the female. The poet said:
'And I saw a female leopard and a male ... And the cub follows its mother like the wild cat'

His saying: 'La ahmilu as-silah' (I do not carry weapons), and 'Wa la amliku...' (Nor do I control...) are two sentences in the place of accusative as the predicate (Khabar) of 'Asbaha' (became) if you consider it incomplete, or in the place of State (Hal) if you consider it complete and independent of a predicate, as if he said: 'I became not carrying weapons, nor controlling the camel's head if it flees from me!'

In 'Adh-Dhi'b' (The wolf), nominative (Raf') and accusative (Nasb) are allowed; Raf' by inchoation (Mubtada), and Nasb by hiding a verb; as if he said: 'And I fear the wolf, I fear it'. The choice is Nasb; because the verse before it starts with a verb, so it is preferred to hide a verb for 'the wolf', to coordinate what a verb acted upon with what a verb acted upon, seeking similarity in wording. It is allowed that this sentence is coordinated with the Major Sentence (Jumlah Kubra), which is: 'Asbahtu la ahmilu...'. And it is allowed that this sentence is coordinated with the Minor Sentence (Jumlah Sughra), which is: 'La ahmilu as-silah'.

The Major Sentence: Is every sentence that has no grammatical place. The Minor Sentence: Is every sentence that has a grammatical place. Because every sentence where a single word can be estimated in its place has a grammatical place, and every sentence where a single word cannot be estimated in its place has no grammatical place. The Major is like saying: 'Zaydun abuhu muntaliqun' (Zayd, his father is leaving). This entire sentence is called Major. As for your saying: 'Abuhu muntaliqun' (His father is leaving), it is called Minor; because it is in the place of the predicate of the subject, and it is part of the Major Sentence. A sentence can be Minor and Major in two different ways; like saying: 'Zaydun abuhu ghulamuhu muntaliqun' (Zayd, his father, his servant is leaving). This sentence is Major. Your saying: 'Ghulamuhu muntaliqun' is Minor; because it is a predicate for the father. Your saying: 'Abuhu ghulamuhu muntaliqun' is Minor relative to Zayd, and Major relative to the servant.

His saying: 'Wahdi' (Alone): In the place of accusative as State (Hal), as if he said: 'If I pass by it alone'. His saying: 'In nafara' (If it bolts), and 'In marartu bihi' (If I pass by it): Are two conditions that did not have a response (jawab) come after them; because the preceding speech sufficed as the response. It is like saying: 'I thank you if you do good to me'.
The meaning of the poetry: Due to his extreme old age, his strength has weakened to carry weapons to war, and he has reached a state where he cannot control a camel if he rides it, and he fears the wolf might attack him, and he is harmed by the wind if it blows, and rains if they fall. This is similar to his saying in another poem:
'When winter comes, warm me up ... For indeed the elder, winter destroys him'

'And as for when every cold departs ... Then a thin garment or a cloak'
This is like the Arabs saying in their proverbs: 'I was when I did not fear the wolf, and I was when the camel could not be led against me!!'
The apparent meaning of Ar-Rabi's statement contradicts the saying of some centenarians:
'Abu Zayd lent my right hand his weapon ... And some weapons of Time for a man are like pain'
'And I was such that if the dog denied its people ... I recognized them, while the dog was awake yet asleep'
Because Ar-Rabi' negated carrying weapons from himself due to old age, while this second one describes that he aged and thus carries Abu Zayd's weapon! Ar-Rabi' meant: He cannot carry weapons *to war*! As for Abu Zayd's weapon that this one describes carrying, it is: The staff that the elder leans upon. Abu Zayd: A Kunya for Time (Ad-Dahr). It is also nicknamed: Abu Sa'd. It is said: Abu Sa'd is the Kunya of old age. This meaning is what Al-Isba' al-Adwani meant by saying:
'Do you not see my equipment: The spear of Abu Sa'd ... Indeed I carry weapons together'

Narrators reported: Ar-Rabi' bin Dab' lived until he reached Islam, and he came to Syria to Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan with a grandson of his. His grandson entered upon Muawiyah, so Muawiyah said to him: 'Sit, O Shaykh!' He said: 'And how can one sit whose grandfather is at the door?!' Muawiyah said: 'Perhaps from the children of Ar-Rabi' bin Dab'?' He said: 'Yes.' So he ordered him to enter. When he entered, Muawiyah asked him about his age? He said:
'The Jarib (valley) to the two Zujjs has become desolate of Mayya ... Except for the gazelles and the cows'
'As if she was a soft pearl ... From women who were pearls before her'
'Youth has become early departing from me ... If it distances itself from me, it has stayed for ages'
'It left us before we left it ... When it finished its desire of our union'
'Here I am, bored of life, and ... My age and birth have reached Hujr'
'O Abu Imru' al-Qays, have you heard of him? ... Far, far away! This time is long'
'I have become such that I do not carry weapons, nor ... Do I control the head of the camel if it bolts'
'And the wolf, I fear it if I pass by it ... Alone, and I fear the winds and the rain'
'After a strength I used to rejoice in ... I have become an elder treating old age'
So Muawiyah, may Allah have mercy on him, recited: 'And he to whom We grant long life We reverse in creation.'

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Particles that Raise the Noun and Install the Predicate (Inna and sisters):
'Qays's destruction was not the destruction of one ... But it was the structure of a people that collapsed'
This verse is by 'Abda bin at-Tabib. He is from Banu Abd Shams bin Ka'b bin Sa'd bin Zayd Manat from Tamim. 'Abda': Feminine of 'Abd', transferred from adjectives behaving like nouns. At-Tabib: The skilled one in things, proficient in them. Alqama bin Abda said about it:
'If you ask me about women, then I am ... Insightful regarding the illnesses of women, a doctor'
This 'Abda' has a still Ba. As for 'Abadah' Abu Alqama, he has a moving Ba. 'Abda bin at-Tabib restricted this by describing himself:
'They give glad tidings that 'Abda is coming ... No, by the One who gathered the pilgrims at Mina'
This verse is from a poem mourning Qays bin Asim al-Minqari, the master of Banu Minqar. Before it:
'Upon you is the peace of Allah, O Qays bin Asim ... And His mercy as long as He wills to have mercy'
'A greeting from one whom you left as a target of destruction ... When he visited your land from a distance, he greeted'

The Ha in 'Walakinnahu' (But it/he): Returns to 'Al-Hulk' (The destruction). The meaning: But his destruction is the collapse of the structure of a people that collapsed; i.e., the house of their glory collapsed. 'Bunyan' here: A source used as a noun, meaning the building itself, because the 'Bunyan' meant as a source is not described by collapsing. In the Hadith: 'Whoever destroys the building of Allah is cursed.' Meaning: Killing a Muslim soul that did not deserve death.
His saying: 'Ma sha'a an yatarahhama': 'Ma' here is estimated with the verb as a source, and the source stands in place of an adverb of time. As if he said: 'The duration of His willing mercy'. And He, Glory be to Him, wills with His mercy whoever He has mercy upon eternally. 'Tahiyya' (Greeting): An emphatic source, because his saying 'Upon you is the peace of Allah' conveyed the meaning of greeting. It is like the Almighty's saying: '[This is] the decree of Allah upon you', and like Zuhair's saying:
'Know, by the life of Allah, this is an oath ... So estimate by your arm span and see where you go'

His saying: 'Gharad ar-rada' (Target of destruction): Accusative as State (Hal), even if added to a definite, because its meaning is like an adjective, i.e., 'Intended by destruction'. Its addition is estimated as separated, as if he said: 'Gharadan li-r-rada' (A target for destruction), i.e., intended for it.
His saying: 'Idha zara 'an shahtin biladaka sallama' (When he visited your land from a distance, he greeted): Can be a substitute (Badal) for 'Gharad ar-rada', so the sentence has a grammatical place. It can also be a substitute for the Ha in 'Ghadarathu' (Left him), so the sentence has no place, just as the adjective has no place.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'As if a wine bought (Sabi'ah) from Bayt Ras ... Its mixture is honey and water'
This verse is by Hassan bin Thabit bin al-Mundhir bin Haram al-Ansari. Kunya: Abu al-Walid. His name is improvised, not transferred, but it is derived from 'Al-Husn' (Beauty), so its pattern is 'Fa'al' (diptote/morphologically flexible). It could be derived from 'Al-Hiss' (Sensation), so its pattern is 'Fa'lan', diptote due to the addition at the end and being a proper noun. The most analogous is that it is diptote (not fully declined), because Hassan did not decline his name in his saying:
'The traces of the station did not stir Hassan ... Nor the journey of the tribe nor the building of tents'
As for Thabit, Al-Mundhir, and Haram: They are transferred names, not improvised. Thabit and Al-Mundhir: Descriptions from names transferred from adjectives. As for Haram: It could be transferred from their saying 'Rajulun haram', i.e., in a state of Ihram, so it is from names transferred from adjectives. It could be transferred from 'Al-Haram' which is the opposite of Halal, transferred to names from adjectives, assuming it was used as a description, so it was said: 'A thing forbidden'. Al-Haram is also a name for ants.

'As-Sabi'ah': Wine that is bought. It is said: 'Saba'tu al-khamra' with Hamza if you bought it. It is 'Fa'ilah' with the meaning of 'Maf'ulah' (passive). Ibn Harma said:
'Expensive, trembling, aged ... Its buying price is high in the hands of merchants'
He meant by 'Ar-Ras': The head of vintners, and specified him because his wine is older than others'. Abu al-Abbas al-Mubarrad said: Bayt Ras is a place.
It is narrated: 'Ka'anna Sulafatan'. As-Sulafa: The first that flows from the wine. It is said: It is what flows from grapes without pressing. Supporting this is the poet's saying:
'From the old vines it came as Sulaf ... The presser did not tread on it with his foot'
He meant: The juice came as Sulaf that he did not tread with his foot!

Regarding his saying: 'Yakunu mizajuha 'asalun wa ma'un' (Its mixture is honey and water), there are four opinions:
1. It is due to poetic necessity, and Sibawayh recited it as such.
2. He meant 'Mizajan laha' (A mixture for it), intending separation by the addition (Idafa), so he reported with an indefinite about an indefinite.
3. 'Mizajuha' is accusative as an adverb standing in place of the predicate, not the predicate itself, as if he said: 'Yakunu [mustaqirran] fi mizajiha' (It is stable in its mixture).
4. This was allowed because honey and water are types (species), and types resemble indefinites. Saying 'I ate the honey' and 'I ate honey', and 'I drank the water' and 'I drank water' is the same; because it is known you didn't eat the entire species of honey or drink the entire species of water. This is because types and genera do not have specific names for their parts qua parts; rather, every part of the genus is expressed by the genus name. Every part of water is called 'water'.

Abu Uthman al-Mazini used to narrate: 'Yakunu mizajuha' with Raf' (nominative), making it the noun of 'Yakunu', and installing 'Asalan' as its predicate, and raising 'Ma'un' by a hidden verb indicated by 'Al-Mizaj', as if he said: 'Wa mazajaha ma'un' (And water mixed it).
His saying: 'Min Bayt' is in the place of an adjective for 'Sabi'ah'. 'Yakunu mizajuha' is also in the place of an adjective for it, as if he said: 'A wine bought from Bayt Ras, being its mixture honey and water.' As for the predicate of 'Ka'anna' upon which the comparison falls, it is in another verse after this, which is:
'Upon her canine teeth, or the taste of a fresh ... Apple whose fruit was crushed by the picker'

Grammarians usually make 'Ka'anna' for comparison wherever it occurs. That is not correct. It is only pure comparison if a noun representing its subject falls in the predicate, and the predicate is more elevated or lower than it, like saying: 'Ka'anna Zaydan malakun' (As if Zayd is an angel) or 'Ka'anna Zaydan himarun' (As if Zayd is a donkey). But if its predicate is a verb, an adverb, a prepositional phrase, or an adjective of its subject's adjectives, then the meaning of doubt and supposition enters it, like saying: 'Ka'anna Zaydan qa'imun' (It seems Zayd is standing), or 'Ka'anna Zaydan fi ad-dar' (It seems Zayd is in the house). You are not comparing Zayd to anything here; you only think he is standing or in the house. Similarly, the poet's saying:
'I treated her until she recovered, an Abyssinian [she-camel] ... As if silk and green fabric were upon her'
It also has other meanings not mentioned here.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:

'Stop before separating, O Duba'a ... And let not the situation/position (Mawqif) from you be the farewell'
This verse is by Al-Qatami. His name is: Umair bin Shuyaym. Umair is a transferred name; if you wish, make it the diminutive of 'Amr', which is the earring, or life, or sleeve edge, or flesh between teeth. If you wish, make it the diminutive of their saying: 'Rajulun 'Amir' (A man constantly visiting/performing Umrah). If you wish, it is a truncated diminutive of 'Amir', 'Ammar', or 'Mu'ammar', like Zuhair from Azhar.
As for 'Shuyaym' with damma or kasra on the Shin: Transferred from the diminutive of 'Ashyam' truncated, which is one with a mole (Shamah). Al-Qatami is transferred from the hawk, because the hawk is called 'Qatam'. 'Qatam' with damma or fatha on Qaf, derived from 'Qatam', which is the craving for meat or craving for intercourse. It is said: 'Fahlun Qatim' if he is excited for mating. It is a nickname that prevailed upon him due to his saying:
'The striking Qatami (Hawk) strikes them side by side ... The fleeing sandgrouse'
The witness in the verse is the raising of 'Mawqif' (position) which is indefinite, and installing 'Al-Wada'a' (Farewell) which is definite. This was facilitated because the noun of 'Kana' and its predicate are for one thing, and his saying 'Minki' (from you) is in the place of Raf' as an adjective for 'Mawqif', as if he said: 'A position being from you'. When the indefinite is described, it is strengthened by the adjective and approaches the definite. Since the indefinite was strengthened by the adjective, and the definition by Alif-Lam is weak having no strength of other definitions, 'Al-Wada'' and 'Mawqif' became as if they were equivalent. It is narrated: 'Wa la yaku mawqifi' with addition (my position), which requires no speculation.
Duba'a, whom he flirted with, is: Duba'a bint Zufar bin al-Harith al-Kilabi, whom he praised in this poem. Therefore, he said after this verse:
'Stop, ransom your prisoner, for indeed my people ... And your people, I do not see for them a meeting'
'And how can they meet with what they permitted ... Of the great sanctities and what they wasted?'
'Did I not inform you that the ropes of Qays ... And Taghlib have separated in severance?'
It is said: 'Wada'' with fatha on Waw and 'Wida'' with kasra. 'Wida'' with kasra was the source of 'Wada'tu wida'an' (I bid farewell), and 'Wada'' with fatha was the noun.

He recited in this Chapter:
'For I am not [a son] of a human, but for a king ... Descending from the atmosphere of the sky, diving down'
This verse is by Alqama bin Abda, narrated at the end of his poem starting with:
'A heart inclined to beautiful women has carried you away ... After youth, at the time graying arrived'
Abu Ubayda Ma'mar bin al-Muthanna mentioned it belongs to a man from Abd al-Qays. Alqama and Abda (with open Ba) are transferred names. Alqama: One unit of colocynth (bitter plant). It is said: 'Food with Alqama', i.e., bitterness. Abda: The mixing stone for perfume. Abda is also: The lion's thicket. Abda is disdain; it is said: 'Abida mina ash-shay'i ya'badu abdan wa abdatan' if he disdained it.

The Lam in 'Li-insiyyin' is attached to a deleted element, likewise in 'Li-malakin'. Both have a grammatical place; because the first Lam fell in the place of the predicate of 'Laysa', so it hangs on the predicate it substituted, i.e., 'I am not a son of a human'. The second Lam in 'Li-malakin' fell in the place of a predicate for a subject, as if he said: 'But you are for a king'.
His saying: 'Tanazzala min jaww...' is a sentence in the place of an adjective for 'Malik'. 'Yaswubu' is a sentence in the place of State (Hal) from the pronoun in 'Tanazzala'. It is allowed to be a second adjective for 'Malik'. The meaning of 'Yaswubu': Intends towards the earth (dives).
He meant 'Li-Mal'akin' (For an angel), so he brought it on the original form, because 'Malik' is a lightening of 'Mal'ak', the vowel of its Hamza transferred to its Lam, as they said in 'Yas'alu': 'Ysalu', and 'Sham'al' in 'Shamal'. The poet said:
'Malik stayed in the lands of the enemy ... The winds of the north (Sham'al) blow upon him'
There is disagreement on the weight of 'Mal'ak'. Most morphology scholars said its weight is 'Ma'fal', inverted from 'Ma'lak'. They argued with the Arabs' saying: 'Alaka' if he sent, and calling a message 'Aluk' and 'Alukah'. Labid said:
'And a boy whose mother sent him ... With a message (Aluk), so we gave what he asked'
Abu Bakr bin Duraid recited:
'So who will convey to the youths of my people a message ... Coming from the kings of those who disbelieved?'
Abu Ubayd al-Qasim bin Sallam said: Its weight is 'Maf'al', derived from 'La'aka' if he sent, so there is no inversion in it. It is possible that 'La'aka' is inverted from 'Alaka'. Ibn Kaysan claimed that 'Malak' is derived from 'Malaka Yamliku' (to possess), and the Hamza in 'Mal'ak' is extra like its addition in 'Sham'al'. The weight of 'Mala'ikah' (Angels) according to those who make it inverted is 'Ma'afilah' (inverted from Ma'alikah). According to Abu Ubayd: 'Mafa'ilah', not inverted. According to Ibn Kaysan: 'Fa'a'ilah'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:

'When winter comes, warm me up ... For indeed the elder, winter destroys him'
This verse is by Ar-Rabi' bin Dab' al-Fazari, mentioned earlier. It is from a poem praising his sons and his quiver, mentioning their kindness to him:
'O deliver to my sons, the sons of Rabi' ... For the scoundrels of sons are a ransom for you'
'That I have aged and my skin has thinned ... So let not women distract you from me'
'And indeed my quiver is [like] truthful women ... And my sons did not fall short nor did they do evil'
'When winter comes, warm me up ... For indeed the elder, winter destroys him'
'And as for when every cold departs ... Then a thin garment or a cloak'
'If a youth lives two hundred years ... Then joy and youthfulness have gone'
'Al-Andhal': Lowly ones, singular 'Nadhl'. Meaning of 'Alla': Fell short in kindness. It is said: 'Ala alwan'. If you increase the action, you say 'Alla yu'alli ta'liyatan'. Zuhair said:
'A people strove after them to catch them ... But they did not act, nor blame, nor fall short'
'Al-Qarr': The cold. 'Al-Fata' (shortened): Singular of 'Fityan' (Youths). 'Al-Fata'' (extended): Youthfulness of age. It is said: 'Fata bayyin al-fata''. It is narrated: 'Al-Muru'ah' (Chivalry) and 'Al-Ladhadhah' (Pleasure). 'At-Takhayyul': Arrogance and self-admiration. It is narrated: 'Yahrimuhu' (Ages him).

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'How will it be when you pass by a house of people ... And neighbors to us who were noble?'
This verse is by Al-Farazdaq. His name is Hammam bin Ghalib. Ibn Qutayba said: Humaym bin Ghalib. Kunya: Abu Firas. Ibn Qutayba's speech differed regarding his nickname Al-Farazdaq. In 'Adab al-Katib' he said: Al-Farazdaq is pieces of dough, singular 'Farazdaqa', a nickname for him because he was grim-faced! In 'Tabaqat ash-Shu'ara', he said: He was nicknamed Al-Farazdaq for his thickness and shortness, likened to the crumb-paste women drink, which is Al-Farazdaqa. The first opinion is more correct; because he had smallpox on his face, then recovered, but his face remained grim and hateful. It is narrated a man said to him: 'O Abu Firas, your face looks like gathered vulvas!' He said: 'Look closely, do you see your mother's among them?!'
This verse is from a poem praising Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik bin Marwan and mocking Jarir bin al-Khatafi. It is said this verse is:
'Are you turning aside with us briefly (La'anna) ... To see the courtyards or the traces of tents?'
'I hold back the tears of my eyes ... And after tears there is no blame'
'La'anna': A dialect of 'La'allana' (Perhaps we). It is said: 'La'allaka', 'La'annaka' (with dotted Ghayn and Nun), 'La'annaka', 'Ra'anka', 'Allaka', 'Annaka', 'Law annaka' - all with one meaning.
It is narrated that he recited this poem to Sulayman, and when he reached:
'Three and two, so they are five ... And a sixth leaning towards my smelling [or Shimam mountain]'
'They were pushed to me, no one touched them before me ... And they are healthier than ostrich eggs'
'They spent the night beside me thrown down ... And I spent the night breaking the seals of the rings'
'As if the latches of pomegranate in it ... And ember of Ghada wood they sat upon is hot'
Sulayman said: 'You have confessed to adultery in my presence, and I am the Imam (Leader), and the Hadd punishment must be established upon you!' Al-Farazdaq said: 'From where did you obligate it upon me, O Commander of the Faithful?' He said: 'Allah Almighty says: "The woman and the man guilty of adultery, flog each of them with a hundred stripes".' Al-Farazdaq said: 'The Book of Allah Almighty averts the Hadd from me. Allah, Blessed and Exalted, says: "And the poets - the deviators follow them. Do you not see that in every valley they roam, and that they say what they do not do?" And I only said what I did not do!' Sulayman smiled and said: 'Woe to you!!'

Abu al-Qasim followed the path of Al-Khalil and Sibawayh regarding Al-Farazdaq's verse, making 'Kana' in it redundant (Za'ida). Abu al-Abbas al-Mubarrad rejected that and said: The Waw in 'Kanu' is the noun of 'Kana', and 'Lana' is its predicate, as if he said: 'And neighbors, noble, who were ours.' A group of grammarians followed Abu al-Abbas, saying: How can 'Kana' be nullified from work when the pronoun is attached to it?! This objection does not hold; because 'Zhanantu' (I thought) is nullified from work despite the pronoun's attachment in saying: 'Zaydun muntaliqun zhanantu'. We mentioned in the first book what Abu Ali al-Farisi and Ibn Jinni argued for Al-Khalil, which suffices repeating here.

The place of 'Lana' is genitive (Khafḍ) according to Al-Khalil's view, because it is in the place of an adjective for 'Jiran' (neighbors). It is in the place of accusative (Nasb) according to Abu al-Abbas's view, because it is in the place of the predicate of 'Kana'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'When I die, people will be two types: A rejoicer [at my death] ... And another praising what I used to do'
This verse is by Al-'Ajir as-Saluli, attributed to Banu Salul, a tribe of the Arabs. 'Ajir: Transferred name. Possibly diminutive of 'Ajar', from 'Ajara 'unuqahu' (twisted his neck). Possibly truncated diminutive of 'A'jar' (Protruding navel). As-Saluli: Improvised name.
It is narrated: 'Mittu' and 'Muttu' (kasra/damma on Meem). Narrated: 'Sinfani' (Two types - Nom.), 'Sinfayni' (Acc./Gen.), and 'Nisfayni' (Two halves). Whoever raises it hides 'the matter/situation' in 'Kana', making 'An-nasu sinfani' a subject and predicate clause in place of 'Kana's' predicate. Whoever installs makes 'An-nasa' the noun of 'Kana' and 'Sinfayni' its predicate; there is no witness in this narration. 'Shamitun' and 'Akharu' are raised as predicates of a hidden subject, as if explaining the two types: 'They are a rejoicer and another praising'. It is allowed to raise 'Shamitun' as a substitute (Badal) for 'As-Sinfan'. It is allowed the estimation is: 'One of them is a rejoicer, and the other praising'.
After this verse:
'But there will weep for me calamities and a council ... And disheveled ones humiliated in councils, starving'
'And a seeker of refuge whom the people struck a blow ... Far from allies, obtaining what he used to gather'
'I returned to him what the weak opinion missed in the forenoon ... And yesterday, until he returned to us leaning'
'And he was not - that he was - my cousin nor my brother ... But whenever I can remove harm, I am useful'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'She is the cure for my disease if I attained her ... And not from her is the cure of the disease granted'
This verse is by Hisham, brother of Dhu al-Rumma. It is an improvised name derived from 'Hashamtu ash-shay' (I broke the thing). Abu al-Fath mentioned: Transferred from the source 'Hashamtu'.
It is possible that 'Laysa' in this verse is the operator, so 'the matter/situation' is hidden in it, and the sentence is its predicate. It is possible it is like 'Ma' which does no work, a dialect of some Arabs. Regarding 'Law', it can be the one indicating the impossibility of a thing due to the impossibility of another, and the answer is deleted, as if he said: 'If I attained her, I would be cured', so the mention of cure beforehand sufficed. Just as we say: 'I thank you if you do good to me'. It is possible 'Law' is for wishful thinking, as if he said: 'Would that I attained her'.
The Ba in 'Biha' is attached to 'Zhafirtu'. 'Min' in 'Minha' is attached to 'Mabdhul', having no place as it attaches to an apparent word.
After this verse:
'She reveals the side-teeth of one with serrated teeth when she smiles ... As if he is watered with wine, saturated'
'Tajlu': Reveals/Shows. 'Al-'Awarid': The premolars/laughing teeth. 'Az-Zulm': Water flowing on the teeth (luster). 'Al-Munhal': Given a first drink. 'Al-Ma'lul': Given a second drink. 'Ar-Rah': Wine.
This verse is also narrated for Ka'b bin Zuhair, and for Hisham.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Particles that Install Nouns and Raise Predicates:
'O Muawiyah, indeed we are humans, so be kind ... For we are not mountains nor iron'
This verse is by Uqaybah al-Asadi, as mentioned by Sibawayh. Uqaybah: Transferred name. Possibly diminutive of 'Aqabah' (small difficult pass). Or diminutive of 'Uqbah' (like Zulmah) - remains of broth/meat in a borrowed pot. Or 'Uqbah' in riding. Or 'Uqbat al-Qamar' (return of the moon). The poet said:
'His lock of hair does not taste washing or oils ... Nor scented powder except at the return of the moon'
Asad: Transferred name, possibly from the lion (Asad), or source of 'Asida ar-rajulu' (became lion-like/brave).
'Az-Zubayr': Transferred name. Zubayr: Mud/Slime. Zubayr: A well lined with stones. Zubayr: A written book. Ibn Jinni recited: 'Like the written scroll and the Zubayr'. Zubayr: Calamity. Zubayr: Insult/Humiliation.

Sibawayh recited this verse as 'Wa la al-hadida' (Nor iron) with Nasb, as Abu al-Qasim recited, and rejected it upon him. It is said the poetry has genitive (Khafd) rhymes, which is:
'O Muawiyah, indeed we are humans, so be kind ... For we are not mountains nor iron'
'You ate our land and stripped it bare ... So is there any standing crop or harvested?'
'Do you hope for eternity when we perish ... While there is no eternity for us nor for you?'
'So consider us a nation that perished in waste ... Your emir increases, and Abu Yazid'
'Leave the betrayal of leadership and be upright ... And the advancing of the lowlifes and slaves'

Those who argued for Sibawayh claimed: This verse is from a poem attributed to Abdullah bin az-Zubayr al-Asadi. It is said: It is by Al-Kumayt bin Ma'ruf al-Asadi, saying in it:
'Calamities threw the women of the family of Amr ... With a decree to which they stood stunned'
'It turned their black hair white ... And turned their white faces black'
'Turn it over, O Banu Harb, upon yourselves ... And do not shoot the far target with it'
It is not denied that the verse belongs to both poems; because poets may borrow speech, or take a verse exactly without changing it, like Al-Farazdaq:
'You see people, when we walk, walking behind us ... And if we nod to the people, they stop'
This verse belongs to Jamil bin Abdullah, plagiarized by Al-Farazdaq. Qays bin al-Khatim said:
'If our swords fall short, their connection is ... Our steps towards our enemies, so we strike'
The poem has genitive rhymes. Al-Akhnas bin Shihab al-Yashkuri said:
'And if our swords fall short, their connection is ... Our steps towards our enemies, so we strike'
The poem has nominative rhymes.

Imru' al-Qays said in a poem rhyming in Ba:
'Whose are the dwellings effaced since eras ... The south of Al-Fard became desolate, then Al-Kharib'
'A house of a tribe, changed after them ... To inhabiting wild beasts, and Time has consequences'
'Time took its turn on them so they departed ... Time ate upon them and drank'
An-Nabigha al-Ja'di took half of the third verse and reversed it in a poem rhyming in Lam, saying:
'My neighbor asked me about my family ... And when a person of intellect is stumped, he asks'
'She asked me about people who perished ... Time drank upon them and ate'
Abu al-Abbas al-Mubarrad recited it in 'Al-Kamil' according to Imru' al-Qays's poetry but attributed it to An-Nabigha al-Ja'di, which is a mistake.
Sometimes a poet repeats a single verse of his poetry in two poems with different rhymes, like Al-Husayn bin al-Humam al-Murri:
'When I saw that affection is not beneficial to me ... Even if it was a day of stars, dark'
'We were patient, and patience was a nature of ours ... With our swords cutting a hand and a wrist'
'Splitting heads of people dear ... To us, while they were more disobedient and unjust'
Then he said in another poem:
'When I saw that affection is not beneficial to me ... Even if it was a day of a star, gray'
'We were patient, and patience was a nature of ours ... With our swords cutting heads and a shoulder'
'Splitting heads of men dear ... To us, while they were more disobedient and destructive'
In the poetry of Abu at-Tayyib al-Mutanabbi, there are many verses he plagiarized, changing only a little, like his saying:
'As if every request in his ears ... Is the shirt of Joseph in the eyelids of Jacob'
This verse is transferred from Al-Husayn's saying:
'As if every request in his ears ... Is the shirt of Joseph in the eyelids of his father'
And his saying:
'And of the misery of the world upon the freeman is that he sees ... An enemy for whom he has no escape from friendship'
This verse is transferred from Ishaq al-Mawsili's saying:
'And of the misery of the world upon the freeman is that he sees ... An enemy, so he desires it to be said: A friend'
If the matter of poetry is of this attribute, it is not denied that his saying: 'O Muawiyah, indeed we are humans, so be kind...' occurred in two different poems by Uqaybah al-Asadi, or occurred in a poem by Uqaybah with genitive rhymes, and a poem by Ibn az-Zubayr with accusative rhymes.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Prepositions:

'So I said to the riders when appeared to them ... From the right of Al-Hubayya a look from the front (Qabal)'
This verse is by Al-Qatami, whose name we mentioned. After it:
'Was it a glimpse of the brightness of lightning my sight saw ... Or the face of a high woman, by whom the curtains strutted?'
'She sends to us whenever our position is high ... The scent of lavender in which dew flowed, moist'
Al-Hubayya: A place in Syria. It is of the names that came diminutive and have no non-diminutive form. Meaning of 'Nazratun Qabal': A look not preceded by another look. It is said: 'Ra'aytu al-hilala qabalan', meaning no one saw it before me. 'Ar-Rakb': Plural of 'Rakib' according to Al-Akhfash; according to Sibawayh it is a collective noun, not a plural. It is narrated: 'Ala bihim' and 'Alat bihim': Meaning made them ascend and overlook to look at its top. It is like saying: 'A'laytuhum', because Ba and Hamza alternate in making verbs transitive, like: 'Dhahabtu bihi' and 'Adh-habtuhu'. 'Sana al-barq': Its light. 'Ikhtalat': Strutted/walked proudly. 'Al-Kilal': Curtains, singular 'Killah'. He meant the face of a high woman appeared to them from behind the curtain, so they looked at it in wonder. Whoever narrates 'Biha' returns the pronoun to 'Aliyah'. Whoever narrates 'Bihi' returns it to the face. If feminine, the sentence is a State (Hal) for 'Aliyah'; if masculine, a State for the Face. 'Whenever our position was high': i.e., in a high place hit by wind. It is said: 'So-and-so sat on the high part of the wind', i.e., in an overlooking place hit by wind. 'Al-Khadil': Very wet.
He made 'An' (from/about) a noun and introduced the preposition upon it. In this verse is a witness that 'An' is a noun, and a witness that 'Ala' is a verb.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this verse:
'She went early from upon it after her thirst was complete ... Clucking, and from a shell (Qayd) in a distinct desert'
This verse is by Muzahim bin al-Harith al-Uqayli. Muzahim and Al-Harith are names transferred from adjectives to proper nouns. The ram is nicknamed Abu Muzahim if it has great horns. He is called Ash-Shaqhatab. Before it:
'Is that, or a sandgrouse (Kudriyyah) whose chick remained ... Thrown in Sharawra like the dependent orphan'
He meant by Kudriyyah: A sandgrouse with turbidity in its color. Sandgrouse are two types: Kudri and Juni. Kudri: Dusty colored. Juni: Black colored. Zuhair mentioned it:
'Juni sandgrouse, like the stones of Al-Qism is their pasture ... In As-Siyy, there is no Astragalus or Caltrop'
'Al-Laqa': The thrown thing not paid attention to. Sharawra: A place. He likened it in its isolation and bad state to the orphan. 'Al-Mu'ayyal': The poor. Al-Asma'i said: He said 'Laqa bi-Sharawra' because sandgrouse only lay eggs in the ground in hollows, not in trees. 'Ghadat min 'alayhi ba'da ma tamma': She stayed with her chick until she needed water, became thirsty, and flew seeking water when her thirst was complete. 'Az-Zhim'': The duration of patience from water. It is narrated: 'Ba'da ma tamma khimsuha', i.e., coming to water every five days. He didn't mean she waits five days; that is for camels, not birds, but he used it as a metaphor. This is Abu Hatim's view, thus the narration 'Zhim'uha' is better. Al-Asma'i said: 'Min 'alayhi' means from above the chick. Abu Ubayda said: It means she went from *at* her chick. Yaqub said: 'After her thirst was complete' means she drank every three or four days once.
Abu Hatim said: I said to Al-Asma'i: How did he say 'Ghadat' (went early morning) when sandgrouse go to water at night? He said: He didn't mean morning, but it is a metaphor for haste. The Arabs say: 'Bakkarat ilayya al-ashiyya' (She came early to me in the evening) while there is no morning (Bukur) there. Abu Zayd recited:
'She came early reading a script after midnight in the dew ... Forbidden upon you is my blame and rebuke'
An-Nabigha adh-Dhubyani used this similarly:
'Avoiding a black rock-line, its bottoms ... The walk of the morning slave-girls carrying bundles'
Abu Hatim said: Meaning of 'Tasillu': Her insides make a sound from thirst and dryness. 'As-Salil': Sound of dry things. Others said: Meant she makes noise in flying. 'Al-Qayd': Top shell of the egg. Narrated: 'Bi-zayza'a majhali' adding Zayza' to Majhal. 'Az-Zayza'': Rough ground. 'Al-Majhal': Desolate land without landmarks. Narrated: 'Bi-bayda'a': Desert that destroys ('Tabidu') who travels it.
'Zhalla farkhuha': Sentence with grammatical place (Adjective for Kudriyyah). 'Tasillu': Accusative as State.
'Adhalika': Refers to a male ostrich mentioned before:
'I crossed with a swift she-camel, as if her saddles ... Were upon a dyer (ostrich) mounting the rough grounds, huge'

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Hatta:
'So oh wonder! Even Kulayb insults me ... As if their father is Nahshal or Mujashi'
This verse is by Al-Farazdaq. We mentioned his name earlier. It is narrated: 'Fa-ya 'ajaban' with Nunation, and 'Ya 'ajaba' without. Whoever nunates it has two ways: 1. Indefinite vocative. 2. A source (Masdar), with the vocative deleted, as if saying: 'O my people, wonder a wonder'. Whoever does not nunate has two ways: 1. (Better) Added vocative, dialect of 'Ya ghulama aqbil'. As if saying: 'O wonder, be present; for this is your time'. 2. Intending 'Ya 'ajabah' (Oh wonder!), mostly used in lamentation, but used elsewhere.
His saying: 'Hatta Kulaybun tasubbuni': Speech uttered in contempt of Kulayb, because 'Hatta' (Even) is used for contempt or magnification. 'Hatta' did not operate grammatically on the word because it does not operate on sentence phrases, only their positions. There is a deletion, as if saying: 'Do people insult me, such that even Kulayb insults me?!' The Kufans allow lowering 'Kulaybin' on the basis of limit (Ghayah), making 'Tasubbuni' emphatic.
Meaning: Even Kulayb is in this state of cursing. 'As-Sib' (with kasra) is one who abuses you. It is said the verse is:
'We seized the horizons of the sky over you ... Ours are its two moons, the stars, and the rising ones'
'Step aside from the Batha (valley), for its ancient part ... Is ours, and the anchored towering mountains'
'And we used to, if the tyrant twisted his cheek ... Strike him until the neck veins straightened'
Al-Mufaddal said: He meant by the two moons: Muhammad and Ibrahim (peace be upon them), and by the stars: The guided Caliphs.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'I traveled by night with them until their raid mounts became weary ... And until the steeds were not led by reins'
This verse is from the famous poetry of Imru' al-Qays. 'Al-Qays': Intensity (according to Ali bin Hamza). Others said: Name of an idol. Al-Asma'i disliked saying 'Imru' al-Qays' and narrated 'O Imru' Allah'. Kunya: Abu Wahb, Abu al-Harith. Name said to be Jundah, Imru' al-Qays is a nickname. 'Al-Jundah': Yellow dune. 'As-Sura': Night travel. 'Ma yuqadna bi-arsan': They were exhausted so they didn't need leading.
'Bi-him' attached to 'Saraytu'. 'Takillu matiyyuhum': Sentence in place of Genitive by 'Hatta', estimated as a source standing for a time adverb: 'Until the time of the weariness of their mounts'. This is for those who install 'Takillu' (with Nasb) via 'Hatta' or hidden 'An'.
Whoever raises 'Takillu': The sentence is not genitive in place, but coordinated with 'Saraytu', as if saying: 'I traveled with them until their mounts became weary'. It is a reported State (Hal) after its occurrence time; so estimated as past tense. 'Ma yuqadna': Sentence in place of Raf' (Nominative) as predicate of 'Al-Jiyad' (subject).

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'He threw the scroll so he might lighten his saddle ... And the provisions, even his sandals he threw them'
This verse: People attribute it to Al-Mutalammis, but it is not in his Diwan. It is by Ibn Marwan an-Nahwi, said regarding the story of Al-Mutalammis when he fled from Amr bin Hind. After it:
'He went thinking the courier of Amr was behind him ... In fear, and he left his land and hated it'
He said 'He left his land and hated it' because Al-Mutalammis said:
'She yearned for the farthest palm tree, so I said to her ... Basl (forbidden) upon you, are not those calamities?'
'My mother is Levantine, since we have no Iraq ... A people we love while our people are grim'
'You will not walk the paths of Al-Bubah heading to Najd ... As long as Amr lives nor as long as Qabus lives'
Al-Mutalammis had mocked Amr bin Hind. Tarafa also mocked him. This reached Amr bin Hind, who didn't show anger. Then they praised him. He wrote a letter for each to his governor in Al-Hira, ordering their killing. He misled them that it was a gift. Al-Mutalammis said to Tarafa: 'We both mocked the King. If he wanted to give to us, he would, without writing to Al-Hira. Come let us check the letters. If good, we enter; if bad, we flee!' Tarafa refused. Al-Mutalammis swore to open his. He found a boy who read it: 'Woe to Al-Mutalammis's mother!' He told Tarafa: 'Open yours, it's the same!' Tarafa said: 'He wouldn't dare against me to anger my people!' Al-Mutalammis threw his scroll in the river and fled to Syria. He said:
'I threw it at the bend by the side of Kafir ... Thus I acquire every misleading cat (decree)'
'I accepted the water for it when I saw it ... The current shifting it in every stream'
Tarafa went and was killed. Al-Mutalammis escaped.
Whoever narrates: 'Hatta na'luhu' (Raf'), the Ha in 'Alqaha' returns to the sandal only. Whoever installs or lowers 'Na'l', the pronoun can return to the sandal or the scroll.

Narrated: 'Alqa al-Haqibata' (bag) and 'Al-Hashiyya' (saddle pad).

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Oath:
'So oppose, for no, by Allah, you do not descend a valley (Tal'ah) ... Of the earth except you are knowledgeable of humiliation'
This verse: Attributed to Muzahim al-Uqayli, but not in his Diwan. I think the attributor confused it with his poem starting:
'A dwelling at Al-Arin excited you, becoming wild ... From the tribe, and storms intensified upon it'
Meaning: A traveler in Arab lands outside sacred months, without a protector, is robbed or killed. He would seek protection from a tribe leader.
'Al-Muhalafah': Contracting and reconciliation. 'Tal'ah': Low place, or high place. Tarafa's verse allows both:
'I am not one to settle in the valleys/hills out of fear ... But when the people seek help, I help'
Whoever makes 'Tal'ah' high places means he doesn't hide in mountains fear of raids. Whoever makes it low places means he doesn't hide from guests.
'Fala wallahi tahbitu': Meant 'La tahbitu' (You do not descend), placing 'La' out of place. Or 'La' mentioned first sufficed.
'Illa anta li-dh-dhulli 'arifun': Sentence in place of State (Hal) for pronoun in 'Tahbitu'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'By Allah, does there remain upon the days one with crooked horns (Dhu Hayad) ... In a high mountain, containing jasmine and myrtle?'
This verse: Narrated for Malik bin Khalid al-Khuna'i in Sibawayh. Abu Ja'far said: Abu Nasr recited it for Abu Dhu'ib al-Hudhali. Abu Amr narrated it for Al-Fadl bin Abbas.
'Ta-Allahi' and 'Li-Allahi': Both oaths with wonder.
'Dhu Hayad': The ibex. 'Hayad': Veering/fleeing. Or crookedness in the horns.
'Mishmakherr': High mountain. 'Zhayyan': Wild jasmine. 'As': Myrtle or bee traces.
'Bi-mishmakherrin': Attached to 'Ka'in' (existing). 'Bi-hi azh-zhayyan': In place of adjective for 'Mishmakherr'.
'Ala al-ayyam': State for 'Dhu Hayad'; i.e., Does he remain while days alternate upon him.
Before it:
'O Mayy, if you lose a people you bore ... Or they are snatched from you, for Time is a snatcher'
'Amr and Abd Manaf whom I knew ... At the valley of Mecca refusing injustice are Abbas'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this verse:
'So I said, By the oath of Allah, I will not cease sitting ... Even if they cut my head in your presence and my limbs'
This verse: Famous poetry of Imru' al-Qays. 'Al-Awsal': Limbs. 'Ladayki': With you. 'Abrahu': Cease/Leave. Answer to 'Law' deleted: 'I would not leave'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'So a group of the people said when I implored them ... Yes, and a group [said]: By the oath of Allah (Laymunu Allah), we do not know'
This verse: By Nusayb. He was a black slave from Wadi al-Qura, bought his freedom writing, praised Abd al-Aziz bin Marwan who bought his loyalty. Kunya: Abu Mihjan. Nusayb: Transferred name. Diminutive of 'Nusb' (sacrificial stone) or 'Nasb' (fatigue). Abu Bakr bin Duraid narrated: I met Nusayb and asked: Why named Nusayb? He said: I was born to a family in Waddan, my master said: 'Bring him to look at him'. He said: 'He is erected in creation (Munsab)', so I was named Nusayb. Then Abd al-Aziz bought and freed me. This implies diminutive of 'Munsab'.
The poem is one of his best:
'O eagle of the nest, the nest of Dariyyah ... May you be watered by morning clouds, as an eagle and a nest'
'Nights pass and months, and I do not see ... The passing of nights making me forget the daughter of 'Amr'
'She says: Visit us or abandon us...'
'So a group of the people said when I implored them: ... Yes, and a group: By the oath of Allah, we do not know'

It is also narrated: 'He threw the *Hashiya* (cushion/saddle pad),' which is what the rider rides upon. Whoever narrates: 'Until his *Na'l* (sandal/horseshoe)' in the nominative case (*Raf'*), then the pronoun 'ha' in 'alqaha' (he threw it) refers back to the *Na'l*, and nothing else. Whoever puts *Na'l* in the accusative (*Nasb*) or genitive (*Khafd*), it is permissible for the pronoun in 'alqaha' to refer to the *Na'l*, and it is permissible for it to refer to the *Sahifa* (page/writing), and there would be hysteron proteron (inversion of order) in the verse, as if he said: 'He threw the page—he threw it—so that he might lighten his saddle, and the provisions, even his sandals.' The *Rahl* (saddle) is for the she-camel what the *Sarj* (saddle) is for the horse. Abu al-Qasim recited in the chapter of Oaths: 'So oppose, for by God, you will not descend a *Tal'ah* (ravine/slope) ... of the earth, unless you are acquainted with humiliation.' This verse: A group attributes it to Muzahim al-Uqayli, but I did not find it in his collected poetry (Diwan). I suspect that the one who attributed it to him imagined it was from his poem that begins: 'Did a dwelling at Al-Arin excite you, which became desolate ... of the tribe, and upon which the storms intensified?' But this verse is not from that poem, nor does it contain meaning befitting this verse! The meaning of this verse is: A traveler in the lands of the Arabs, outside of the sacred months, if he does not have a protector to grant him sanctuary, or a confederate to make a pact with, he would be robbed in every place, and perhaps killed. So a stranger would seek sanctuary with the master of the tribe, who would write for him on an arrow or something else: 'So-and-so is my neighbor (under my protection),' or someone would accompany him to travel with him until he left his jurisdiction, then he would seek sanctuary with the master of another tribe. He would continue to do this in every place he passed until he reached his own tribe. For this reason, Al-A'sha said regarding a man who went out during a sacred month, then the month was about to end while he had not reached his people, so he took refuge with a man who granted him sanctuary and protected him. Al-A'sha said to Al-Rifad: 'Before you, Al-Rifad fulfilled his duty to his neighbor ... so he saved him from what he feared and dreaded; He caught him at the unsheathing of the weapons after ... he had passed not a short distance, and had almost perished.' *Muhalafah* (Alliance): Making a pact and reconciliation. Its origin is that each of the two men swears to his companion that he will not betray him. The *Tal'ah* here: The low place in the ground, though it can also be the high place in the ground. The verse of Tarafa allows for both meanings, which is his saying: 'And I am not one to settle in the *Tila'* (ravines/hills) out of fear ... but when the people seek assistance, I assist.' It is also narrated 'Li-baytatin' (for a night). Whoever interprets *Tila'* in this verse as high places, its meaning is that he does not settle in high places for fear of being raided. This meaning is strengthened by the narration of the one who narrated 'Li-baytatin'. Whoever interprets it as low places, its meaning is: He does not settle in hidden places fleeing from guests seeking him; because the miser hides his location and shortens the height of his tent so strictly that he is not sought. This second meaning is supported by his saying: 'But when the people seek assistance, I assist.' And his saying: 'So no, by God, you descend' (*Fa-la wallahi tahbitu*), he meant: 'So no, by God, you will NOT descend.' He placed 'La' (no/not) in a position other than its [usual] place, just as Al-A'sha said: 'Old age settled its burdens upon him ... and old age did not beguile him, except with a beguiling.' He meant: 'And nothing but old age beguiled him with a beguiling.' It is possible that when he mentioned the first 'La', it sufficed him from repeating it a second time. And his saying: 'Min al-ard' (of the earth): If you make 'Min' connected to 'Tahbitu' (descend), it has no place [grammatically], because it connects to an explicit noun. If you make it connected to an omitted word, it has a place, which is in the position of an adjective for 'Tal'ah'. And his saying: 'Illa anta li-dhulli 'arifu' (Unless you are acquainted with humiliation): This is a sentence that has a grammatical place because it is in the position of a circumstantial accusative (*Hal*) from the pronoun in 'Tahbitu'. Abu al-Qasim recited in this chapter: 'By God, does there remain upon the days a *Dhu Hayad* (Ibex) ... in a *Mushmakhirr* (lofty place) containing *Zayyan* (wild jasmine) and myrtle?' This verse: It is narrated for Malik bin Khalid al-Khuna'i, as stated in the Book of Sibawayh. Abu Ja'far Ahmad bin Ubayd said: Abu Nasr recited this poetry to me for Abu Dhu'ayb al-Hudhali. He said: And Abu Amr narrates this poetry for Al-Fadl bin Abbas Utbah bin Abi Lahab. It is narrated: 'Tallahi' and 'Lillahi' (By God/For God), and both are oaths containing the meaning of wonder. By 'Dhu Hayad', he means the Ibex (*Wa'l*). *Hayad* means dodging and fleeing. This is how Abu al-Abbas Muhammad bin Yazid narrated it. It is also narrated 'Dhu Hiyad' with a Kasra on the Ha, and he said: It is the plural of *Haydah*, like *Haydah* and *Hid* (menstruation). This is how Abu Sa'id al-Sukkari narrated it in the poems of the Hudhalis. It is said: It is a crookedness in the horn of the Ibex. *Mushmakhirr*: The high mountain. *Zayyan*: Wild jasmine. *As*: Myrtle. It is said *As*: Traces of bees when they pass and drops of honey fall from them; Al-Shaybani narrated this. It is said: Bee droppings on stone. It is said: The remains of ashes on the tripod stones (*Athafi*). The author of Kitab al-Ayn said: *As* is a type of honey. The 'Ba' (in) in his saying 'Bi-Mushmakhirrin' is connected to [the implied word] 'Ka'in' (existing/being), meaning: existing in a lofty place.

And the 'Ba' (in/with) in his saying: 'bihi al-zayyanu' (in it is wild jasmine) also has a grammatical position, and it is in the position of an adjective for 'Mushmakhirr', as if he said: 'in which exists wild jasmine,' or 'in which is settled wild jasmine.' In this case, 'Al-Zayyan' is the agent (*Fa'il*) of the settling/existing. It is also permissible for 'Al-Zayyan' to be nominative due to being the subject (*Mubtada*), and 'bihi' is its predicate (*Khabar*); so the 'Ba' in this case would be in the position of nominative, while in the first case it was in the position of genitive (*Khafd*), and in both cases, it connects to an omitted word. His saying: 'Ala al-ayyam' (upon the days) is in the position of a circumstantial accusative (*Hal*) from 'Dhu Hayad'; meaning: 'A Dhu Hayad (Ibex) does not remain while the days succeed each other upon it.' He meant: 'Upon the succession of days,' or 'Upon the passing of days,' so he omitted the possessed noun (*Mudaf*) and placed the possessor (*Mudaf ilayhi*) in its stead. Before this verse is: 'O Mayya, if you lose a people to whom you gave birth ... or if you are bereft of them, for indeed Time is a snatcher. Amr and Abd Manaf, my two parents whom I knew ... in the belly of Mecca, refusing injustice, frowning [fierce].' It is also narrated: 'In the belly of Ar'ar.' This is how Abu Sa'id al-Sirafi and Abu Ali al-Farisi narrated it. Abu al-Qasim recited regarding this verse: 'So I said, The oath of God, I will not leave sitting ... even if they cut off my head in your presence and my limbs.' This verse: Is from the famous poetry of Imru' al-Qays, and we have mentioned his name and agnomen previously. *Awsal*: Limbs, singular is *Wasl*. The meaning of *Ladayk*: With/at you. *Abrah*: To cease/leave (used with negative to mean 'remain'). The answer to 'Law' (even if) is omitted because what preceded it suffices for it, as if he said: 'Even if they cut off my head, I would not leave!' Abu al-Qasim recited in this chapter: 'So a group of the people said when I adjured them ... 'Yes,' and a group said, 'By the oath of God, we do not know.'' This verse: Belongs to Nusayb. He was a black slave belonging to a man from the people of Wadi al-Qura. He entered a contract of manumission (*Kitabah*) for himself, praised Abd al-Aziz bin Marwan, who then bought his loyalty (patronage). His agnomen (*Kunya*): Abu Mihjan. Ibn Qutaybah claimed his agnomen was: Abu al-Hajna, and recited a verse by Kuthayyir satirizing him: 'I saw Abu al-Hajna passing among the people ... and the color of Abu al-Hajna is the color of beasts. You see him, despite the blackness that has loomed over him ... even if he is oppressed, having the face of an oppressor.' Nusayb is a transferred name. It is possible that it is the diminutive of *Nusub*, which is a stone upon which they used to slaughter what they sacrificed to idols. God Almighty said: '...and what has been slaughtered upon the *Nusub*.' It is possible it is the diminutive of *Nasab*, which is fatigue, or the diminutive of *Nasab* (with Fatha on Nun and Sukun on Sad)—which is what is set up—so he worshipped other than God. God Almighty said: 'As if they were hastening to a *Nusub*.' It is possible it is the diminutive of *Nisab*, or *Nasib*, being a diminutive of trimmings (*Tarkhim*). Al-Isfahani narrated with a chain of transmission from Abu Bakr bin Durayd, who said: I met Nusayb one day at the gate of Hisham bin Abd al-Malik, so I said to him: 'O Abu Mihjan, why were you named Nusayb? Is it because of your saying in your poetry: 'The fatigue (*Nusub*) appeared to her'?!' He said: 'No, but I was born among a household in Waddan, and my master said: 'Bring him to us so we may look at him.' He said: 'He is erected/upright (*Munsab*) in creation.' So I was named Al-Nusub, then Abd al-Aziz bin Marwan bought me and freed me.' This report implies that it is the diminutive of: *Munsab*, which is the one overlooking in straightness, and it was trimmed by removing its extra letters, just as if you made the diminutive of Muhammad and trimmed it, you would say: Humayd. As for *Al-Mihjan*: It is a stick with a hooked end, called *Al-Qasqasah*, and the common people mispronounced it and said: *Al-Kaskasah*. *Al-Hajnah*: Feminine of *Ahjan*, and the plural of *Ahjan* is *Hujn*. Al-Nabigha said: 'Hooks (*Hujn*) on towering ropes ... extended by hands pulling toward you.' It is the bent and crooked. The poem containing this verse is among his finest poetry, which says: 'Ho, O Eagle of the nest, the nest of Dariyyah ... may you be watered by the morning clouds, concerning an eagle and a nest. Nights and months pass, and I do not see ... the passing of nights making me forget the daughter of Amr. She says: Connect with us or abandon us, and she may see ... that if she abandons, there is no connection with abandonment. So I was not pleased with what she said, nor did I show anger ... and my chest became tight with what I concealed of her love. I remained in Dhu Waddan reciting to my young she-camel ... while I had upon her neither a young camel nor a virgin camel. And I do not adjure the shepherds except as a distraction ... regarding the one with clear canine teeth and pleasant scent. So the shepherds said to me: 'Why do you not mix with us?' ... I said: 'Yes (I will), for I have been thinking of her!' And mention was made to me of one sorrowful, familiar with ... the young camels of Adiy, or the young camels of Banu Wabr. So a group of the people said when I adjured them: ... 'Yes,' and a group said, 'By the oath of God, we do not know.'

'By Him whom the pilgrims perform Hajj to His House ... And knows the days of sacrifices and slaughter'
'Indeed nights Layla spent at Al-Ghamr increased me ... In love for Al-Ghamr and its people'
'So does Allah hold it a sin against me that I mentioned her ... And distracted my companions with her on the night of departure (Nafr)?'
