Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Two nursing friends of the milk of one mother's breast, they swore alliance ... By a dark black [night/blood/ash], forever (Awad), we shall not separate'
This verse: By Al-Asha of Bakr. Praising Al-Muhallaq bin Jusham al-Kilabi. Al-Muhallaq was named so because a camel bit his face leaving a ring-mark. He was obscure with no fame, had daughters no one proposed to. Al-Asha passed by him. He slaughtered a camel for him. Al-Asha asked: Do you have a need? He said: Spread my mention, perhaps I become famous and my daughters get proposals. Al-Asha went to Ukaz and recited this poem. Before evening, all his daughters were proposed to!
Before this verse:
'By my life, many eyes have glanced ... At the light of a fire on the high ground burning'
'Kindled for two shivering men warming themselves ... And Generosity and Al-Muhallaq spent the night at the fire'
He mentioned the fire and alliance because they used to swear alliance over fire. He made Generosity and Al-Muhallaq like two brothers nursing from one mother.
'Awad' (Forever): Damma for Bakr bin Wa'il. Said to be a name of Time (Dahr).
'Bi-ashama dajin': Seven opinions: 1. Ash (Ramad). 2. Night. 3. Womb. 4. Blood (they dipped hands in it). 5. Nipple. 6. Wineskin. 7. Blood of sacrifices to idols. 'Asham': Black. If blood dries, it turns black.
'Radi'ay': Accusative as State (Hal) or Predicate of 'Bata'. Or 'Radi'' meaning 'Radi'' (Sucking - active) taking one object, or 'Murdi'' (Nursing - causative) taking two objects.
'Awad la naftariqu': If 'Awad' is a noun of Damm (joining/gathering), it has three ways. If a name of Time, two ways: Substitute for 'Asham', or Adverb ('We shall not separate forever').
'La natafarraqu': Came as the answer to the oath, imitating the wording of the swearers.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of the Active Participle:
'It appeared to me that I am not catching (Mudrik) what has passed ... Nor outstripping (Sabiq) a thing if it is kneeling/crouching'
This verse: Narrated for Zuhair bin Abi Sulma, Surmah al-Ansari, or Ibn Rawaha. Zuhair: Transferred name. Surmah: Piece of camels (10-40). Rawaha: Improvised from Rawh.
'Anni lastu mudrika...': Sentence in place of Raf' as Subject of 'Bada'.
'Lastu mudrika...': Sentence in place of Raf' as Predicate of 'Anna'.
'Sabiqan': Accusative coordinated with 'Mudrikan'. Or Raf' (hidden subject). Or Genitive (imagining Ba in Mudrik).
'Ma': Relative (Alladhi) or Indefinite.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Indeed I am connecting my rope with your rope ... And feathering my arrows with the feathers of your arrows'
This verse: Imru' al-Qays (Bin Hujr or Bin Aish). Meaning: A metaphor for agreement and following. 'Hujr': Forbidden/Sanctuary.
After it:
'As long as I do not find you on the guidance of a trace ... Which a tracker tracks your path before me'
'Indeed I cut off him who cuts me off ... And I renew the connection of him who seeks my connection'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'And how many filling his eyes with something other than it ... When the white women like statues went towards the Jamrah'
This verse: By Umar bin Abi Rabi'ah. Kunya: Abu al-Khattab. Umar: Counted among improvised names, though modified from 'Amir'.
This poem was said about the daughter of Marwan bin al-Hakam. She performed Hajj and wanted to see him but feared scandal. She sent a woman to guide him blindfolded at night. He touched the tent with henna to mark it. Next day he found the tent. She sent him money to keep quiet. He refused unless she accepted his gift. She did. He said:
'And how many a slain one for whom no blood money is paid ... And of a mortgage locked (Ghaliq) when Mina gathered him!'
'And how many filling his eyes with something other than it ... When the white women like statues went towards the Jamrah!'
'Dragging the tails of woolen wraps (Murut) on legs ... Plump, when they turn their backs are full'
'Friendly women, robbing the forbearing man of his heart ... Oh how long they traversed and how beautiful the sight'
'I have not seen a sight for a viewer like the stone-throwing (Tajmir) ... Nor like the nights of Hajj that destroyed a lover'
'La yuba'u bihi dam': No retaliation is taken for him.
'Min ghaliqin rahnan': Accusative as Specification (Tamyiz). 'Ghaliq': Fixed pledge.
'Al-Bid' (White women): Raf' (Nominative). Some narrated Genitive (Badal for 'Shay'').
'Aqtalna': Destroyed (variant readings: 'Afltna' - saved).

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Are you sending Dinar for our need ... Or Abd Rabb, the brother of Awn bin Mikhraq?'
This verse: Unknown author. Dinar is a man's name. 'Aw Abd Rabb': Accusative by coordination with the place of 'Dinar' (which is genitive in form but accusative in meaning). Or accusative by hidden verb: 'Or send Abd Rabb'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Those striking Umayr away from their houses ... At the hill (At-Tall) on the day Umayr was an unjust aggressor'
This verse: By Al-Qatami. Praising Zufar bin al-Harith. Before it:
'I was informed that Qays is at Al-Hushshak, they descended ... Among us with a tribe gathering for guests'
Al-Hushshak: Water or land name. Or those who gather. 'Umayr': Umayr bin al-Hubab as-Sulami, whom Taghlib killed. 'At-Tall': A place of battle.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Those opening (Al-Fariju) the Prince's vague/locked door'
This Rajaz: By a man from Banu Dabbah. 'Al-Farijun': Opening. 'Al-Mubham': Locked. Two meanings: 1. They conquer kings and enter their fortified doors. 2. They are noble; kings do not bar them from entry. Opposite of Jarir's satire:
'A people, when their delegations attend the kings ... Their mustaches are plucked at the doors'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Those preserving the weakness (Awrah) of the tribe, so there does not ... Come to them from behind us any defect (Wakaf)'
This verse: By Qays bin al-Khatim al-Ansari. Al-Khatim: From 'Khatamtu al-ba'ir' (haltered the camel). Named so due to a scar on his nose. Before it:
'Convey to Banu Jahjabi and their people ... The nobles, that we are noses (leaders/proud) behind them'
'And that we suffice against what the enemies impose on them ... Of the injustice of a plan'
'Al-Awrah': Place feared for enemy entry. 'Al-Wakaf': Defect/Leak. Narrated: 'Nataf'. Meaning: We guard the tribe so no blame comes from our direction. 'Al-Hafizhu': We who preserve (pronoun output as third person).

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'O many an envier of us, if he sought you ... He would meet distance from you and deprivation'
This verse: By Jarir bin Atiyah bin Hudhayfa. Jarir: Transferred name (Camel rope). Named so because his mother dreamt she gave birth to a rope strangling people. Interpreter said: He will be a poet strangling poets. He defeated 80 poets except Al-Farazdaq. 'Ghabit': Envier who wishes for what you have without wishing you lose it. Meaning: Many envy our connection to you, but if they tried, they would fail.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Examples Acting like the Active Participle:
'Striking with the sword blade the shanks of their fat ones ... If they lacked provisions, for indeed you are a slaughterer'
This verse: By Abu Talib, uncle of the Prophet (PBUH), mourning Abu Umayya bin al-Mughira. He died at a place called Sur and Suhaym. Abu Talib said:
'Indeed the Provision of the Riders (Zad ar-Rakb), undefended ... At Sur and Suhaym, the graves hid him'
'They called out that the Master of the tribe is not among them ... And the two tribes Ka'b and Amir were bereaved'
'And he used to, when coming from Syria returning ... The glad tidings would run to us at his arrival'
'So the People of Allah (Quraysh) become white (joyful) ... As if Raydah and Ma'afir clothed them in silk'
'You see his house, never ceasing by it ... Felled huge camels and herds of cattle'
'Striking with the sword blade the shanks of their fat ones ... If they lacked provisions, for indeed you are a slaughterer'
'And if there is no fresh meat, then indeed ... The sacks are poured upon their mouths'
'O for you as a mourner, you greeted with a tool ... Pointed (Shura'iyyah), from which fingernails turn yellow'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Cautious of matters that do not harm, and safe ... From what will not save him from the decrees'
This verse: Fabricated, not Arabic. Attributed to Ibn al-Muqaffa. Created to trick Sibawayh regarding transitivity. However, a verse by Zayd al-Khayl at-Ta'i exists with no objection:
'Did I not inform you of news that came to me ... Abu al-Kusah, the threat was serious'
'It came to me that they are tearing my honor ... The donkeys of the two Karmals, having a noise'
Meaning: Describing a human's ignorance of consequences; fearing what is safe and feeling safe from what is dangerous.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Then they increased that they are in their people ... Forgiving (Ghufur), their sin is not boasting'
This verse: From famous poetry of Tarafa. Narrated 'Fujur' (Wicked/Lying). Story of Bedouin and Umar bin al-Khattab: 'O Allah forgive him if he lied (fajar).' Narrated 'Ghayru fakhur' (Not boasting).

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of the Adjective Resembling the Active Participle:
'Lank of belly (Lahiqu batnin), fat of the loin'
This verse: By Humayd al-Arqat. Humayd: Transferred name. Al-Arqat: Speckled. He describes a donkey, not a horse. Before it:
'Lean-waisted, overlooking the depressions ... White-flanked (Ahqab), braying, driver of herds'
'Mifa'': Overlooking. 'Ahqab': White on the croup. 'Lahiqu batnin': His belly is lean joined to his back. 'Shahhaj': Braying.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Wonder (Ta'ajjub):
'If men wintered and their eating intensified ... Then you are the whitest of them in a cook's shirt'
This verse: By Tarafa bin al-Abd, mocking Amr bin Hind. Recited:
'As for kings, you are today the meanest of them ... In meanness, and the whitest of them in a cook's shirt'
Also recited for Tarafa mocking Amr bin Hind:
'O father of Jaramiq, do you hope they submit to you ... O son of the crushed one, estates among rocks?'
'You are the son of Hind, so inform who is your father then ... The kingdom is not fit except for every proud one'
'If you say Nasr, then Nasr was the worst youth ... Of old, and the whitest of them in a cook's shirt'
'Al-Jaramiq': Nabataeans/Foreigners. 'Ash-Shadikh': Crushed head. 'Baddhakh': Very proud. Meaning of 'Whitest in a cook's shirt': He does not cook (stingy), so his shirt is clean of grease. Opposite of Miskin ad-Darimi's saying:
'As if the pots of my people every day ... Are Turkish domes covered with cloths'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'A girl in her flowing shift ... Whiter than the sister of Banu Ibad'
This poetry: Unknown author. Found in Ibn al-A'rabi's Nawadir. 'Sister of Banu Ibad': A Christian woman (whiteness metaphor). 'Fadfad': Long/Full. 'Qabba'': Lean-bellied. 'Radrad': Fleshy.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Habbadha:
'Oh, how lovely (Habbadha) is Mount Rayyan as a mountain ... And how lovely is the dweller of Rayyan, whoever it was'

This verse: By Jarir bin al-Khatafi. From a poem mocking Al-Akhtal. After it:
'And how lovely are breezes from a southern wind ... Coming to you from the direction of Rayyan sometimes'
'Ya Habbadha': 'Ya' is either a vocative (O people, lovely is...) or an opening particle. 'Min jabalin': Accusative as Specification (Tamyiz). 'Min kana': Who was (whoever it was).

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Subjects and Objects where each acts upon the other:
'But fairness (Nisfan) - if I insulted and they insulted me - ... Are the sons of Abd Shams from Manaf and Hashim'
This verse: By Al-Farazdaq. Mocking Jarir. Before it:
'And it is forbidden that I insult Muqa'is ... With my fathers, the high-nosed, the noble, the generous'
'Al-Khadarim': Generous ones (like oceans). 'Nisf': Fairness. Meaning: It is not fair to mock those below me; fairness is to mock equals (Banu Abd Shams). 'Hashim': Coordinated with Abd Shams. 'Abdu an': I disdain/hate.
Al-Farazdaq's stance on not mocking inferiors contradicts his practice of mocking everyone. Three schools of satire among Arabs: 1. Ignoring the lowly (Bashar bin Burd). 2. Mocking the noble tribe of the lowly insulter. 3. Mocking everyone (Al-Farazdaq).

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'And bays (Kumtan) bloodied, as if their saddle-cloths ... Flowed over them, and they were clad in a gilded color'
This verse: By Tufayl bin Awf al-Ghanawi (Abu Quran). Called 'Muhabbar' (Beautified) for his beautiful poetry describing horses. Tufayl: Diminutive of 'Tifl' (Soft/Tender) or 'Tif'l' (Child/Sun/Spark).
Colors of horses (Kumayt): Reddish-black. Divided into 8 types (Ahamma, Ashama, Mudamma, etc.).
'Kumtan': Accusative coordinated with previous verse 'Halabna...' (We milked/obtained... bays and blacks).

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'He returned to the heart a lovesick passion ... And he was asked (Su'ila) - if only he would clarify to us - a question (Su'alan)'
'And we might stay in it and see ages ... In which the shy, plump women lead us'
Abu al-Qasim attributed these to Umar bin Abi Rabi'ah. Mistake. They are by Al-Murrar al-Asadi (Al-Faq'asi). 'Al-Murrar': Transferred name. 'Al-Amid': Lovesick/Liver-sick.
'Su'ila': Passive voice. 'Su'alan': Accusative source. Or 'Su'ila [jawab] as-su'al'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Adding the Source to what follows it:
'Striking (Qar'u) the cups [against] the mouths of pitchers ... Exhausted my old wealth and what I gathered of property'
This verse: By Al-Uqayshir al-Asadi (Al-Mughira bin Abdullah). Al-Uqayshir: Diminutive of Aqshar (Red-faced/Peeling). He was an alcoholic. Poem:
'I say while the cup is in my hand turning it ... Addressing the nobles, sons of Amalek'
'Do not drink wine sipping ... Except with the white-faced, sons of Patricians'
'Striking the cups [against] the mouths of pitchers ... Exhausted my old wealth...'
'Al-Qawaqiz': Cups. 'Al-Gharaniq': Youths. 'Banat al-Ma'': Aquatic birds (pitchers likened to them). Meaning: Do not drink with stingy people (penny-pinchers/Danfaq), but with nobles.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'And they are standing (Wuquf) waiting for his decision ... In an exposed distinct land, his command, while he is silent'
This verse: By Ash-Shammakh (Ma'qil bin Dirar). Describes wild donkeys waiting for the male to move to water. 'Wuquf': Plural of Waquf/Waqif. 'Damiz': Silent.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'The horses (Al-Mughira) knew that I ... Caught up and did not recoil from striking a hearing (Masma'a)'
This verse: By Al-Murrar al-Asadi. 'Al-Mughira': The raiding horses. 'Ankul': Recoil/Coward. Witness for Source (Darb) working with Alif-Lam.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Defining the Number:
'And does greeting bring back, or blindness remove ... The three tripod-stones (Thalathu al-Athafi), and the desolate traces?'
This verse: By Dhu al-Rumma (Ghaylan bin Uqbah). Meaning of Dhu al-Rumma: Owner of the worn-out rope (story of Mayya/Kharqa). Meaning: Does greeting the empty ruins bring back the past? 'Al-Athafi': Stones for the pot. Singular: Uthfiyyah.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'He ceased not, since his hands tied his waist-wrapper ... He rose and attained five spans'
This verse: By Al-Farazdaq. Praising Yazid bin al-Muhallab. 'Sama': Rose/Grew. 'Five spans': Height of a newborn is 4 spans. Reaching 5 means growing up. Or refers to the baton of Caliphs.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Kam (How many):
'How many (Kam) a lowly one whom generosity attained heights ... And a noble one whom stinginess lowered!'
This verse: By Anas bin Zunaym. To Abdullah bin Ziyad. 'Muqrif': Lowly father. 'Wada'ahu': Lowered him.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'How many (Kam) an aunt of yours, O Jarir, and a maternal aunt ... Crooked-footed, who milked my pregnant camels'
This verse: By Al-Farazdaq mocking Jarir. 'Fad'a'': Crooked hand/foot (from milking). 'Kam': Exclamatory (Khabariyyah) or Interrogative. Case of 'Ammah' depends on interpretation.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Mudh and Mundhu:
'Whose are the dwellings at the peak of Al-Hijr ... They became desolate since (Min/Mudh) years and since an age'
This verse: Attributed to Zuhair bin Abi Sulma. 'Aqwayna': Became desolate. 'Mudh': Preposition here. Attribution of the opening verses of Zuhair's poem is disputed (Hammad ar-Rawiya confessed to fabricating them to Caliph Harun ar-Rashid).

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Section:
'You weep for Lubna while you left her ... And you were more capable regarding her at Al-Mala'
This verse: By Qays bin Dharih al-Kinani. Lubna: His beloved/wife forced to divorce. 'Al-Mala': A place. Meaning: You divorced her (under pressure) and now weep, though you had control then.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Vocative:
'O rider, if you pass by, then convey ... To my boon-companions from Najran that there is no meeting'
This verse: By Abd Yaghuth bin Waqqas al-Harithi. Captive destined for death. Lamenting himself.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Lo, O Palm tree from Dhat Irq ... Upon you and the mercy of Allah be peace'
This verse: Unknown (or Al-Ahwas). 'Palm tree': Metonymy for a woman (Umar banned mentioning women). Grammatical dispute on word order of 'Alayki wa rahmatullahi as-salamu'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Is it a dwelling at Hazwa that stirred a tear for the eye ... So the water of passion pours or trickles?'
This verse: By Dhu al-Rumma. 'Hazwa': Place. 'Ma' al-hawa': Tears.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Lo, O servants of Allah, my heart is enslaved ... By the best of those who prayed, and the ugliest of them as a husband (Ba'lan)'
This verse: Unknown. 'Ba'lan': Husband (implies ugly/inadequate husband of a beautiful woman). 'Tayyam': Enslaved by love.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Hurayra said when I came visiting her ... Woe upon you, and woe is me from you, O man!'
This verse: By Al-Asha. 'Wayli 'alayka': Fear for him (killing). 'Wayli minka': Fear from him (scandal).

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Azza greeted you after abandonment and turned away ... So greet, woe to you, he who greeted you, O camel!'
This verse: By Kuthayyir 'Azza. 'Ya Jamalu': O Camel (Vocative). She greeted the camel to greet him indirectly.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Lo, O Zayd and Ad-Dahhak, travel ... For you have passed the cover (Khamar) of the road'
This verse: Unknown. 'Khamar': Trees/Cover. Meaning: You passed the danger zone.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'So Ka'b bin Mama and Ibn Su'da are not ... More generous than you, O Umar the Generous'
This verse: By Jarir praising Umar bin Abd al-Aziz. Ka'b bin Mama: Pre-Islamic Arab famous for generosity (died of thirst giving his water to others).

'They throw down the person of intellect until there is no movement in him... And they are the weakest of God's creation in person'

'Al-Ghabit' (The Envier/Wisher): Is like the 'Hasid' (Envier), except that the 'Ghabit' is one who wishes to have the like of what another has, without wishing for the blessing to be removed from the envied person. The 'Hasid' (Malicious Envier) is one who wishes for the blessing to be removed from the envied person, even if he himself does not obtain it, like the action of Iblis - may Allah curse him - with Adam, peace be upon him. He says: Many a man thinks we obtain from you what we desire, and that you grant us from your connection what we hope for, so he envies ('Ghibta') us for that; yet if he sought your connection as we seek it, he would not obtain anything of what he desires!

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Examples Acting like the Active Participle:
'Striking (Darubun) with the sword blade the shanks of their fat ones... If they lacked provisions, for indeed you are a slaughterer'

This verse is by Abu Talib - the uncle of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace - from a poem mourning Abu Umayya bin al-Mughira bin Abdullah bin Umar bin Makhzum. He was his son-in-law. He went out as a merchant to the Levant (Sham) and died at a place called Sur and Suhaym. Abu Talib said mourning him:
'Is not the Provision of the Rider (Zad ar-Rakb) undefended... At Sur and Suhaym, the graves have hidden him?'
'At Sur and Suhaym is a familiar and accepted one... And a knight of raids, a speaker, and a gamesman (Yasir)'
'They called out that the Master of the Tribe is not among them... And the two tribes, Ka'b and Amir, were bereaved'
'And he used to, when coming from the Levant returning... The glad tidings would run to us at his arrival'
'So the People of Allah (Quraysh) become white (joyful) as if... Raydah and Ma'afir clothed them in silk (Hibir)'
'You see his house, never ceasing by it... Felled huge camels (Muja'ja'ah) and herds of cattle'
'If they are eaten one day, the next day brings the like of them... Fat ones (Zawahiq) or heavy pregnant camels (Bahazir)'
'Striking (Darub) with the sword blade the shanks of their fat ones... If they lacked provisions, for indeed you are a slaughterer'
'And if there is no fresh meat (Gharid), then indeed... The sacks are poured upon their mouths'
'O for you as a mourner, you greeted with a tool... Pointed (Shura'iyyah), from which fingernails turn yellow'

'Nasl as-Sayf': Its blade. Therefore, he added it to the sword. Sometimes the whole sword is called 'Nasl'. He praised him for hamstringing camels for guests when provisions were scarce. 'Sur wa Suhaym': Upper parts of it. 'Al-Yasir': One who plays *Maysir* (gambling for charity). 'Al-Qafil': The one returning from travel. 'Al-Basha'ir': Plural of 'Bishara' (Good news). He meant by 'Ahl Allah' (People of Allah): Quraysh; the Arabs used to call them the People of Allah because they were the caretakers of the religion. 'Al-Hibir': Soft garments made in Yemen. 'Raydah': A town mentioned by Tarafa in his saying: 'And at the foot of the mountain are signs as if their traces... Are Yemeni woven in Raydah and Sahul'. He meant the people of Raydah. 'Ma'afir': A tribe from Yemen. 'Al-Muja'ja'ah': Thrown down/Felled. 'Al-Kum': Camels with large humps. 'Al-Baqir': A name for a herd of cows. 'Az-Zawahiq': The fat ones. 'Az-Zuhm': Those with much fat, singular 'Zahim'. Zuhair said: 'Leading horses with injured hooves... Among them are the lean and the fat (Zahim)'. 'Al-Makhad': Pregnant camels, singular 'Khalifah' (from a different root). 'Al-Gharid': Fresh/Tender. Meaning of 'Takubbu': Pour. 'Al-Ghara'ir': Sacks, plural of 'Ghararah'. 'An-Na'i': The one who announces a person's death. 'Al-Alah': The tool/weapon. 'Ash-Shura'iyyah': That which is aimed for stabbing, i.e., directed.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Cautious (Hadhirun) of matters that do not harm, and safe... From what will not save him from the decrees'

This verse: Is fabricated, not Arabic. There is disagreement about its fabricator. Some claimed it is by Ibn al-Muqaffa. Al-Mazini recounted: 'Abu Yahya al-Lahiqi told me: Sibawayh asked me about a verb: Is it transitive? So I fabricated this verse for him.' Because of this, this verse was rejected against Sibawayh! We have found in the poetry of Zayd al-Khayl at-Ta'i another verse against which there is no objection, which is his saying:
'Did I not inform you of news that came to me... Abu al-Kusah, the threat was serious'
'It came to me that they are tearing my honor... The donkeys of the two Karmals, having a noise'

As for the meaning of the verse, it allows two interpretations: First: That he describes a human with ignorance and lack of knowledge, placing matters in wrong places, feeling safe from what should not be trusted, and fearing what should not be feared!...

The second interpretation - which is more likely to me -: Is that he meant that man is ignorant of the consequences of matters; he plans, but analogical reasoning and planning betray him. Thus it is like the Almighty's saying: 'But perhaps you hate a thing and Allah makes therein much good,' and 'But perhaps you love a thing and it is bad for you.' And like the saying of Abu al-Atahiya:
'And a person may perish from the direction of his safety... And be saved by Allah's permission from where he fears'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Then they increased [in praise] that they are in their people... Forgiving (Ghufurun), their sin is not boasting'

This verse is from the famous poetry of Tarafa. It is narrated: 'Fujurun' (Wicked/Lying) with Jim, which is the plural of 'Fujur', meaning one who is very immoral, or very lying, for it is said: 'Fajara ar-rajulu' if he lied. It is narrated that a Bedouin came to Umar bin al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, and said: 'My she-camel has sores and sores on its back, so give me a mount!' Umar said: 'By Allah, your she-camel has no sores or back sores!' The Bedouin said:
'Abu Hafs Umar swore by Allah... That she has no sores or back sores'
'Forgive him, O Allah, if he lied (Fajara)!'
Umar said: 'O Allah, forgive me!' Then he gave him a mount!!
It is narrated: 'Ghayru fakhur' with a dotted Kha (boasting). Its meaning: They do not boast of their honor, nor are they impressed with themselves, but they are humble to people, as the other said:
'Do you not see a people other than us, the best of their people... Boast less against their people than us?'
'And pride does not deter us against them... When they speak to us, from speaking to them gently'

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of the Adjective Resembling the Active Participle:
'Lank of belly (Lahiqu batnin), fat of the loin'

This verse is by Humayd al-Arqat. Humayd: Is a transferred name. It is possible it is a truncated diminutive of Ahmad, Hamid, Mahmud, Humayda', or Hamdan; for all these names, if diminutized and truncated, return to Humayd. Al-Arqat: Similar to Al-Abrash (speckled). He described a wild donkey. Some who discussed the verses of Al-Jumal claimed he described a horse, which is a mistake. The evidence that he described a wild donkey is his saying before it:
'Lean-waisted (Aqabba), overlooking the depressions... White-flanked (Ahqab), braying, driver of herds'
'Al-Aqabb': Lean at the waists. 'Al-Mifa'': Overlooking. The verb is 'Awfa'. The quadriliteral verb does not form 'Mif'al' (instrument/intensive noun); 'Mif'al' is only formed from the triliteral. However, it came by deleting the addition, just as they said 'Mahawin' (plural of Mihwan), meaning a very giving man, from 'Ahana' (to give/despise wealth). Al-Kumayt said:
'High-nosed, despisers (Mahawin) of the bodies of slaughter camels... Empty-bellied in the evenings, not weak nor stingy'
So 'Mahawin' is plural of 'Mihwan', which is from 'Ahana'. 'Ar-Ruzun': Low places where water gathers. 'Al-Ahqab': One with whiteness on his croup, the place of the saddlebag. Meaning of 'Lahiqu batnin': His belly is lean so it joined his back, as Imru' al-Qays said:
'The starving of the run folded him, so the belly is lean... Raised to the two loins, so it is empty'
'Ash-Shahhaj': The intensely braying (Shahij is the sound). 'Al-Mishall': One who drives away a lot; 'Ash-Shall' is driving away. 'Al-'Un': Groups of wild donkeys, singular 'Anah'. 'Al-Qara': The back.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Wonder (Ta'ajjub):
'If men wintered and their eating intensified... Then you are the whitest of them in a cook's shirt'

This verse is by Tarafa bin al-Abd, in a poem mocking Amr bin Hind. Al-Farra' recited it from Al-Kisa'i:
'As for kings, you are today the meanest of them... In meanness, and the whitest of them in a cook's shirt'
Abu Muhammad bin Rustam recited in Tarafa's poetry from Yaqub, mocking Amr bin Hind:
'O father of the Jaramiq, do you hope that... O son of the crushed one, estates among rocks will submit to you?'
'You are the son of Hind, so inform who is your father then... The kingdom is not fit except for every proud one'
'If you say Nasr, then Nasr was the worst youth... Of old, and the whitest of them in a cook's shirt'
'You have no shade or leaves in the heights... And in disgrace you have roots upon roots'
'If glory is divided, it stops short of your nobles... Or if meanness is divided, you are preferred with Sheikhs'
'Al-Jaramiq': The Nabataeans, a people of the non-Arabs. 'Ash-Shadikh': One whose head is crushed. 'Ad-Diba'': A type of predator, crooked in creation; he likened his clan to them in stupidity, for the hyena is described with stupidity. It is nominative by 'Tarju'. 'Al-Ajyakh': Rocks - according to At-Tusi. 'Al-Baddhakh': One who boasts much of his fathers and deeds.

'Al-Asnakh': Plural of 'Sinkh', which is the root of everything. Meaning of 'Akda': Fell short and decreased in this place, though in another place it means increased; it is of the auto-antonyms (Addad). 'Sarat al-Qawm': Their nobles. The meaning of 'whiteness of a cook's shirt': That he cooks little, so his shirt is clean with no blackness on it. It is the opposite of Miskin ad-Darimi's saying:
'As if the pots of my people every day... Are Turkish domes covered with cloths'
'As if those kindling fire for them are camels... Painted with tar, and the tar is coating'
'In their hands are ladles of iron... Resembling the bucket of the water-wheels'
'Al-Faqirah': The well into which water flows from another.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'A girl in her flowing (Fadfad) shift... Whiter than the sister of Banu Ibad'

This poetry: I do not know its author. I found Ibn al-A'rabi recited it in his Nawadir:
'Oh, would that I were like you in whiteness... Whiter than the sister of Banu Ibad'
'A girl in the past Ramadan... Cutting off the conversation with flashing (Iymad)'
He explained 'Cutting off the conversation with flashing' saying: If she flashed [a smile], they left their conversation and looked at her due to her beauty! His saying 'In the past Ramadan': The spring gathered them at that time. 'Al-Iymad': What appears of the whiteness of her teeth when laughing and smiling. It is likened to the flash of lightning. Dhu al-Rumma clarified this by saying:
'And she smiles the flash of lightning from a distinct mouth... Like the color of chamomile, watered by rain'
Another said:
'The flash of lightning was between me and her... When her smiling appeared from between the houses'
Others besides Ibn al-A'rabi added:
'Like the gazelle adorned with jewelry (Khadad)... Lean-bellied (Qabba'), having a fleshy (Radrad) rump'
'Dir' al-Mar'ah': Her shift. 'Al-Fadfad': The long, full one. 'Banu Ibad': A people (Christians of Al-Hira, known for fair skin). 'Al-Khadad': A small amount of jewelry, or a type of it. The poet said:
'And if she shone from the edge of the curtain without jewelry... You would say: A gazelle with no Khadad on it'
'Al-Qabba'': Lean-bellied. 'Ar-Radrad': Fleshy.

Abu al-Qasim - may Allah have mercy on him - recited in the Chapter of Habbadha:
'Oh, how lovely (Habbadha) is Mount Rayyan as a mountain... And how lovely is the dweller of Rayyan, whoever it was (Min kana)'

This verse is by Jarir bin al-Khatafi. We mentioned the derivation of his name previously in the book. It is from a poem mocking Al-Akhtal. After this verse:
'And how lovely are breezes from a southern wind... Coming to you from the direction of Rayyan sometimes'
'A south wind blew with my remembrance; I did not mention you... At the rock east of Hawran'
His saying 'Ya Habbadha': 'Ya' could be a vocative, and the addressed is deleted, as if he said: 'O people, lovely is Mount Rayyan'. It could be an opening particle of speech, which is Al-Asma'i's view. Similar to the Rajaz poet:
'O (Ya) curse of Allah upon the people of Ar-Raqam... People of the large herd, donkeys, and nose-rings'
His saying 'Min jabalin': In the place of accusative as Specification (Tamyiz). The operator in it is the preceding sentence, as the other said:
'O horseman, what a horseman you are... Trodding the sides, wide of arm span'
As if he said: It is beloved to me among mountains, or I single it out for my love among mountains. Al-Kisa'i and Al-Farra' said this. 'Nafahat': Plural of 'Nafhah', from saying: 'Nafahat ar-rih' if it blew. He means by 'Al-Yamaniyah': The South Wind; because it blows from the direction of Yemen. He clarified that saying: 'Habbat januban'. Sibawayh recited: 'Habbat januban fa-dhikra ma dhakartukum', meaning: I remembered you a remembrance??! 'Ma' is extra. 'Hawran': A mountain. 'Min' is in the place of accusative as the predicate of 'Kana', and its noun is hidden in it; as if he said: Whoever it was?

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Subjects and Objects where each acts upon the other:
'But fairness (Nisfan) - if I insulted and they insulted me - ... Are the sons of Abd Shams from Manaf and Hashim'

This verse is by Al-Farazdaq, from a poem mocking Jarir bin al-Khatafi. Before it:
'And it is forbidden that I insult Muqa'is... With my fathers, the high-nosed, the noble, the generous (Khadarim)'
'But fairness - if I insulted and they insulted me - ... Are the sons of Abd Shams from Manaf and Hashim'
'Those are my fathers, so bring me the like of them... And I disdain/hate ('Abdu) that Kulayb be mocked by Darim'

'Ash-Shumm': Plural of 'Ashamm', which is one having straightness and elevation in the nasal bone. This is praiseworthy. It is also used to mean might and pride. It is borrowed from the she-camel that sniffs the stuffed skin of her dead calf (baww) but does not accept it. This is used as a proverb. Abu Tammam at-Ta'i mentioned it saying:
'Of the Rudayni spears which, when they shake... Sniff the stuffed skin of the small-nosed one possessing pride (Shamam)'
'Al-Khadarim': The generous nobles, likened to oceans. It is said 'Bahr Khadram' if it has much water. 'An-Nisf': Fairness/Justice. He says: It is not fair that I exchange insults with one who is below me in lineage and majesty of position; fairness is only that I exchange insults with one who is my equal! Meaning of 'A'badu': I disdain and hate. It is said: 'Abidtu min ash-shay'i a'badu 'abadan' if I disdained it and got angry. From it is the Almighty's saying: 'Say, if the Most Merciful had a son, then I would be the first of worshippers (Abidin)' meaning: The disdainers.
His saying: 'Law sababtu wa sabbani': A sentence in the place of the predicate of 'Lakinna', carried on the meaning; as if he said: 'But fairness is that I insult Banu Abd Shams.' 'Hashim': Coordinated with 'Abd Shams', not 'Manaf', because Abd Shams and Hashim are brothers, their father is Abd Manaf. Al-Farazdaq clarified this in a poem praising Hisham bin Abd al-Malik:
'You inherited the clothes of glory, so they are your attire... From the two sons of Manaf: Abd Shams and Hashim'
He said in another poem:
'And if asked who is our equal, the sun would point... To the two sons of Manaf: Abd Shams and Hashim'

As for Al-Farazdaq's claim of refraining from mocking those below him; this is a path not agreed upon. The Arabs have three schools in this:
Some call him 'The Lowly' (Al-Khasis) and honor themselves from replying to him, as narrated about Bashar bin Burd. A rogue stood before him while Bashar was reciting and said: 'Cover your poetry as you cover your private parts!' Bashar clapped his hands, got angry, and said: 'Who are you, woe to you?!' He said: 'I am a man from Bahila; my maternal uncles are Salul, my in-laws are Ukl, my name is Kalb (Dog), my father's name is Qird (Monkey), my birthplace is Adah, and my home is Nahr Bilal!' Bashar laughed and said: 'Go, woe to you, for you are noble in your meanness. God knows you have screened yourself from me with fortresses of iron!' Similar to this is the other's saying:
'Your honor saved you, the safety of the fly... Its measures protected it from being reached'
Another said:
'The slave of Banu Misma' made me hear [insults]... So I protected my soul and honor from him'
'I did not answer him due to my contempt for him... And who bites the dog if it bites?!'

Some of them: If the lowly one mocked him, he mocked the best of his tribe, as the other said:
'Indeed, if the dog of the tribe barks at me, I say to it... Peace [goodbye], while your Lord is strangled by the rope'

Some of them: Mock everyone who mocks them, whether noble or lowly. Al-Farazdaq followed this path, contradicting what he said in this poem! Abu Tammam said:
'He hoped the lowness of his rank would save him... And he did not know that the lion preys on the dog'

Abu al-Qasim - may Allah have mercy on him - recited in this Chapter:
'And bays (Kumtan) bloodied, as if their saddle-cloths... Flowed over them, and they were clad in a gilded color'

This verse is by Tufayl bin Awf bin Dabis al-Ghanawi. Kunya: Abu Quran. He was called 'Muhabbar' (Beautified). There is disagreement on why he was named so. Abu Ubayd said: Named so for his beautiful description of horses. Ibn Qutayba said: Named so for the beauty of his poetry, and Abu Ubayd said the same. As-Suli said: Named so for his saying describing a garment:
'Its upper part is rags of a beautified (Muhabbar) garment... And its back is from a bound Athami fabric'
The most correct of these opinions: He was named so for the beauty of his poetry. It is narrated that Muawiyah said: 'Leave Tufayl for me, and the rest of the poets are for you!!'
Tufayl is of the transferred names. Possible to be diminutive of 'Tifl' - with open Ta - which is the soft and tender; it is said 'Baz Tifl'. Possible to be diminutive of 'Tif'l' - with kasra on Ta - which is a homonym with different meanings. 'At-Tif'l': The young of humans and others. People disagreed on Zuhair bin Abi Sulma's saying:
'I will travel in the dawn then journey continuously... Until night unless a Tif'l diverts me'
Some said: The foal of the she-camel, i.e., unless my camel gives birth, so I stop for her. It is said: He meant by Tif'l the spark that falls from the fire-stick when striking fire, i.e., unless I strike fire and stop. Dhu al-Rumma said describing a spark falling from the fire-stick:
'When it appeared, I shrouded it while it was a Tiflah (spark)... Small, not completing an arm nor a span'
It is narrated: 'While it was alive (Hayyah)'.

Some said: He meant by 'Tif'l': The yellowing of the sun and its inclination to set. The most famous pronunciation for this is 'Tafal' with fatha on Ta and Fa. Ibn Qutayba said: 'At-Tif'l' is a prayer they used to pray at sunset. Awf and Dabis: Transferred names. 'Al-Awf': A plant. An-Nabigha said:
'And it grew hawdhan and awf in bloom... I will gift him from the best of what a sayer said'
The locust is called 'Umm Awf'. The poet said:
'What is a yellow one nicknamed Umm Awf... As if her two legs are two sickles'
The male organ is called 'Awf', and the female organ 'Sharij'. It is said to the married one: 'Ni'ma awfuka!' (Excellent is your Awf!). The poet said:
'If Awf enters into Sharij... Openly, then the dowry becomes obligatory'
'Ad-Dabis' among men: The ill-natured.
Abu Ubayda Ma'mar bin al-Muthanna mentioned in the Book of Dibajah that 'Al-Kumayt' (Bay) among horses is between 'Al-Ahwa' (Black-brown) and 'Al-Asda'' (Rusty). It is closer to black than 'Ash-Shaqar' (Chestnut) and 'Al-Ward' (Dun), and more red than 'Ash-Shaqar al-Ward'. The female is also 'Kumayt'. He divided it into eight sections: Kumayt Ahamm, Kumayt Asham, Kumayt Mudamma, Kumayt Ahmar, Kumayt Mudhahhab, Kumayt Muhallif, Kumayt Aklaf, and Kumayt Asda'.
'Al-Kumayt al-Ahamm': Resembles 'Al-Ahwa'. 'Al-Ahwa' is less black than 'Al-Jawn'. 'Al-Kumayt al-Ahamm' is distinguished from 'Al-Kumayt al-Ahwa' by the redness of his flanks and elbows. 'Al-Kumayt al-Asham' has more visible redness in his back than 'Al-Ahamm', but his redness is not pure. 'Al-Kumayt al-Mudamma': Whose back hair is red, intensely red, and the lower the redness goes to his elbows, the more it increases. 'Al-Kumayt al-Ahmar': More intensely red than 'Al-Mudamma'. 'Al-Kumayt al-Mudhahhab': Whose redness is mixed with yellowness. 'Al-Kumayt al-Muhallif': That causes swearing (dispute); observers differ on it, some say Chestnut, some Dun, some Bay. He said: The sign of 'Al-Muhallif' is between 'Al-Ashab' and 'Al-Ahmar'. The poet said:
'A Kumayt not causing dispute, but... Like the color of pure red dye applied to leather'
'Al-Kumayt al-Aklaf': Whose redness is not pure, and blackness is seen at the tips of his hair. 'Al-Kumayt al-Asda'': Which has 'Sad'ah', i.e., turbidity, and it covers every color of horses except blackness (Duhma), and has a little yellowness. They likened it to the color of iron rust. Abu Ubayda said: If the yellowness is free of turbidity, and there is no redness of 'Kalf', it is 'Afrah'.
'Kumayt' is one of the diminutive names that have no non-diminutive form. It is a truncated diminutive of 'Akmat', like 'Humayd' from 'Ahmad', except that 'Akmat' was not used. Evidence is their pluralizing it as 'Kumt'. Sibawayh said: I asked Al-Khalil - may Allah have mercy on them - about 'Kumayt'? He said: It is like 'Jamil' and 'Humayr'. It is a redness mixed with blackness, not pure. They diminutized it because it is between black and red, not purely called black nor red, but close to them. It is like saying: It is a little below that.
'Al-Mutun': The backs. Meaning of 'Istash'arat': Wore it as a 'Shi'ar' (undergarment). 'Ash-Shi'ar': What touches the body. 'Ad-Dithar': What is over it. 'Kumtan' is accusative because it is coordinated with his saying before it:
'We milked from Al-A'raf, the manes of Bisha... And the manes of Lubna, the horses, oh how far the milking place!'
'Daughters of Al-Urrab, and Al-Wajih, and Lahiq... And A'waj Yataami resembling Al-Mutanassib'
'Bays and blacks (Wuwan), high represent their hip bones... Daughters of a stallion known as Majnab'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'He returned to the heart a lovesick (Amid) passion... And he was asked (Su'ila) - if only he would clarify to us - a question (Su'alan)'
'And we might stay in it and see ages... In which the shy, plump women lead us'

Abu al-Qasim mentioned these two verses for Umar bin Abi Rabi'ah, which is a mistake. They are for Al-Murrar al-Asadi, from Banu Faq'as, as in Sibawayh's book. I did not find them in his poetry collection. There are two Murrars: Asadi - Al-Murrar bin Sa'id, who used to exchange satire with Al-Musawir bin Hind. And Adawi - Al-Murrar bin Munqidh from Banu al-Adawiyah, who said:
'Not lovely are you, O Sana'a, as a land... Nor Shu'ub, neither as a love of mine nor as revenge'
Al-Murrar: Name transferred from adjectives. Likewise Sa'id and Munqidh. As for Faq'as: Improvised name, I know no derivation for it!
'Al-Hawa al-Amid': That corrupts the liver. 'Ar-Rajul al-Amid': Whose liver love has corrupted. It is said: 'Al-Amid' is the sick person who cannot sit unless supported from his sides. The first view is supported by the poet's saying:
'If they described me, then thin of body... Or if they searched me, then white of liver'
Another said:

'I wander in love for Da'd as long as I live, and if I die... Then oh my liver from what I met regarding Da'd!'
This is by An-Nimr bin Tawlab. His saying: 'Faradda 'ala al-fu'adi hawan 'amidan': He meant: He had forgotten, but when he looked at the dwelling of his beloved, his passion returned, as Bishr bin Abi Khazim said:
'O my two friends, indeed the house is a relapse (Ghafr) for the lover... Just as the insane or the wounded relapses'
'Al-Ghafr': Relapse of illness. Meaning of 'Naghna': We stay. 'Al-'Usur': Time/Ages. Meaning 'Yaqtadnana': Lead us as a beast is led. He used the verb form 'Ifta'ala' for exaggeration in leading; as said 'Kasaba' and 'Iktasaba'. 'Al-Khurud': Plural of 'Kharidah', the shy woman. It is said 'Takharadat al-mar'ah' if she became bashful. 'Al-Khidhal': Plural of 'Khadlah', one with fleshy calves. The verbs in the second verse: 'Nara' and 'Yaqtadnana'; he made the first operative ('Nara'), so he hid the pronoun in the second. If he had made the second operative, he would have deleted the pronoun and returned the verb to its origin, saying 'Yaqtaduna al-Khurudu al-Khidhalu'. The verse stands in meter with the operation of either verb. He connected it to the [previous] verse to show the rhymes are accusative and that he operated the first.
Ibn Durastawayh used to say: Whoever installs 'As-Su'ala' with 'Yubayyin' has erred, because the question is not clarified by the answerer, but by the questioner. He said: It is accusative by 'Su'ila' as its source, and the object of 'Yubayyin' is deleted, as if he said: 'And he was asked the question (Su'alan), if only he would clarify to us the answer!' It is narrated 'Su'alan' without Alif-Lam, which is closer to what Ibn Durastawayh said. Others said: It is not impossible to be accusative by 'Yubayyin' in two ways: First: Meaning 'Answer to the question', deleting the annexed noun. Second: Letting the question stand in place of what is asked about, as said: 'The Emir was beaten', and 'A garment woven in Yemen'. The verse of Ibn Abi Rabi'ah intended by Abu al-Qasim, which he mistook, is:
'If she does not use the Siwak of Arak wood... She selects and uses the Siwak of Ishil wood'

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of What is Allowed to Precede of Pronoun over Apparent Noun, and What is Not:
'May his Lord reward Adi bin Hatim for me... The reward of howling dogs, and He has done so'
This verse: I do not know its author. Abu al-Qasim cited it as evidence for preceding the pronoun over the apparent noun by necessity. Some interpreted it: That the pronoun in 'Rabbuhu' returns to the 'Jaza'' (Reward) indicated by 'Jaza' (verb); as said: 'Who lies, it is bad for him'. 'Jaza'a al-kilabi al-'awiyati': Accusative as Source. Their reward: To be beaten and humiliated! Parallel to 'Wa qad fa'ala' is Al-Mutanabbi's saying:
'And this is a prayer, if I were silent I would be sufficed... But I asked Allah regarding you, and He has done so'

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Adding the Source to What Follows It:
'Striking (Qar'u) the cups [against] the mouths of pitchers... Exhausted my old wealth and what I gathered of property (Nashab)'
This verse is by Al-Uqayshir al-Asadi. His name is: Al-Mughira bin Abdullah bin al-Aswad. Al-Mughira, Al-Aswad, and Al-Uqayshir are transferred descriptions/names. Al-Uqayshir used to get angry at this name. He passed by Banu Abs one day, and one said: 'O Uqayshir!' He looked at him angrily and said:
'Do you call me Al-Uqayshir, that is my name... And I call you Son of the Lamp-Extinguisher'
'She whispers to her lover at night secretly... And the Lord of mankind knows what she whispers!'
So he named that man: Son of the Lamp-Extinguisher, and that name remained in his descendants! He was famous for drinking and never sobering up. He said regarding that:
'I say while the cup is in my hand turning it... Addressing the nobles, sons of Amalek'
'Do not drink wine sipping... Except with the white-faced, sons of Patricians'
'Striking the cups [against] the mouths of pitchers... Exhausted my old wealth and what I gathered of property'
'As if they, while the hands of drinkers are working... When they shine in the hands of the youths (Gharaniq)'
'Daughters of water [birds], their chests are sunken... Red are their beaks, yellow are the eye-sockets'
'The hands of the cupbearers work them forever... As if their return is the return of handkerchiefs (Makhariq)'
'That is pleasure, as long as no obscenity comes... Or you shoot in it with an arrow of fallen notch'
'Stick to every youth, generous in his character... Pure of veins, noble, not mixed'
'And do not accompany a mean person in whom is shame... And do not visit the owners of Dawanig (pennies)'
'Ar-Rah': Wine, named so for the relief (Irtiyah) generated for its drinker. The poet said:
'And I met what Ma'add [Arabs] met all of them... And I lost wine (Rahan) in youth and pride (Khali)'
He meant by 'Rah': Joy, and 'Khal': Pride. 'Al-Ghurr': Plural of 'Agharr', the white, handsome one. 'Al-Agharr' also: The famous one, likened to the horse with a blaze. 'Al-Batariq': The great ones of the Romans, singular 'Bitriq'. 'At-Tilad': Old wealth. 'An-Nashab': Name for estates and fixed assets one cannot travel with. 'Al-Qawaqiz': Vessels to drink from, singular 'Qaquzah' and 'Qazuzah'. The analogy for 'Qazuzah' is plural 'Qawaziz'. It is narrated 'Qaqizzah'. An-Nabigha al-Ja'di recited:
'As if I drank with Kisra... He has a Qaquzzah and I have two'
'Al-Gharaniq': Young men, singular 'Ghurnuq', 'Ghurnuq', 'Ghurniq', 'Ghurniq', 'Gharanq', 'Ghurunq'. The aquatic plant 'Gharaniq' is likened to them, as Abu al-Hindi said:
'Pitchers will suffice Abu al-Hindi instead of the milk-skin of Salim... To which the grease of butter does not stick'
'Presented, bouncing (Qazzan), as if their necks... Are necks of aquatic birds terrified by thunder'
'Al-Fuwq' of the arrow: The place placed on the bowstring. If the notch falls, the arrow is ruined and useless; used as a proverb. 'Al-Maqrafah': Baseness of the father. 'Al-Qirfah': Suspicion. He meant by 'Ashab ad-Dawanig': The commoners. 'Ad-Dawanig': Plural of 'Dawnaq', a dialect of 'Daniq' (sixth of a dirham). He says: Do not drink with one whom a daniq pleases and its loss angers, but drink with the generous!
Similar to this is the other's saying:
'If the commoner gets angry... A grain satisfies him!'
'And taking a fals (penny) from his hand... Is like pulling a molar from his mouth'
'And whoever becomes a slave of the fals... Tell me: How can he give?!'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'And they are standing (Wuquf) waiting for his decision... In an exposed distinct land (Dahin 'Adhatin), his command, while he is silent (Damiz)'

This verse is by Ash-Shammakh. His name is Ma'qil bin Dirar. Kunya: Abu Sa'id. Abu Bakr bin Duraid mentioned this and said he is one of the five one-eyed poets of Qays. All these names are transferred, not improvised. Al-Ma'qil: Fortress, or place of detention. Ad-Dirar: Source of 'Dharra', harming each other. Or plural of 'Darir', the bank of a river/valley. Aws bin Hajar said:
'And no gulf from Al-Marut having branches... Throwing the bank (Darir) with wood of Talh and Dal'
As-Sa'id: Possessor of happiness. As-Sa'id: Small stream. Ash-Shammakh: One who holds his nose high (Yashmakhu) in pride. Ad-Dahi: Apparent/Exposed to sun. Al-'Adhah: Good land. Ad-Damiz: Silent closing his mouth. He described wild donkeys thirsty, needing water, waiting for their stallion to rise so they rise with him, while he is silent. Wild donkeys do not go to water by day fearing hunters; they wait for night. He said before this:
'As if my saddle is upon a thick wild ass (Ja'b), driven... Away from the herd, the milk-less jennies (Jidad) emaciated him'
'He folded their two thirsts in the heat of summer after... The stony lands flowed in the prime of the two Sirius stars'
'So she remained at A'raf, as if her eyes... Towards the sun [asking]: Do drying wells approach [sunset]?'
'Wuquf': Plural of 'Waqif', like 'Jalis/Julus'. It should have been 'Waqifat' if plural of 'Waqifah' (sound), or 'Awaqif' (broken). The origin is 'Wuwuqif', first Waw turned to Hamza to avoid two Waws, carrying broken plural on diminutive (diminutive of Waqifah is Uwayqifah). It seems Ash-Shammakh treated the singular as masculine on the dialect of those who carry adjectives of females on the meaning of lineage ('Imra'ah 'Ashiq', 'Naqah Damir'), so he pluralized as 'Wuquf'. Or carried masculinity on the meaning of 'Person' (Shakhs). Or because plural can be masculine/feminine.

And do not accompany a mean person in whom there is *Maqrafah* (ignobility) ... and do not visit the owners of *Dawaniq* (pennies/miserliness). *Al-Rah*: Wine. It was named *Rah* because of the *Irtiyah* (relief/joy) generated for its drinker. The poet said: 'And I encountered what all of Ma'add encountered ... and I lost *Rah* (joy) in youth and *Khal* (pride).' By *Rah*, he meant joy, and by *Khal*, pride. *Al-Ghurr*: Plural of *Agharr*, which is the beautiful white one. *Al-Agharr* is also the famous one among people, likened to the *Agharr* horse, which has a blaze (*Ghurrah*) on its forehead. *Al-Batariq*: The great ones of the Romans and their masters among them; the singular is *Bitriq* (Patrician). *Al-Tilad*: Old wealth/inheritance. *Al-Nashab*: A noun applied to estates and used items that a person cannot travel with. *Al-Qawaqiz*: Vessels to drink from; singular is *Qaquza* and *Qazuza*. By analogy, one who says *Qazuza* should say *Qawaziz* in the plural. *Qaqizah* is also narrated. He recited for Al-Nabigha al-Ja'di: 'As if I had caroused with Khosrow ... he had a *Qaquza* and I had two.' *Al-Gharaniq*: Young men; singular is *Ghurnuq*, *Ghurnuq*, *Ghurniq*, *Ghurniq*, *Gharaniq*, and *Ghurwaniq*. Water plants are *Gharaniq*, which resemble them (the young men), as Abu al-Hindi said: 'Pitchers to which the residue of butter did not cling ... will suffice Abu al-Hindi instead of the milk-skin of Salim. Covered with silk, as if their necks ... were the necks of water-daughters (*Banat al-Ma'* - aquatic birds/insects) frightened by thunder.' *Al-Fawq* - of the arrow: The place that sits on the bowstring. If the *Fawq* of the arrow breaks, it becomes ruined and useless; this is cited as a proverb. *Al-Maqrafah*: Baseness of the father. *Al-Qirfah*: Accusation and suspicion. By 'owners of *Dawaniq*', he meant the common rabble. *Dawaniq* is the plural of *Dawnaq*, which is a dialectal variant of *Daniq* - with opening or breaking of the Nun - which is one-sixth of a Dirham. He says: Do not carouse with one whom obtaining a Daniq pleases, and losing it angers, but carouse with the generous and noble! Similar to this is the saying of another: 'When the market-dweller gets angry ... a grain (small coin) pleases him! And stripping a fils (penny) from his hand ... is like stripping a molar from his mouth. And he who has become a slave to the fils ... tell me: how can he give?!' Abu al-Qasim recited in this chapter: 'And they are standing (*Wuquf*), waiting for his decree ... in a bright open land (*Dahin*), following his command, while he is silent (*Damiz*).' This verse: Belongs to Al-Shammakh. His name is Ma'qil bin Dirar, and his agnomen: Abu Sa'id. Abu Bakr bin Durayd narrated this and mentioned he is one of the five one-eyed poets from Qays. These names are all transferred, not improvised. As for *Al-Ma'qil*: It is the fortress, and it is also the place of detention. *Al-Dirar*: The verbal noun of 'Darra al-rajulu al-rajula' (The man harmed the man) if each harms the companion. It can also be the plural of *Darir*, which is the shore of the sea or the valley. Aws bin Hajar said: 'And no bay from the barren lands possessing branches ... throws the *Darir* (bank) with the wood of Talh and Dal trees.' *Al-Sa'id*: Possessor of happiness (*Sa'd*). *Al-Sa'id* (also): The small irrigation channel. *Al-Shammakh*: One who holds his nose high (*Yashmakhu*) above people, meaning he acts grandly over them and is arrogant. *Al-Dahi*: The exposed/apparent, and what protrudes from the earth to the sun. *Al-Adhah*: The noble/good earth. *Al-Damiz*: The silent one who has shut his mouth. He described wild donkeys (*Humur Wahsh*) that had become thirsty and needed to approach water, so they were waiting for their stallion to rise, so they would rise with his rising, while he was silent. Wild donkeys do not rise to approach water during the day for fear of the hunter; they wait for the approach of night. So he rises, and they rise with his rising. Likewise, he said before this verse: 'As if my saddle is upon a smooth-bodied wild donkey ... of the *Huqb* (white-bellied), whom the drying, scant-milking (years/conditions) have emaciated. He folded their two thirsts in the intense heat of summer after ... the rocky grounds flowed in the rein of the two Sirius stars. So they remained at high places (*A'raf*), as if their eyes ... were towards the sun (watching) whether receding water-wells would approach.' *Wuquf*: Plural of *Waqif* (standing), just as *Jalis* and *Julus* (sitting). It should have been said: 'And they are *Waqifat*' if the plural of *Waqifah* (standing female) were a sound plural, or: 'And they are *Awaqif*' if it were a broken plural. The original is *Wawaqif*, so the first Waw is changed to Hamza due to dislike of two Waws meeting, and to treat the broken plural like the diminutive. Do you not see that if you made the diminutive of *Waqifah*, you would have to say: *Uwayqifah*. It is as if Al-Shammakh mentioned the singular according to the dialect of those who carry feminine adjectives on the meaning of lineage/relation, saying 'Imra'ah Ashiq' (A lover woman) and 'Naqah Damir' (A lean she-camel). Therefore, he pluralized it as *Wuquf*, or he carried the masculine based on the meaning of the 'Person/Figure' (*Shakhs*). Or because the plural can be masculine or feminine.

Or it is possible he meant: 'And they are possessors of standing' (Dhawat wuquf), deleting the annexed noun, so 'Wuquf' is a source (Masdar) used in place of the active participle. This parallels their saying: 'Fulan 'Adl' (So-and-so is Justice). Or the estimation is: 'Dhu 'Adl', or 'Adl' meaning 'Adil'. Similar is Al-Khansa's saying:
'She grazes as long as she grazes, until if she remembers... Then she is only advancing (Iqbal) and retreating (Idbar)'
His saying: 'Yantazirna qada'ahu': A sentence in the place of Hal (State) from the pronoun in 'Wuquf' or in the place of an adjective for 'Wuquf'. His saying: 'Wa huwa damizu': A sentence in the place of Hal as well. The Ba in 'Bi-dahin' means 'Fi' (In). The estimation: 'And they are standing in an exposed distinct land'. This is the meaning, but you should not carry it grammatically on this; because you would separate the connection and the connected, for what follows 'Al-Qada'' is part of the connection of the source, so it must be an adverb for 'Al-Qada'', not for 'Al-Wuquf'.
'Al-Qatud': Wood of the saddle. 'Al-Ja'b': Thick donkey. 'Al-Mutarrad': Driven away by hunters from water. 'Lahathu': Changed him/Emaciated him. 'Al-Jidad': Jennies whose milk dried up, singular 'Jadud', likewise 'Al-Ghawariz'. 'Al-Huqb': Plural of 'Ahqab', having whiteness where the hind-girth goes. 'Az-Zhim'': Interval between drinks. 'Tawa Zhim'ayha': Made two drinking intervals into one; fear of going to water, intensifying thirst. 'Baydat al-Qayz': Height of summer heat. 'Ash-Shi'rayan': Two stars (Sirius and Procyon). 'Inanuhuma': Beginning of their heat. 'Al-Ama'iz': Stony places. 'A'raf': High place. 'Ar-Raki': Plural of 'Rakiyyah' (Well). 'An-Nawakiz': Whose water partly dried. He likened her eyes to them for their sunkenness from fatigue. 'Tadnu': Approaches setting. He says: She watches the sun setting to head towards water.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'The horses (Al-Mughira) knew that I... Caught up and did not recoil (Ankul) from striking a hearing (Masma'a)'

This verse is by Al-Murrar al-Asadi. 'Al-Mughira': The horses - said with kasra on Meem and damma. 'Ankul': Recoil and delay/be cowardly. Sibawayh recited this verse as evidence for the operation of the Source (Masdar) when it has Alif-Lam ('An ad-darbi masma'a'). Some grammarians do not allow the operation of the Source with Alif-Lam, and install 'Masma'an' by 'Lahiqtu', not by 'Ad-Darb'. Their argument is that Alif-Lam distances the Source from resembling the verb. Likewise, the active participle for them does not operate if it has Alif-Lam (in past meaning context usually, though general operator capability is debated), and they install what follows it by a hidden verb, or by resemblance to the object. It is narrated: 'Karartu fa-lam ankul', which is closer to being an argument for installing 'Masma'a' not by 'Ad-Darb', because if 'Karartu' (I returned/attacked) was transitive to it, he would have said: 'Ala masma'in'. It is permissible for one who denies this to argue that the poet deleted the preposition, as they said: 'Anba'tu Zaydan', meaning: 'An Zaydin', like the poet:
'Amartuka al-khayra fa-if'al ma umirta bihi... Fa-qad taraktuka dha malin wa dha nashabi'
Although Abu Ali al-Farisi reasoned this by saying: The preposition is not deleted if there is an alternative.
After this verse:
'And indeed I make the horses run, stumbling on spears... Protecting the solitary ally so he is defended'
'And we brought the horses from the market of Himyar... Until we trod the land of Khath'am as strangers'

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Defining the Number:
'And does greeting bring back, or blindness remove ... The three tripod-stones (Thalathu al-Athafi), and the desolate traces?'

This verse is by Dhu al-Rumma. His name is: Ghaylan bin Uqba bin Buhaysh. Kunya: Abu al-Harith. Ghaylan is an improvised name, derived from 'Ghaylah' (suckling while pregnant) or 'Ghilah' (deception). We mentioned Uqba previously. Buhaysh: Transferred; diminutive of 'Bahsh'. Al-Harith: Transferred from 'Haratha' (to earn/plough). Al-Harith also: The marrier/plougher of woman. Allah says: 'Your women are a tilth (Harth) for you'. The poet punned:
'If the locusts ate the tilths (crops) of a people... Then my tilth (wife) is concerned with eating locusts'
Regarding his nickname: Dhu al-Rumma, it is disputed. Some claimed: Nicknamed for his saying describing a tent peg:
'The eternity of time did not leave of it... Except three like blackened hearthstones'
'And other than a buried peg... Disheveled, remaining [with] a piece of worn rope (Rummah) of the garlanding'
Some claimed: Mayya nicknamed him that. He passed her tent before flirting with her, saw her and liked her. He wanted to talk to her, so he tore his bucket and approached her saying: 'O young lady, sew my bucket for me!' She said: 'I am Kharqa' (clumsy/unskilled)'. Ghaylan was embarrassed, put his bucket on his neck tied with a worn rope (Rummah), and turned back. She did what he wanted (to tease him), then Mayya said: 'O Dhu al-Rumma (Owner of the worn rope), turn back!' So he turned back. Then she said: 'If I am Kharqa, my maid is skilled (Sana'). Sit until she sews your bucket!' She called her maid: 'Sew the bucket.' Dhu al-Rumma used to call Mayya: Kharqa, because she said 'I am Kharqa', and 'Dhu al-Rumma' stuck to him due to her saying 'O Dhu al-Rumma'. This is Tha'lab's view. It is said: Kharqa is not Mayya, but a woman from Banu Amir; he saw her, asked for water, she was shy and refused. He told her mother: 'Tell her to give me drink!' Her mother said: 'Give him drink, O Kharqa!' Thus Dhu al-Rumma said:
'The perfection of Hajj is that the mounts stop... At Kharqa's, she of the veil'
Abu al-Abbas al-Ahwal said: Named Dhu al-Rumma because he feared the Evil Eye as a boy, so he was taken to a sheikh who made an amulet for him, tied to his upper arm (with a Rummah)! This is the least likely. The famous is the first (or second) view.
His saying: 'Wa hal yurji'u at-taslimu...': He described standing at Mayya's dwelling and greeting it, then denied his action saying: Does greeting or lifting the blindness of passion return to me a quarter empty of its people, containing only tripod stones and desolate traces?! Before it:
'O two dwellings of Mayya, peace be upon you... Do the times that passed return?'
You can raise 'Thalathu al-Athafi' with the first verb (Kufan choice) or the second (Basran choice). Originally 'Athafiyy' (shadda), but usage lightened is more common. Zuhair's verse is narrated with shadda and lightened:
'Athafiyya suf'an (Black tripods) in the place of a cooking pot... And a trench like the stump of the cistern not broken'
Singular of 'Athafi': 'Uthfiyyah' (damma on Hamza) and 'Ithfiyyah' (kasra). Grammarians differed on its weight. Some said: 'Uf'ulah', origin 'Uthfuwiyyah', Waw turned to Ya, assimilated, Fa broken for the Ya. They argued Hamza is extra by saying 'Thaffaytu al-qidra' (put pot on tripods), and 'Imra'ah Muthfah' (woman with three husbands), and Al-Kumayt's verse. Some said: Weight is 'Fa'liyyah', Hamza original. Argued with An-Nabigha's verse:
'Do not throw me into a corner with no equivalent... Even if enemies crowd around you (Ta'aththafaka) with support'
'Ta'aththafaka' is 'Tafa'alaka'. If from 'Thaffaytu', he would say 'Aththafaka'. Argued also: 'Athfa ar-rahla ithfa'an' (put the geometric pad). A complex Basran issue.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'He ceased not, since his hands tied his waist-wrapper... He rose (Sama) and attained five spans'

This verse is by Al-Farazdaq, praising Yazid bin al-Muhallab. Before it:
'And when men see Yazid, you see them... Submissive of necks, lowering the eyes'
'Sama': Rose. 'Adraka khamsata ashbar': Rose and exceeded the limit of walking; philosophers claimed: If a newborn is born full term without womb defects, he is eight spans of his own span. His navel is the center: 4 spans to top, 4 to bottom. 4 spans from navel to fingertips of both hands spread. If decreased/increased, it's a defect. So if a boy exceeds 4 spans, he begins ascending to full height! Some claimed: He meant the baton Caliphs held. Predicate of 'Ma zala' is in a later verse:
'He brings close battalions from battalions meeting... With stabbing on a day of fighting and stumbling'

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Kam (How many):
'How many (Kam) a lowly one whom generosity attained heights... And a noble one whom stinginess lowered!'

This verse is by Anas bin Zunaym, to Abdullah bin Ziyad. Before it:
'Ask my Emir what changed him... From my connection today until he left it'
'Do not insult me after you honored me... For severe is a habit stripped away'
'Let not your promise be a lightning without rain... For the best lightning is that with which is rain'
'How many a lowly one...'
Anas: Transferred name; 'Al-Anas': The people. Al-Khansa said:
'That tribe is the tribe of Banu Sulaym... With their travelers and the residing people (Al-Anas)'
Zunaym: Transferred; diminutive of 'Zanim' truncated. 'Zanim': The bastard/adopted.
'Al-Muqrif': Lowly father. If lowly mother: 'Hajin'. 'Wada'ahu': Lowered him. Used 'Wada'a' on the rejected original form (usually 'Yada'u'). Some read: 'Ma wada'aka rabbuka'. Poet said:
'So he strove his striving among his people... Then he did not attain, nor leave incapacity'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'How many (Kam) an aunt of yours, O Jarir, and a maternal aunt... Crooked-footed (Fad'a'), who milked my pregnant camels'

This verse is by Al-Farazdaq mocking Jarir. After it:
'Lifting her leg to urinate (Shaghghara), striking the colt with her leg... Milking with fingertips (Fattara) the front teats of first-borns'
'We used to beware that our milk-camels get lost... But to her [they come] when she hears the call of Yasar'
He tells Jarir: How can you compete with me when your aunts were shepherds for my camels? You should respect my right and acknowledge my precedence! 'Al-Fad'a'': One with 'Fada'' (crookedness) in legs from much walking behind camels. 'Fada'': Deviation between foot and leg, or hand and arm. 'Al-'Ishar': Camels in 10th month of pregnancy. 'Ash-Shaghghara': Who lifts leg like a dog urinating. 'Taqidu al-fasil': Hits the colt if it approaches during milking. 'Al-Fatr': Milking with fingertips. 'As-Saff': Milking with whole hand (for large udders). He described her skill in milking as she grew up with it!
Whoever lowers 'Ammah'/'Khalah' (Genitive) or installs them (Accusative): Makes them many aunts. Whoever raises (Nominative): Makes it one aunt, with abundance applying to the times/action ('How often an aunt...'). Installing/Lowering is more emphatic in satire. If raised/lowered, 'Kam' is News (Khabariyyah) without disagreement. If installed, there is disagreement: As-Sirafi said it is Interrogative (Abu al-Qasim's choice). Al-Farisi said: No meaning for interrogation, but News resembled Interrogative so it installed, just as Interrogative resembles News and lowers ('Ala kam jidh'in...'). Ar-Raba'i mediated: Face is Al-Farisi's, Sirafi's view valid as mocking interrogation!

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Mudh and Mundhu:
'Whose are the dwellings at the peak of Al-Hijr... They became desolate since (Min) years and since (Min) an age'

This verse is narrated for Zuhair bin Abi Sulma. Zuhair: Transferred name (diminutive of Zahr or Azhar/Zahir). Sulma: Improvised, damma Sin, shortened like 'Hubla'. Abu Sulma's name: Rabi'ah. 'Al-Qunnah' and 'Al-Qullah': Mountain top. 'Aqwayna': Became desolate. 'Al-Hijaj': Years. Meaning for Basrans: 'Min marri hijaj' (From the passing of years). Narrated: 'Mudh hijaj' and 'Mudh shahr'. This is on the dialect of those who make 'Mudh' genitive always. Abu al-Qasim said: 'It was of his dialect to make Mudh genitive always like Mundhu'. This apologizes for the narration to avoid the objection: How to make genitive with 'Mudh' what passed (past time)? Its rule is raising past and lowering present.
However, the first three verses of this poem are not authenticated as Zuhair's! It is narrated Harun al-Rashid asked Al-Mufaddal: How did Zuhair start with 'Leave this and count the saying on Harim...' without preceding context? Al-Mufaddal said: Poets usually start with nostalgia/travel description. Zuhair intended that, then said to himself: Leave what you intended and turn to praising Harim; he is more worthy! Harun liked this. Hammad ar-Rawiya was present and said: O Commander of the Faithful, this is not the start, before it is:
'Whose are the dwellings at the peak of Al-Hijr... They became desolate since years and since an age'
'Time played with them and changed them... After me, the blowers of dust and the rain'
'Desolate at the stream of An-Nuha'it from... The two banks of possessors of Dal and Sidr trees'
Harun turned to Al-Mufaddal: 'Did you not say "Da' dha" is the start?' He said: 'I never heard this addition until today; it is likely fabricated!' Harun asked Hammad: 'Tell me the truth!' He said: 'I added these verses!' Harun said: 'Whoever wants reliable narration, stick to Al-Mufaddal. Whoever wants abundance, stick to Hammad!'
Modern poets imitated Al-Mufaddal's logic. Ibn ar-Rumi:
'Pass from you the dwellings, the ruins and the lifeless, No!... Indeed in praising Abu as-Saqr is a distraction from them!'
Al-Mutanabbi:
'If it is praise, then the erotic prelude is presented... Is every eloquent poet a lover?'
'The love of Ibn Abdullah is worthier, for... With it the beautiful mention begins and ends'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Section:
'You weep for Lubna while you left her... And you were more capable regarding her at Al-Mala'

This verse is by Qays bin Dharih al-Kinani, one of the famous Arab lovers. His companion was Lubna. Qays, Dharih, Lubna: Transferred names. Qays: Preceded. Dharih: Hills, singular 'Dharihah'. 'Adh-Dharih' and 'Adh-Dharh': Food with saffron. Lubna: A type of perfume (Liquid Styrax). Imru' al-Qays mentioned it:
'And Ban and Alwiyy from India, fragrant... And Rand and Lubna, and the smoking incense'
'Al-Mala': Wide land. Or a specific place. Imru' al-Qays:
'Is it from the memory of a Nabhani woman whose family settled... At the dune of Al-Mala, your eyes tear?'
He said 'And you left her' because he had married her, then his father and mother forced him to divorce her. His father swore, placing himself in the sun...

A group claimed: Mayya nicknamed him that (Dhu al-Rumma - Possessor of the Frayed Rope). That was because he passed by her tent before he composed poetry about her. He saw her and she pleased him, so he loved to speak with her. He pierced his bucket, approached her, and said: 'O young woman; stitch my bucket for me!' She said: 'I am *Kharqa*' (clumsy/awkward). *Al-Kharqa* is she who does not do work well. Ghaylan (Dhu al-Rumma) was embarrassed, placed his bucket on his neck—it being tied with a worn-out rope (*Rumma*)—and turned back. She then did what he wanted (or realized his intent). Mayya said to him: 'O Dhu al-Rumma, turn back,' so he turned back! Then she said: 'If I am clumsy, my maidservant is skilled (*Sina'*), so sit until she stitches your bucket!' Then she called her maidservant and said: 'Stitch the bucket.' So Dhu al-Rumma used to call Mayya: *Kharqa*, because of her saying: 'I am Kharqa,' and the name Dhu al-Rumma prevailed over him because of her saying: 'O Dhu al-Rumma.' This is the opinion of Tha'lab. It has been said: *Kharqa* is someone other than Mayya, and that she was a woman from Banu Amir. He saw her, asked her for water, but she was shy and refused to give him water. He said to her mother: 'Tell her to give me water!' Her mother said to her: 'Give him water, O Kharqa!' For that reason, Dhu al-Rumma said: 'The completion of the Hajj is that the riding camels stop ... at Kharqa, who is wearing the veil.' Abu al-Abbas al-Ahwal said: He was named Dhu al-Rumma because the Evil Eye was feared for him while he was a boy, so he was brought to a Sheikh of the tribe to make an amulet for him, and it was tied to his upper arm! This is the furthest of opinions, and the famous one is the first opinion. His saying: 'And does the greeting return...' describes that he stood at Mayya's home and greeted it, then disapproved of his own action, saying: 'Does the greeting return (is it answered), or does it reveal what is in me of the distress of love, which carried me to visit the dwellings, or to greet it: a quarter empty of its people, containing nothing but the *Athafi*, which are the potstones, and the empty ruins (*Rusum Balaqi*)?!' Before it is: 'O two dwellings of Mayya, peace be upon you both ... Do the times that have passed return?' You may put the three *Athafi* in the nominative via the first verb, which is the choice of the Kufans, or via the second, which is the choice of the Basrans. The origin of *Athafi* is with a Shadda (doubled Y), but its usage as lightened (single Y) is more frequent on the tongues of the Arabs. Zuhayr's verse is narrated both with Shadda and lightened: '*Athafi* (Tripod stones) black/scorched in the place where a cooking pot was set ... and a trench like the stump of a tank not broken.' The singular of *Athafi* is called: *Uthfiyya* - with a Dhamma on the Hamza - and *Ithfiyya* - with a Kasra. Grammarians differed on its weight (morphological pattern). Some said: Its weight is *Uf'ulah*, its origin is *Uthfuwiyyah*, then the Waw was changed to Ya, and incorporated into the Ya, and the Fa was broken because of the Ya. They argued that the Hamza is extra based on the Arabs' saying: 'Thaffaytu al-qidra' (I put the pot on the Athafi), and their saying: 'Imra'ah Muthfah' (A woman made like an Athafi), which is one who has had three husbands, likening them to the Athafi. And by the saying of Al-Kumayt: 'And our neighbor's pot was not taken down among others ... nor was it placed on Athafi (*Thuffiyat*) except among us when it is set up.' Others said: Its weight is *Fa'aliyyah* and the Hamza is original (root letter). They argued for this with Al-Nabigha's saying: 'Do not cast at me a corner (support) that has no equal ... even if the enemies gather against you (*Ta'athafaka*) with support.' The weight of *Ta'athafaka* is *Tafa'alaka*. If it were from *Thaffaytu*, he would have said: *Athafaka*. Among their proofs is that it is said: '*Athaftu al-rahla athfan*' (I sought the saddle), regarding a camel. These are among the difficult issues of the Basrans and require more discussion than this, but this is not the place for it. Abu al-Qasim recited in this chapter: 'He did not cease, since his hands tied his lower garment ... then he rose and reached five spans.' This verse: Is by Al-Farazdaq, praising Yazid bin al-Muhallab. Before it is: 'And when the men saw Yazid, you saw them ... with humbled necks, lowering their gazes.' The meaning of *Sama*: He rose/grew tall. The meaning of 'reached five spans': He grew tall and exceeded the limit of walking; because the philosophers claimed: If a newborn is born completing the gestation period, and no affliction affects him in the womb, he will be the size of eight spans, of his own span. His navel will be like the center for him. From it to the end of his upper half is four spans of his own span, and from it to the end of his lower half is four spans. And from it to the tips of his fingers of both hands is four spans. So that if he were laid on his back, and his arms opened, and a compass placed on his navel and rotated, it would resemble a circle. They said: Whatever exceeds this or falls short is due to an affliction that happened to him in the womb. For you find one whose upper half is longer than the lower, and one whose lower half is longer than his upper half, and one whose hands are short, and one whose single hand is shorter than the other! So if the boy exceeds four spans, he has begun ascending to the limit of height! A group claimed: He meant the bamboo stick (*Khayzuranah*) that the Caliphs used to hold in their hands. The predicate of 'Ma Zala' (He did not cease) is in another verse after this one, which is:

...He draws battalions close to battalions meeting ... with stabbing on a day of desertion and stumbling. Abu al-Qasim recited in the chapter of *Kam* (How many/much): 'How much (*Kam*) by generosity has a low-born one (*Muqrif*) attained heights ... and a noble one, his miserliness has lowered him!' This verse: Is by Anas bin Zunaym, from poetry he spoke to Abdullah bin Ziyad. Before it is: 'Ask my emir what changed him ... from connecting with me today, until he abandoned it. Do not humiliate me after you honored me ... so strengthen a hand (favor) customarily snatched away. Let not your promise be a deceiving lightning ... for the best lightning is that which has rain with it. How much by generosity has a low-born one attained heights ... and a noble one, his miserliness has lowered him.' Anas: Is one of the transferred names; because *Al-Anas* means the people (*Al-Nas*). Al-Khansa said: 'So that tribe is the tribe of Banu Sulaym ... with their departing ones and the residing people (*Al-Anas*).' Zunaym: Also transferred; because it is the diminutive of *Zanim* (trimmed), which is the adopted one/bastard. *Al-Muqrif*: One of base father (if the mother is base, he is *Hajin*). He says: Generosity elevates the base one until his status rises! And miserliness lowers the status of the noble one until his matter becomes insignificant! He brought 'Wada'a' (he left/abandoned) based on the rejected original form (usually *Yada'u* is used). Some readers recited: 'Ma wadda'aka rabbuka' (Your Lord has not forsaken you - distinct from *Wada'a*). Similar is the saying of another: 'He strove his striving among his people ... then he did not reach, nor did he leave (*Wada'*) an inability.' Abu al-Qasim recited in this chapter: 'How many (*Kam*) an aunt of yours, O Jarir, and a maternal aunt ... *Fad'aa* (club-footed/distorted hand) has milked my *'Ishar* (pregnant camels)!' This verse is by Al-Farazdaq satirizing Jarir. After it is: '*Shaghara* (Leg-lifter) who strikes the young camel with her leg ... *Fattara* (finger-milker) of the front teats of the first-born camels. We used to beware that our milk-camels would be lost ... and she has, when she hears the call of Yasar.' He says to Jarir: How can you contend with me when your paternal and maternal aunts were herders for my camels? You ought to respect my right and acknowledge my precedence and priority! *Al-Fad'aa*: She who is afflicted with *Fada'* in her legs from excessive walking behind camels. *Al-Fada'*: A deviation and tilt in the foot between it and the leg, and in the palm: a deviation and tilt between it and the forearm. *Al-'Ishar*: She-camels that have entered the tenth month of their pregnancy; singular: *'Ushara'*. *Al-Shaghara*: She who lifts her leg as a dog lifts it when urinating. 'She strikes (*Taqiddu*) the young camel with her leg': Hits it if it approaches her during milking. *Al-Fatr*: Milking with the tips of the fingers.
