If it is with the whole hand, it is *Al-Saff*. *Al-Saff* is only for large she-camels. As for the small ones, they are milked with the fingertips due to the shortness of their udders. He described her skill and knowledge of milking because she grew up doing it! Whoever puts 'Aunt' (*'Ammah*) and 'Maternal Aunt' (*Khalah*) in the genitive or accusative: makes them many aunts. Whoever puts them in the nominative: makes them one aunt and one maternal aunt, making the abundance apply to the occurrences (of the act), as you say: 'How many (*Kam*) Zayd came to me,' meaning: 'Many times Zayd came to me.' Therefore, the accusative and genitive are more eloquent in satire! If the aunt and maternal aunt are nominative or genitive, then *Kam* is Predicative/Exclamatory (*Ikhbar*) without dispute. If he puts them in the accusative, there is a dispute: Al-Sirafi used to say: It is Interrogative (*Istifham*), and this is what Abu al-Qasim—may God have mercy on him—went with. Al-Farisi used to say: There is no meaning for interrogation here, but he likened the News/Predicative *Kam* to the Interrogative one, so he installed the accusative with it, just as he likened the Interrogative to the Predicative so he put the genitive with it, in your saying: 'Ala kam jidh'in baytuka mabni' (On how many trunks is your house built?). Abu al-Hasan al-Raba'i took a middle path between them, saying: The correct view is what Abu Ali said, but what Al-Sirafi said is permissible on the basis that he is questioning him mockingly! Abu al-Qasim recited in the chapter of *Mudh* and *Mundhu* (Since): 'To whom belong the dwellings at the peak of Al-Hijr ... they have become desolate since (*Min*) years (*Hujaj*) and since (*Min*) an era (*Dahr*)?' This verse: Is narrated for Zuhayr bin Abi Sulma. Zuhayr: One of the transferred names, as we mentioned previously. As for Sulma: It is one of the improvised names, with a Damma on the Seen, shortened (Maqsur) on the pattern of *Hubla*. The name of Abu Sulma was Rabi'ah. Rabi'ah: A name transferred from *Rabi'ah*, which is the helmet/egg of armor. *Al-Qunnah*: And *Al-Qullah* with Lam and Nun - The top of the mountain. *Aqwayna*: They became empty/desolate. *Al-Hujaj*: Years; singular is *Hijjah*. Its meaning according to the Basrans: Since years passed, and since an era passed, meaning: They became desolate because of the passing of years and eras and their succession upon them. It is narrated: '*Mudh* Hujajin' and '*Mudh* Dahrin' (Since years/Since an era). This is according to the dialect of those who use the genitive with *Mudh* in all cases. For this reason, Abu al-Qasim said: 'And it was of his dialect to use the genitive with *Mudh* in all cases and treat it like *Mundhu*,' meaning Zuhayr was from the people of this dialect.

This is an apology for this narration; lest it be said to one who narrates thus: 'How do you put the past in the genitive with *Mudh*, when its rule is to put the past in the nominative, and the present (what you are in) in the genitive?!' However, the three verses at the beginning of this poem have not been authenticated as belonging to Zuhayr! It has been narrated that Harun al-Rashid said to Al-Mufaddal bin Muhammad: 'How did Zuhayr begin his poem with his saying: 'Leave this, and count the speech regarding Harim ... the best of those present and the master of the settled-dwellers,' when nothing preceded it to refer back to?' Al-Mufaddal said: 'It was the custom of the poets to present before the praise a prelude (*Tashbib*), a description of camels, riding through deserts, and the like. It is as if Zuhayr intended that, then said to himself: Leave what you intended—of what is customary—and turn your speech to the praise of Harim; for he is the most worthy of one for whom speech is embellished and composed, and the most deserving of one with whose mention speech begins and ends!' Al-Rashid approved of his saying. Hammad al-Rawiya was present, so he said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, this is not the beginning of the poem, but before it is: 'To whom belong the dwellings at the peak of Al-Hijr ... they have become desolate since years and since an era. Time played with them and changed them ... after me, the scattering winds of dust and the rain. A wasteland at the outpouring of Al-Nahait from ... the two sides of the owners of Dal and Sidr trees.'' Al-Rashid turned to Al-Mufaddal and said: 'Did you not say that 'Leave this...' is the beginning of the poem?' He said: 'I have not heard of this addition until this day of mine, and it is likely to be a fabrication!' Al-Rashid said to Hammad: 'Tell me the truth!' He said: 'I added these verses to it!' Al-Rashid said: 'Whoever wants reliability and good, correct narration, let him stick to Al-Mufaddal; and whoever wants abundance and expansion, let him stick to Hammad!' Modern poets have followed this speech of Al-Mufaddal. Ibn al-Rumi said: 'Pass over the dwellings, the ruins, and the dead (memories), No??! Indeed, in the praise of Abu al-Saqr there is a distraction from them!' And Al-Mutanabbi said: 'If there is praise, the amatory prelude is put forward ... Is every eloquent one who recites poetry enslaved by love? The love of Ibn Abdullah is more worthy, for ... by him, beautiful mention is begun and ended.' Abu al-Qasim recited in this section: 'You weep for Lubna while you left her ... and you were, regarding her, by Him who holds the vacant lands (*Al-Mala*), more capable?!' This verse is by Qays bin Dharih al-Kinani. He is one of the famous lovers of the Arabs, and his companion for whom he was famous is Lubna. Qays, Al-Dharih, and Lubna are transferred names. As for Qays, it has been mentioned. As for *Al-Dharih*, it is the hills; singular *Dhariha*. *Al-Dharih* and *Al-Dharh*: Food in which saffron is put. As for *Al-Lubna*, it is a type of perfume/incense; it is said to be storax (*May'ah*). Imru' al-Qays mentioned this in his saying: 'And Ban (willow) and Aloe from India, fragrant ... and Rand (laurel) and Lubna, and the smoking incense.' *Al-Mala*: The wide expanse of earth. *Al-Mala* is also a specific place. Imru' al-Qays said: 'Is it from the memory of a Nabhani woman whose family settled ... at the sandy tract of *Al-Mala* that your eyes are rushing (with tears)?' He only said: 'And you left her,' because he had married her, then his father and mother tasked him with divorcing her. His father swore an oath, placed himself in the scorching heat, and said: 'By God, I will not leave this spot until I die or you divorce her'—while he refused to divorce her due to the intensity of his infatuation with her! His people made his action seem ugly to him and said: 'If your father dies in this state, it will be a shame upon you. Satisfy your father by divorcing her, then take her back after that!' So he divorced her. Then he wanted to take her back, but she refused then, and her father refused, and married her to another! For that reason, he said: 'The slanderers surrounded me and disturbed me ... So oh God, (judgment) for the obeyed slanderer.' And he said: 'If the world has changed regarding Lubna ... then Time and the World have bellies (interiors) and backs (exteriors). There was in her a place for trust ... and a pasture for the heart and a view for the eye.' The meaning of his saying: 'Then Time and the World have bellies and backs': He meant that the matters of the world include that in which the correct face is apparent to a human, and that which is hidden from him! Abu al-Qasim recited in the chapter of the Vocative (*Nida*): 'So O Rider, if you pass by, convey ... to my drinking companions from Najran that we shall not meet.' This verse is by Abd Yaghuth bin Waqqas al-Harithi. Yaghuth: Name of an idol to which he was attributed. Waqqas: Active participle from their saying:

And 'Qassat 'unuquhu' (his neck broke) if you broke it; it is a description transferred to naming. Abd Yaghuth was one of those captured on the Day of Al-Kulab. Taym ar-Rabab captured him, seeking vengeance for a man of theirs named An-Nu'man bin Jassas. He was certain he would be killed, so he said this poetry lamenting himself. It begins:
'Do not blame me, for blame is enough for what I am in... For there is no good in blame for you nor for me'
'Do you not know that blame, its benefit... Is little, and my blaming my brother is not of my nature (Shamali)?'
'So O rider, if you pass by (Aradta), then convey... To my boon-companions from Najran that there is no meeting'
'Abu Kurab and the two Ayhams, both... And Qays at the highest of Hadramout the Yemeni'
Meaning of 'Aradta': Presented yourself/Passed by. 'An' is lightened from the heavy version, its name is hidden. Estimation: 'Annahu la talaqiya lana' (That there is no meeting for us). The predicate of 'La' of negation is deleted. The sentence is in the place of the predicate of 'An'. He meant: 'Min ahli Najran' (From the people of Najran), deleting the annexed noun. Abu Kurab, The two Ayhams: Men of Yemen. Qays: Ibn Ma'adi Yakrub, Abu Qays bin al-Ash'ath al-Kindi. 'Ash-Shimal': Singular of 'Shama'il' (Nature/Character).

Abu al-Qasim - may Allah have mercy on him - recited in this Chapter:
'Lo, O Palm tree from Dhat Irq... Upon you and the mercy of Allah be peace'

This verse: I do not know who it belongs to. Some attribute it to Al-Ahwas. Dhat Irq: A place. 'Min Dhat Irq': In the place of an adjective for 'Nakhlah', as if saying: 'O Palm tree existing from Dhat Irq'. 'Min' is attached to a deleted element.
'Alayki wa rahmatullahi as-salamu': Abu al-Hasan al-Akhfash's view is he meant: 'Alayki as-salamu wa rahmatullahi', moving the coordinated element forward out of necessity. Parallel to Dhu al-Rumma:
'As if we are upon the children of a white-flanked [wild ass], [the heat] changed her... And the throwing of the dust her breaths, with arrows'
Estimation: 'Lahaha janubun wa ramyu as-safiy' (A south wind and the throwing of dust changed her). Al-Akhfash said this because 'As-Salam' to him is a subject raised by the 'Istiqrar' (Settling/Existence) hidden in 'Alayki'. This does not bind Sibawayh in his school, because 'As-Salam' to him is raised by Inchoation (Mubtada) and 'Alayki' is a preposed predicate. 'Rahmatullah' acts as coordinate to the raised pronoun in 'Alayki'. So 'Ala' has no place according to Al-Akhfash, but has a place according to Sibawayh.
'The Palm tree' in this place: Metonymy for a woman. Umar bin al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, had forbidden poets from mentioning women in their poetry due to the scandal. Poets used trees etc. as metonymy for women. Therefore Humayd bin Thawr al-Hilali said:
'And am I, if I distract myself with a Sarhah tree... Of the forest, is a path blocked against me?'
'Allah refused but that a Sarhah belonging to Malik... Over all the branches of the thorny trees, pleases/excels'
'It went in width (grew wide), and nothing tops its height... Among the forest except a sparse or tall one'
'So the shade of the cool forenoon, you cannot can utilize it... Nor do you taste the shade (Fay') of the cool evening'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Is it a dwelling at Hazwa that stirred a tear for the eye... So the water of passion pours or trickles?!'

This verse is by Dhu al-Rumma, and we mentioned his name previously. After it:
'Like my crying at the trace of a house, as if... In a soft sandy ground (Wa'sa') stripped by sand-hills, it is a parchment'
'We stopped and greeted, and almost - to an overlooking one... Recognizing my voice - the dung (remains) of the house spoke'
'The soul boils towards me in every stopping place... Of Mayya, and the yearning heart is terrified'
Hazwa: Place name. 'Hijta': Stirred/Excited. 'Al-Abrah': Tear. He named tears 'Water of Passion' because passion pours and makes them flow. 'Yarfaddu': Falls scattered. 'Yataraqraqu': Moves to and fro in the eye. His saying 'Ka-musta'biri': I cried for this house at Hazwa like my crying for that remote house. 'Musta'bir': Source with Meem attached, coming on the form of the passive participle (Maf'ul), as said: 'Iktasabtu iktisaban wa muktasaban'. It is regular for every verb exceeding three letters that its source comes on the form of its passive participle. 'Al-Wa'sa'': Soft smooth sand. 'Tansuha': Strips/Connects to it (from 'Nasawtu ar-rajula' - took by forelock). Narrated 'Tadnuha' (dotted Dad) - reveals/shows it. 'Al-Jamahir': Huge sands. 'Al-Mahraq': Parchment/Paper.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Lo, O servants of Allah, my heart is enslaved (Mutayyam)... By the best of those who prayed, and the ugliest of them as a husband (Ba'la)'

This verse: I do not know its author. In many copies it appeared as 'Fi'lan' (in deed), which is a mistake and corruption, even if it has a good meaning, because what follows this verse invalidates it, which is his saying:
'He crawls upon her intestines every night... The crawl of the horned beetle exploring a soft sandy hill'
The second verse indicates he is praising a woman and mocking her husband. He said: She is the most beautiful of people, and likened him when he mounts her for intercourse to a horned beetle crawling on a sandy hill, referring to her abundant flesh and large buttocks. In 'Tadubbu' is a pronoun returning to 'Ba'l' (husband). 'Al-Qurana': Type of beetle. 'An-Naqa': Long sand hill. 'Taqru': Travels/Explores. 'Ad-Dabib': Weak walking. 'Al-Mutayyam': Enslaved by love; from 'Tayyamahu al-hubb'. Hence 'Taym Allat' (Slave of Allat), Allat being an idol.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Hurayra said when I came visiting her... Woe upon you, and woe is me from you, O man!'

This verse is by Al-Asha of Bakr, name mentioned previously. Narrated: 'Waylan 'alayka', 'Wayla' (kasra/fatha). 'Za'iraha': Accusative as Hal. Meaning: Woe upon you because you might be killed because of me, and woe is me from you because you will expose me! After it:
'O who has seen a rain cloud I spent the night watching... As if lightning in its edges are torches'
'It has a rear rider and a middle, filled, active... Girded with water buckets, connected'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Azza greeted you after abandonment and turned away... So greet, woe to you, he who greeted you, O camel!'
'Would that the greeting was for me so I could thank her... Instead of: O Camel: You have been greeted, O man!'

This poetry is by Kuthayyir Azza, mentioned previously. Azza had abandoned him and sworn not to speak to him. Then she met him in Mecca and struck his camel with her hand saying: 'May Allah greet you, O camel!' His saying 'Ya Jamalan': The norm was to raise 'Jamal' (nominative), leaving nunation, building it on damma, because of her addressing it with vocative, just as 'Rajul' is raised by address. But he was forced [by meter], so he nunated it and returned it to its origin (accusative indefinite). This is Abu Amr bin al-Ala's choice. It is narrated: 'Ya Jamalu huyyita' - with Raf' - and its nunation is for necessity. Leaving it on its Raf' is the choice of Al-Khalil and Sibawayh, may Allah have mercy on them. After this poetry:
'If you had greeted her, you would have remained loved... By me, and night travel and work would not have touched you'
'So he fell from a trunk when I said that to him... And he desired to speak to her, if only camels spoke!'
Narrated: 'Fa-aqbalaha'. Narrated: 'Yawm an-nafr' (Day of Departure - Hajj).

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Lo, O Zayd and Ad-Dahhak, travel... For you have passed the cover (Khamar) of the road'

This verse: I do not know its author. 'Al-Khamar': Everything that covers a person etc., like trees. 'As-Sura': Travel specifically at the end of the night (Sahar). He says to his two companions: You have passed the place where the road is cut off (unsafe), so travel safely and leave what you are doing (fear/hiding).

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'So Ka'b bin Mama and Ibn Su'da are not... More generous than you, O Umar the Generous'

This verse is by Jarir bin al-Khatafi, in a poem praising Umar bin Abd al-Aziz. After it are verses:
'Forbearance returns from you upon Quraysh... And you relieve the severe distresses from them'
'And you have secured their wildness with gentleness... And your wildness tires the people to be hunted!'
'And you call upon Allah striving to be pleased... And you mention the Hereafter among your subjects'
He meant by 'Ibn Su'da': Aws bin Haritha bin La'm at-Ta'i. Su'da: His mother. Bishr bin Khazim mentioned him:
'To Aws bin Haritha bin Su'da... To fulfill my need regarding one who decreed it'
'And none has trodden the earth like Ibn Su'da... Nor worn sandals when he put them on'
Ka'b: Ka'b bin Mama al-Iyadi. He is the one who preferred others over himself with water until he died of thirst!

'Alert, O servants of God, my heart is enslaved (*Mutayyam*) ... by the best of those who pray, and the ugliest of them as a husband (*Ba'la*)!' This verse: I do not know its speaker. In many copies, it appears as 'Fi'la' (in action), which is an error and misinterpretation, even if it has a good meaning, because what follows this verse invalidates it, which is his saying: 'He crawls upon her intestines every night ... the crawl of the *Qarani* (beetle) climbing a soft sand dune.' The second verse indicates that he is praising a woman and satirizing her husband. He said: She is the most beautiful of people, and he likened him, when he mounts her for intercourse, to a *Qarani* crawling over a sand dune (*Naqa*), pointing to the abundance of her flesh and the size of her buttocks. In 'Tadibbu' (crawls), there is a pronoun referring to the husband. *Al-Qarani*: A type of beetle. *Al-Naqa*: The elongated sand dune. *Taqru*: Moves from place to place. *Al-Dabib*: Weak walking. *Al-Mutayyam*: One whom love has enslaved; from it is said: Taym Allat, and Al-Lat is an idol. Abu al-Qasim recited in this chapter: 'Hurayrah said when I came visiting her ... 'Woe upon you, and woe to me from you, O man!'' This verse is by Al-A'sha of Bakr, and we have mentioned his name previously. It is narrated: 'Waylun' (woe) upon you, and 'Waylan'. It is narrated with Kasra on the Lam and Fatha. 'Zairaha' (visiting her): Accusative as a circumstantial state (*Hal*). Its meaning: Woe upon you, because you will be killed on my account; and woe to me from you, because you will expose me! After it is: 'O you who saw a rain cloud that I spent the night watching ... as if the lightning in its edges were torches. It has a rear (clouds) and a filled center, active ... girded with buckets of water, continuous.' Abu al-Qasim recited in this chapter: 'Azza greeted you after the abandonment and turned away ... So greet, woe to you, the one who greeted you, O Camel (*Ya Jumalu*)! Would that the greeting were for me so I could thank her ... in place of 'O Camel'; may you be greeted, O man!' This poetry is by Kuthayyir Azza, and we have mentioned him in the past. Azza had abandoned him and sworn not to speak to him. Then she met him in Mecca, tapped his camel with her hand, and said: 'May God greet you, O camel!' His saying: 'Ya Jumalan' (O Camel - accusative): The norm was the nominative for 'Jumal' (O Jumalu), omitting the Tanwin (nunation) and building it on the Damma, because of her turning to it with the call (*Nida*), just as 'Al-Rajul' (The Man) takes the nominative when turned to. But he was compelled (by meter), so he added the Tanwin and returned it to its original form (accusative/indefinite). This is the choice of Abu Amr ibn al-Ala. It has been narrated: 'Ya Jumalu Huyyita...' - in the nominative - and adding Tanwin to it for necessity, while leaving it in its nominative state is the choice of Al-Khalil and Sibawayh, may God Almighty have mercy on them. After this poetry: 'If you had greeted her, you would have remained possessing love ... with me, and the night journey and work would not have touched you. So he (the camel) fell from fright when I said that to him ... and desired to speak to her, if only camels spoke!' It is narrated: 'Fa-aqbalaha' (so he approached her). And it is narrated: 'Day of the Nafr', which is the day of concluding the Hajj. Abu al-Qasim recited in this chapter: 'Ho, O Zayd and Al-Dahhak, travel ... for you have passed the cover (*Khamar*) of the road.' This verse: I do not know its speaker. *Al-Khamar*: Everything that conceals a person or other things, like trees etc. *Al-Sura*: Traveling specifically at the time of magic (pre-dawn). He says to his two companions: You have passed the place where the path is cut off, so travel safely, and leave what you are doing. Abu al-Qasim recited in this chapter: 'Ka'b bin Mamah and Ibn Su'da are not ... more generous than you, O Umar the Generous (*Ya Umar-al-Jawada*).' This verse is by Jarir bin al-Khatafi, in a poem praising Umar bin Abd al-Aziz. After it are verses: 'Forbearance returns from you upon Quraysh ... and you relieve them of severe distresses. You have secured their fear with gentleness ... while your wildness (aloofness) tires the people to be hunted! You call upon God, striving, so He may be pleased ... and you remind your subjects of the Return (Afterlife).' By 'Ibn Su'da', he meant: Aws bin Haritha bin La'm al-Ta'i. Su'da: His mother. Bishr bin Khazim mentioned him in his saying: 'To Aws bin Haritha bin Su'da ... to fulfill my need among those whose needs he fulfilled. No one like Ibn Su'da has trodden the earth ... nor worn sandals when he put them on.' Ka'b: He is Ka'b bin Mamah al-Iyadi, the one who prioritized another over himself regarding water, until he died of thirst!

The story of that was: He was in a caravan, and with him was a man from An-Namir bin Qasit named Ya'fur bin Qasit. Water became scarce for them. They gave what water they had to a man to divide equally. He would put a round smooth stone in a vessel, then pour water over it until it was covered, and give each man his share. That stone is called 'Al-Muqlah'. This was called 'Tasafin'. When the cupbearer wanted to give Ka'b his share, the Namiri man would look at Ka'b with a gaze of desire and pleading! So Ka'b would say: 'Give drink to your brother the Namiri!' He kept doing this until Ka'b became exhausted and weak. They had camped near the water source. Ka'b was given glad tidings and told: 'Go down [to water], you have reached the water!' But he had no strength to rise, and fell dead! His father said mourning him and mentioning him:
'Ka'b overlooked the water, then it was said to him: Go down... Ka'b, you are a comer to water (Warrad). But he did not go down (Warada)'
Al-Farazdaq mentioned this. He was traveling in a caravan, water became scarce, they rationed it (Tasafanu). A man from Banu al-Anbar bin Amr bin Ghanam asked him to prefer him with his share. Al-Farazdaq did so! Then he asked him to prefer him a second time, but he refused, and said regarding that:
'When we rationed the waterskin, the creases of... The big-bellied Anbari man wept to me'
'He brought a rock like his head... For the water to be poured over it among the determined men'
'So I preferred him when I saw what was with him... In a state where I fear the pursuing blames'
'In a state where if Hatim were among the people... Hatim would not have been generous with water despite his generosity!'
'And we were like the companions of Ibn Mama when he gave drink... To the thirsty brother of Namir on the Day of Daja'im'
'When Ka'b said: Have you quenched Ibn Qasit?... He says to him: Increase me, [for it is] the wetting of throats!'
'So I was like Ka'b except that my death... Its stripping by the prominent places was delayed from me!'
'And I was hoping for thanks from him when he came to... The people of Syria from the people of Al-Hufayr and Jasim'
'The Anbari wished to mock me, and I thought myself... Strong of bridle (dignity), a target for stone-throwers'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Peace of Allah, O Matar, upon her... And not upon you, O Matar, is the peace'

This verse is by Al-Ahwas. His name is Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Asim al-Ansari. 'Al-Ahwas': One with narrow eyes. 'Al-Muhammad': Who is praised much, attributed to Hamd (Praise). Zuhair said:
'Is he not overflowing [generosity], his hands are a cloud... Support for orphans in the years [of drought], Muhammad?'
'Asim': Active participle of 'Ismah'. The Nun in 'Matar' is for necessity (Nunation kept in vocative). After it:
'If marriage is the most lawful thing... Then the marriage of her to Matar is Haram (forbidden)'
'So divorce her, for you are not her equal... Otherwise the sword will rise over your parting'
'So may God not forgive those who married her [to you]... Their sins, even if they prayed and fasted'
Matar was ugly, and Hind (the wife) was of noble lineage. He was the ugliest of people, and his wife the most beautiful! He meant: 'If you do not divorce her, the sword will rise over your head', deleting the condition due to the indication of what preceded it. As Zuhair said:
'Otherwise (if you don't desist), then we are at Ash-Sharbah and Al-Liwa... Hamstringing the mothers of the young camels and the old ones'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'She struck her chest towards me and said... O Adiyya, the protectors have protected you'

This verse is by Muhalhil bin Rabi'ah at-Taghlibi. His name is Adi. Ibn al-Kalbi claimed his name is Imru' al-Qays. Named 'Muhalhil' because he was the first to thin (Halahala - refine/weave thinly) poetry. Ibn al-Kalbi claimed he was named Muhalhil for his saying in a poem:
'When their noisy crowd became rugged in the dust... I thinned (Halhaltu) to avenge Jabir or Sinbil'
Ibn al-Kalbi mentioned that 'Darabat sadraha ilayya' is not by Muhalhil, but by his brother Adi [meaning Udayy/Adi, likely confusion in names or narration]. Others recited:
'A tender one (Taflah), the daughter of Al-Muhallal is not... High-nosed (Shamma'), playful, delicious in embrace'
'A doe from the does of Wajrah, reaching up... And her hands are among green leaves'
'She struck her chest towards me and said... O Adiyya, the protectors have protected you'
'Depart, what is towards you is not far... One in bonds does not suit embracing'
'I do not hope for life after my boon-companions... I see them given to drink from the cup of death (Halaq)'
'After Amr and Amir and Hayy... And Rabi' as-Saduf and the two sons of Unaq'
'And Kulayb, the poison of horsemen when... The shooters of the brave protectors aimed [at him]'
'Indeed under the stones are firmness and generosity... And a quarrelsome opponent, fierce, possessor of a hook (Mi'laq)'
'A snake in the den (Wujar), dusky-colored... The bitten one does not benefit from the blowing of a charmer'
'Taflah' (fatha): Soft-bodied. 'Tiflah' (kasra): Small girl. 'Shamma'': High-nosed. 'Waqatka': Protected you. 'Al-Awaqi': Plural of 'Waqiyah' (Protector/Protection), referring to God's protection and decrees.

It means: Allah protected you from great matters where you were on the verge of destruction. He disliked the combination of two Waws (Wawaqi), so he changed the first Waw to Hamza, carrying the broken plural on the diminutive if you said 'Uwayqiyah'. 'Halaq': Name for death, built on kasra like 'Hizam' and 'Qatam'. 'Al-Kumah': The brave ones, singular 'Kamin' like 'Qadin' (judge) and 'Da'in' (caller), plurals 'Qudah' and 'Du'ah'. 'Al-Ifaq': Placing the arrow on the string to shoot. 'Al-Aladd': Fierce in dispute. 'Al-Mighlaq' (dotted Ghayn): What locks a door. Narrated 'Mi'laq' (undotted Ayn): Like a hook that catches things; meaning if he catches his opponent, he doesn't escape. Al-Ba'ith said:
'Fierce, if I meet a people in a plan... A wounding saddle-sore persists on their shoulders'
'Al-Wujar' (fatha/kasra): Hyena's den, used for others. 'Al-Arbad': Inclining to blackness. This poem indicates it is by Muhalhil, contrary to Ibn al-Kalbi.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Did you not hear: O Abda, in the brightness of the forenoon... The crying of doves that have a cooing?'

This verse: I do not know its author. Some claim it is Kuthayyir. 'Ay Abda': Meant 'Ya Abdah' (O Abdah - truncated). 'Rawnaq ad-Duha': Its brightness and light. 'Al-Hadir' and 'Al-Hadil': Sound of the pigeon/dove. 'Hadara yahdiru' and 'Hadala yahdilu'. 'Li-hunna hadirun': Sentence in the place of an adjective for 'Hamamat'. After it:
'They cried and stirred my longing and passion... And eras have passed since the time of meeting'
Arabs differ regarding the pigeon's sound; some consider it crying, claiming it cries for a chick that died in the time of Noah, peace be upon him, calling it 'Hadil'. Al-Kumayt said:
'And there is none whom you call for victory... Closer in answer to you than a Hadil (pigeon)'
Some consider it singing, as the other said:
'Lo, may Allah fight the pigeons of the morning... On a branch, they stirred us when they sang'
Abu al-Ala expressed doubt in that saying:
'Did that pigeon cry or did she sing... On the branch of her swaying bough?!'
'Neither has come to us, everything passes... But we are in a world that does not know!'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Is it a slave who settled in Shu'abay, a stranger... Is it meanness, may you have no father, and alienation?!'

This verse is by Jarir bin al-Khatafi. We mentioned his name and lineage previously. The reason for saying this poem: He mocked Ar-Ra'i an-Numayri saying in his satire:
'If Banu Tamim are angry with you... You reckon all the people are angry'
Al-Abbas or Khalid bin Yazid al-Kindi, who was residing at Shu'abay, opposed him saying in reply:
'Lo, may the noses of Banu Tamim be rubbed in dust... The farters of dates, if they are angry'
'Banu Tamim were angry with me... So they did not harm a fly with their anger'
'If the crow looked upon Tamim... And what shameful things are in it, it would turn gray'
Jarir mocked him saying:
'If the wretched one is ignorant and did not estimate... Some of the matter, he is about to be struck'
'Rhymes will rise from the peaks of Shu'abay... Upon the Kindi, flaming intensely'
'Is it a slave who settled in Shu'abay, a stranger... Is it meanness, may you have no father, and alienation?!'
'Hudaybah is not hidden when she spends the evening... Nor her feeding the dogs with her lamb'
'She pierces her two milking vessels with arrowheads... And her placenta has wetted the dust'
Sibawayh allowed in 'A-'abdan' to be a vocative (O slave!), or accusative as Hal (State), as if saying: 'Do you boast while being a slave?', i.e., in the state of slavery, for boasting does not befit a slave! 'Shu'abay': A place. 'Ghariban': Accusative as adjective for 'Abdan', or Hal from pronoun in 'Halla'.
His saying: 'A-lu'man la abalaka wa ightiraban': They are accusative in two ways: First: Estimation 'A-tal'amu lu'man wa taghtaribu ightiraban' (Do you be mean... and be alienated...), so they are sources (Masadir) installed by hidden verbs. Second: Estimation 'A-tajma'u lu'man wa ightiraban' (Do you combine meanness and alienation?), hiding one verb acting on both. This way is better to me. The Alif in 'A-lu'ma' is Alif of rebuke and denial, like in Al-Ajjaj's saying:
'Is it playfulness (A-taraban) while you are old (Qinnasriyyu)?!... While only the boy engages in play (Siba)'

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Two Nouns with One Wording, the Second Added:
'O Taym, Taym of Adi, may you have no father... Let not Umar find you in a disgraceful situation!'

This verse is by Jarir, saying it to Umar bin Laja. The reason: Jarir passed by Umar bin Laja while he was reciting a Rajaz poem of his, and people were listening. He stopped to listen. When he reached:
'She came to the water before the time of her forenoon... Preying on snakes in her skin'
'Dragging with ease whoever doubted her... Like the dragging of the old woman the sides of her tent'
Jarir said to him: 'You did badly and failed in what you said!' Umar said: 'How should I say?' He said: 'Say: Like the dragging of the bride the train of her sleeves.' Umar was embarrassed and said: 'You are in a worse state than me where you say:
My people are more protective of the truth than you... And more striking against the tyrant while dust rises
And more trustworthy with the pillion-riding women (Murdafat) in the evening... In catching up when the cutting sword is unsheathed'
Jarir had actually said 'With the slender swords (Murhafat)', but Umar narrated it as 'Murdafat' (pillion riders). Then Umar said to Jarir: 'They were taken in the morning, and you caught them in the evening? By Allah, I only caught them after they were married and disgraced!' Jarir said: 'By Allah, this verse is dearer to me than my first-born Hazarah! But you plotted for Al-Farazdaq and directed it against me, and you will know!' Then Jarir recited his poem saying:
'Clear the way for the one who builds the lighthouse in it... And come out to a duel where fate compels you'
'O Taym, Taym of Adi, may you have no father... Let not Umar find you in a disgraceful situation'
'You ceased not speaking sayings that reach me... The wind of the bitter plant until the clay rose'
'Is it when you were poison, O Banu Laja... And Mudar bet against me regarding its haseb (merits)?!'
Umar bin Laja answered him:
'You lied, and the worst speech is the most lying... Mudar did not bet against you regarding its haseb'
'Are you not the leap of a weak man upon a slave girl... Meanness and weakness do not win the races'
'Whatever bitter thing you say, I will demolish it... O son of the female donkey, by the likes of me ropes are undone'

Then we turn to the explanation of the first verse: 'Ya Tayma Tayma Adiyyin': Two grammatical views. Sibawayh: The first Taym is added to Adi, and the second Taym is emphatic, inserted between the governor (Added-to) and the governed (Added-to noun), like the insertion of 'Ma' in 'Fa-bima rahmatin mina Allahi linta lahum'. Abu al-Abbas al-Mubarrad: First Taym added to a deleted element indicated by what follows, as if saying: 'O Taym of Adi, O Taym of Adi'. Al-Farra' went similarly. The vowel in first Taym is case vowel, second is following vowel (Sibawayh). Both are case vowels (Mubarrad). If believed both nouns became one like 'Hadramout' added to Adi: First Taym built (Mabni), second declinable. As-Sirafi allowed it like 'Ya Zaydu bin Amr', making described and adjective like one noun.
'La aba lakum': 'La' of negation (Tabri'ah), its predicate deleted: 'La aba lakum mawjudun' (No father for you exists). If asked: Why not 'Lakum' as predicate? The answer: The preventing factor is the appearance of Alif in 'Aba'. The vowel letters in 'Ab' and sisters are original, appearing only in addition (Idafa). So due to Alif, it must be added to the pronoun, and the Lam is inserted to emphasize the addition. Since this is the case, 'Lakum' cannot be the predicate. The genitive phrase is the predicate only if Alif is deleted: 'La abba laka', as Nahar bin Tawsi'ah said: 'Islam refused, I have no father other than it...'.
If asked: How is the Lam 'inserted extra' when saying 'La abaka' is invalid because 'Ab' becomes definite by addition to pronoun, and 'La' doesn't work on definite? So if this Lam prepared the noun for 'La', how is it extra? Answer: It is counted for preparing the noun, and not counted regarding the Alif fixation. Contradiction? No, different aspects.
If asked: In 'La aba li-Zaydin', is 'Zaydin' genitive by addition of 'Aba' or by 'Lam'? Answer: Choice is genitive by Lam. Reason: Two operators on one noun is impossible. Suspending one is necessary. Suspending the Noun (Ab) is better because Nouns are suspended (e.g. 'Khayrin wa afdala min thamma'), while Particles rarely suspended except 'Ba' in 'Laysa Zaydun bi-qa'imin' (Za'idah). Also Noun is stronger. Ibn Jinni allowed suspending the Noun. Suspending the Particle possible in narration ('Bi-nama sahibuhu').

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of What Must Keep the Ya:
'O daughter of my uncle (Amma), do not blame and sleep'

This verse is by Abu an-Najm al-Ajli. Name: Al-Fadl bin Qudama. Qudama: Improvised from 'Taqdim'. Al-Fadl/An-Najm: Transferred. After it:
'Do not let me hear blame from you, and hear!... Far, far away, and do not look/expect'
'They are the decrees, so blame or leave it... Do not hope for my separation, do not hope!'
Narrated: 'Hiya al-mulazim' (The sticking decrees).

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'O son of my mother, and O little brother of my soul... You left me to a severe time'

This verse: Narrated for Abu Zubayd at-Ta'i. Name: Harmala bin al-Mundhir. In a poem:
'Except that Al-Julah broke my wing... The day I left him at the high Sa'id'
'On the right of the road, at a grave (Sada)... Thirsty, calling at night, not visited'
'Thirsty asking for aid, not aided... And he used to be the helper of the distressed'
Zubayd: Transferred (diminutive of Zubd/Zabad etc.). Harmala: Transferred (plant).

So *Hudhayba* (a hill) is not hidden when evening comes ... nor is her feeding the dogs with her newborn lamb (*Sakhla*). She pierces its two teats with arrowheads (*Mashaqis*) ... while its placenta has dampened the dust. Sibawayh allowed in his saying 'A-Abdan' (A slave?!) that it be a vocative, or that it be accusative as a circumstantial state (*Hal*), as if he said: 'Do you boast while being a slave?' meaning in the state of his slavery, for boasting does not befit a slave! *Sha'bi*: A place. *Ghariban* (Stranger): Is accusative as an adjective for 'Abd' (slave), or as a *Hal* from the pronoun in 'Halla' (settled). And his saying: 'A-lu'man la aba laka, wa-ightiraban' (Meanness, no father for you, and estrangement?!): They are accusative based on two perspectives. First: That the estimation is 'A-tal'umu lu'man, wa taghtaribu ightiraban' (Do you act meanly with meanness, and become estranged with estrangement?), so they are verbal nouns (Masdar) made accusative by omitted verbs. Second: That the estimation is: 'A-tajma'u lu'man wa ightiraban' (Do you combine meanness and estrangement?), so you omit a single verb that acts upon both of them. This view is better to me than the first. The Alif in his saying 'A-lu'man' is the Alif of scolding and denial, like the one in the saying of Al-Ajjaj: 'A-taraban wa anta qinnasriyyu?! ... Wa innama ya'ti al-siba al-sabiyyu!' (Passion/Youthful joy while you are an old man?! ... Only the boy engages in youthful folly!). Abu al-Qasim recited in the chapter of the Two Nouns whose wording is one, and the second of them is annexed (*Mudaf*): 'O Taym of Taym of Adiy, no father for you (*La Aba Lakum*) ... Let not Umar meet you in a disgrace!' This verse is by Jarir, saying it to Umar bin Laja. The reason for that was that Jarir passed by Umar bin Laja while he was reciting an Urjuza poem of his, and people were around him listening. He stopped to listen. When he reached his saying: 'She arrived before the time of her mid-morning ... preying on snakes in her loose skin. Dragging with ease whoever doubts her ... the dragging of the old woman the sides of her tent.' Jarir said to him: 'You did poorly, and failed in what you said!' Umar said to him: 'So how should I say?' He said to him: 'Say: The dragging of the bride the folds of her sleeves.' Umar was embarrassed and said: 'You are in a worse state than me when you say: 'I am more protective of the reality for my people than you ... and more striking of the tyrant while the dust is rising. And more trustworthy near the *Murdafat* (women riding pillion) in the evening ... catching up when the sharp sword is drawn.'' Jarir had actually said: 'Near the *Murhafat*' (sharp swords/delicate women), but Umar narrated it: 'Near the *Mirdafat*.' Then he said to Jarir: 'They were taken in the morning, and you caught them in the evening. By God, you did not catch them until they had been married and exposed!' Jarir said: 'By God, this verse is dearer to me than my first-born virgin camel! But you plotted for Al-Farazdaq and turned it against me, and you shall know!' Then Jarir recited his poem in which he says: 'Clear the road for the one who builds the lighthouse in it ... and emerge in a duel where fate has compelled you. O Taym, Taym of Adiy, no father for you! ... Let not Umar meet you in a disgrace. You have not ceased speaking words that reach me ... the smell of the twisted rope, until the clay/townsfolk departed. Was it when you were *Samam* (deaf/poison), O Banu Laja ... and Mudar wagered on me regarding her lineages?!' Umar bin Laja answered him, saying: 'You have lied, and the worst speech is its most lying ... Mudar did not wager on you regarding her lineages. Are you not the leap of a weakling upon a slave girl ... Meanness and weakness do not win the races. Whatever you have said once, I will dismantle it ... O son of the female donkey, by the likes of me ropes are dismantled.' Then we turn to the explanation of the preceding poetry: 'Ya Tayma Tayma Adiyyin' (O Taym of Taym of Adiy) has two schools of thought: Sibawayh's school: The first *Taym* is annexed to Adiy, and the second *Taym* is an emphasis that intervened between the governor (genitive particle/construct) and the governed (genitive noun), like the intervention of 'Ma' in His Almighty's saying: 'Fa-bima rahmatin min Allahi linta lahum' (So by what mercy from God you were gentle with them). Abu al-Abbas al-Mubarrad's school: The first *Taym* is annexed to an omitted word indicated by what follows it, as if he said: 'Ya Tayma Adiyyin, Ya Tayma Adiyyin.' Al-Farra went towards something like this. So the vowel in the first *Taym* is a vowel of case declension (*I'rab*), and in the second *Taym* it is a vowel of following/alliteration (*Itba'*) according to Sibawayh's school. According to Abu al-Abbas's school, both vowels are vowels of case declension. Whoever believes that the two nouns together were made into one noun, like Hadramawt and Ba'labakk, and annexed to Adiy: the vowel of the first *Taym* would be a vowel of construction (*Bina'*), and the vowel of the second *Taym* would be a vowel of case declension. Al-Sirafi allowed it to be like 'Ya Zayd bin Amr', making the described noun with its adjective like one noun, so 'Zayd' in this view behaves like an explicative appositive (*Atf Bayan*) acting as an adjective. His saying: 'La Aba Lakum' (No father for you): 'La' is for acquittal (*Tabri'ah*), and its predicate is omitted, as if he said: 'No father for you exists in the world.' If you ask: What prevents 'Lakum' (for you) from being the predicate, so no omission is needed?

The answer is: What prevents that is the appearance of the Alif in 'Al-Ab' (the father); because the letters of prolongation and softness in 'Al-Ab'—and its sisters—are roots that only remain fixed in the state of annexation (*Idafa*). So due to the Alif, it must be annexed to the pronoun, and the Lam (L) becomes inserted as an emphasis for the annexation. If the matter is as we described, it becomes invalid for 'Lakum' to be the predicate. The prepositional phrase is only the predicate if the Alif is omitted and you say: 'La Aba Laka' (as distinct from *La Aba Laka* with the long vowel, though commonly written the same, the argument concerns the morphological form implying distinct constructs), just as Nahar bin Tawsi'ah al-Yashkuri said: 'Islam refused, no father for me other than it ... when they boasted of Qays or Tamim.' If a speaker says: How is it correct to say about this Lam: 'It is a redundant insertion (*Za'ida Muqhama*),' when if you said: 'La Aba Laka' (without intention of separation), it would not be permissible; because the 'Ab' would become definite by annexation to the pronoun, and 'La' does not govern the definite annexed noun? So if this Lam prepared the noun and fixed it so that 'La' could govern it, and reliance is upon it, how can it be said of something that is counted upon and relied upon: 'It is redundant'??! The answer is that the Lam is counted upon from the perspective that it prepared the noun for 'La' to govern it, and it is not counted upon from the perspective of confirming the Alif in 'Al-Ab'. If it is said: How is it correct to say of one thing: 'It is counted upon, and not counted upon'? Is this not like combining contradictories??! The answer is: It would only be considered combining contradictories if we said: 'It is counted upon' from one perspective, in one meaning. But if the perspectives differ, this objection of yours does not hold; because it is not denied that a thing can be counted upon from one perspective and not counted upon from another! If a speaker says: So when you say: 'La Aba li-Zaydin' (No father for Zayd), with what do you put Zayd in the genitive: by the annexation of 'Ab', or by the Lam? The answer is: The choice according to us is that it is in the genitive by the Lam, not by the annexation. The reason for that is: When two governors gather, and it is not permissible for Zayd to be governed by both of them—since two governors cannot act in one governed word, in one state, from one perspective—it was inevitable to suspend one of them from working and apply the other. Suspending the noun was more appropriate for two reasons: First: We have found nouns suspended from governing, as in their saying: 'Marartu bi-khayrin wa afdala min thamma' (I passed by one better and more excellent than there - *where 'better' doesn't govern strict genitive if separated*), and 'Qat'u yadin wa rijlin min khilafin' (Cutting of a hand and a foot from opposite sides), and Al-Farazdaq said: 'O you who saw a rain cloud for which I stayed awake ... between the arms and the forehead of the Lion (constellation).' We have not found a particle suspended from governing, even if it is redundant, except rarely, like the Ba in our saying: 'Laysa Zaydun bi-qa'imin' (Zayd is not standing) - it is redundant but has governed just as the non-redundant governs in: 'Marartu bi-Zaydin' (I passed by Zayd). Similarly, we said: 'Ma ja'ani min ahadin' (No one came to me): 'Min' has governed 'Ahad' even though it is redundant, just as the non-redundant governs in our saying: 'Kharajtu min al-dar' (I went out of the house). The second reason: The noun is stronger than the particle, and the stronger can bear suspension and omission that the weaker cannot bear. Ibn Jinni said this, and he allowed the first opinion, which is suspending the noun. It is possible for one who suspends the particle to say: We have found particles suspended in narration/imitation (*Hikayah*), like the saying of the Rajiz poet: 'Wallahi ma layli bi-nama sahibuhu ... wa la mukhaliti al-layyana janibuhu' (By God, my night is not one whose companion slept ... nor whose side mixed with softness - *where the case endings don't match standard negation governance*). Abu al-Qasim recited in the chapter of what is only permissible with the affirmation of the Ya: 'O daughter of my uncle (*Ya Ibnata 'Amma*), do not blame but sleep.' This verse is by Abu al-Najm al-Ijli. His name is: Al-Fadl bin Qudama. Qudama: An improvised name derived from 'Taqdim' (advancing) or 'Taqaddum' (precedence). Al-Fadl and Al-Najm are transferred names. After it is: 'Do not make me hear blame from you, but hear! ... Far, far away, and do not look. They are the Destinies, so blame or leave it ... Do not hope for my separation, do not hope!' It is narrated: 'Hiya al-Mulazim' (They are the Inseparable ones) - meaning the inseparable fates from which no one escapes! Abu al-Qasim recited in this chapter: 'O son of my mother (*Ya Ibna Ummi*) and O little brother of my soul (*Ya Shuqayqa Nafsi*) ... You have left me to a severe time.' This verse is narrated for Abu Zubayd al-Ta'i. His name is Harmala bin al-Mundhir, in a poem where he says: 'However, Al-Julah broke my wing ... the day I parted from him, at the highest highland. On the right of the road, near a thirsty owl ... calling in the night, unvisited. Thirsty, seeking relief, unrelieved ... and indeed, he was the refuge of the distressed.' Zubayd: Transferred name. It may be the diminutive of *Zabd* (gift), or diminutive of *Zubd* (butter), or diminutive of the foam (*Zabad*) that tops water, or diminutive of *Zabid*, or *Mazbud*, or *Muzbid* - in the sense of trimmed diminutive (*Tarkhim*). Harmala: Also transferred from the singular of *Harmal* (Rue plant).

As for 'Tayyi'': It is 'Fay'il' from 'Ta'a Yatu'u' (traveled/came). Origin 'Tayw', Waw turned to Ya, assimilated. Relative 'Ta'iy' (originally 'Tayyi''). Deleted one Ya, changed second to Alif for ease. 'Hadda': Demolished/Took away. 'As-Sa'id': Earth surface/Grave. 'As-Sada': A bird; Arabs claimed it forms from the dead (slain) saying 'Give me drink' until killer is killed. Hence 'Sadiyan' (thirsty). Famous Arab myth. Tarafa used it differently:
'A generous one quenching himself in his life... You will know if we die, whose Sada is the thirsty one?!'
He says to blamers on drinking: I quench my Sada in life, so it won't cry 'Drink!' after death. You don't, so we'll see whose ghost cries! 'As-Sadi' is raised by Inchoation. 'Ayyina' genitive by addition. People mistakenly nunate 'Sada' and raise 'Ayyuna'. 'Al-'Usrah': Refuge. 'Al-Manjud': Distressed.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'O son of my mother, if I had witnessed you when you called... Tamim, while you were unanswered'

This verse is by Ma'adi Yakrub, known as Ghalfa', mourning his brother Shurahbil bin al-Harith, killed at Yawm al-Kulab (Leader of Bakr). Ibn an-Nahhas claimed it's by Muhalhil - mistake! Ma'adi Yakrub: Improvised ('Sadness missed you' - Tha'lab). Shurahbil: 'God's deposit'. Ghalfa': Transferred (Feminine of Aghlaf). Poem recited by Abu Ubayda:
'Indeed my side is shying away from the bed... Like the unease of beds upon the sharp stones'
'From a hadith brought to me, so my eye does not... Dry its tears, nor do I swallow my drink'
'Bitter like poison I hide from people... Upon Harmala like the meteor'
'From Shurahbil when the spears took turns on him... In a state of youthfulness and youth'
'O son of my mother, if I had witnessed you when you called... Tamim, while you were unanswered'
'Then I would have stabbed defending you until... The people were pushed back or my clothes were stripped'

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of What occurs only in Vocative:
'And her saying made me doubt: O Hanahu (Man)... Woe to you, you attached evil to evil!'

This verse: Narrated for Imru' al-Qays. Al-Asma'i narrated it for a man of Namir bin Qasit (Rabi'ah bin Jusham). 'Rabani': Made me doubt. 'Ya Hanahu': O man (for contempt). 'Alhaqta sharran bi-sharrin': You were accused before, now you increased the accusation!

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'In a clamor, hold So-and-so (Fulan) from So-and-so (Ful)'

This verse: By Abu an-Najm (Al-Fadl bin Qudama). Before it:
'Their hands stir the dust of the dust... When they surrounded the sifted resting place'
'Pushing the old men and not fighting'
'In a clamor: Hold So-and-so from So-and-so (Ful)'
Describing camels stirring dust. 'Al-Qastal': Dust. 'Ash-Shib': Old men (Sheiks). Meaning: They crowd like old men pushing each other in a clamor. 'Amsik fulanan...': Hold this one from that one. 'Ful' is truncation (Tarkhim) of Fulan. 'Lujjah': Confusion of voices. Meaning: In a clamor where it is said [Hold...], 'it is said' hidden.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'I roam what I roam, then I return... To a house whose sitter (wife) is mean (Laka'u)'

This verse is by Al-Hutay'a. Name: Jarwal bin Aws. Kunya: Abu Mulaykah. Mocking his wife.

Jarwal, Aws, Al-Hutay'a, Al-Mulaykah: Transferred names. Jarwal: Stone. Rajaz: 'O palm tree of the Sidr and stones (Jarawil)'. Aws: Gift (compensation) or Wolf. Uways: Diminutive. Mulaykah: Diminutive of Malikah (Queen) or Malakah (measure of Zulmah). Al-Hutay'a: Diminutive of Hat'ah (Fart) or Slap/Throw down. Nicknamed Hutay'a: For shortness, or farting in public ('What is this?' 'Hutay'ah'), or having a 'Mahtu'ah' leg (no arch). 'Atawwafu ma attawwafu': I roam much. Narrated: 'Attawwadu'. 'Ma' with verb: Source estimation ('Tawafi'). 'Qa'idatuhu': Wife. 'Laka'u': Mean/Vile. Masculine 'Luka''. Mostly vocative ('Ya Luka'u'), but sometimes otherwise. Hadith: 'Last Hour won't come until the happiest is Luka' bin Luka''.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'And what is upon you to say whenever... You say Tahlil or Tasbih: O God (Ya lal-lah), what...'
'Return to us our Sheikh safe... From wherever, however, and whenever!!'

This Rajaz: Unknown author. Kufans added: 'For indeed we will not lack good from him'. Meaning: Commanding family to pray for him. 'Ma': Extra.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Istighatha (Seeking Help/Wonder):
'Oh wonder (Ya 'ajaban) for this calamity (Faliqah)... Will the saliva (Riqa) remove the skin disease (Qawba')?'

This poetry: Unknown author. 'Faliqah': Calamity. Also 'Faliq', 'Falaq', 'Falqah', 'Faylaq'. Abu al-Abbas al-Mubarrad claimed 'Falaq' (fatha on Fa) - unknown. Suwayd bin Kura': '...They worked a calamity (Falqa) with it'. 'Faylaq': Army/Calamity. 'Falaq' in 'Falaq as-subh'. 'Al-Qawba'': Skin disease/Lichen (Fatha/Sukun on Waw). Fatha: Hamza is feminine (diptote). Sukun: Hamza is annexation (triptote). Kufans allow diptote with Sukun (feminine), Basrans reject. 'Ar-Riqah': Piece of saliva. Verse about a Bedouin with Qawba', told to use saliva, wondered at it! Narrated: 'Taghlibanna' (Overcome). 'Ajaban': Nunated (Indefinite vocative or Source). Without nunation (Added vocative or 'Ya ajabah'). Example 'Ya marhabahu'.

'The slanderers surrounded me and disturbed me... Oh people, [help against] the obeyed slanderer.'

This verse is by Qays bin Dharih, and we have mentioned his name previously. He had married Lubna, but his father detested it and ordered him to divorce her. He refused, so his father swore not to seek shade under a roof until he divorced her. Then he lay in the Ramda (scorching hot sand heated by the sun) and said: 'By Allah, I will not leave this spot until you divorce her or I die!' His people rebuked Qays for his father's rights and said: 'If your father dies in this state, it will be a disgrace upon you. So satisfy him by divorcing her, and you can seek his favor later to take her back.' So he divorced her unwillingly! Then he lost his mind, and his father regretted what he had done. Lubna's father refused [remarriage] and when asked to let him take her back, he refused and married her to another! So Qays said regarding that:
'O my liver! My pain has returned to me... And the separation of Lubna was like mutilation'
'The slanderers surrounded me and disturbed me... Oh people, [help against] the obeyed slanderer'
'So I became, in the morning, blaming myself... For a thing that is not possible [to undo]'
'Like a cheated one biting his hands... Who realized his loss after the sale'
'In a house of loss I left you, Lubna... Thus the Gin (demons) guide to loss'
'And we lived with the pleasure of life for a time... If only Time were a guardian for man'
'But the gathering is destined for separation... And the causes of death have their callers'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'A distant stranger far from home weeps for you... Oh middle-aged men and youths, for the wonder!'
This verse: I do not know its author. 'An-Na'i': The distant one. He meant here: his distance in lineage, because he mentioned the distance of his place from his place! He described 'Na'in' (distant one), which is indefinite, with 'Ba'id ad-dar' (far of house), which is added to a definite, because its addition implies separation, for 'Ad-Dar' is the subject in meaning, even if it is genitive in wording, because the estimation is: 'Ba'idun daruhu'. He says: The stranger weeps for you, while the close relative rejoices at your death, and that is one of the wonders, as the other said:
'The stranger weeps for him, not knowing him... While the relative in the tribe is happy!'
He sought help (Istighatha) from them, just as he sought help from the middle-aged men. He put a kasra on the Lam of 'Ash-Shubban' because the origin of this Lam is kasra, and it was opened [in the first noun] to distinguish between the one whose help is sought and the one for whom help is sought. When one noun was coordinated with the other, it was known that it falls under its ruling, because the property of 'Waw' (and) is to share between the coordinated and the one coordinated upon in wording and meaning, so that sufficed instead of opening it, thus he brought it on the original form. This is not in every place, but only where the vocative particle is not repeated, like saying: 'Ya la-Zaydin wa li-Amrin wa li-l-'ajabi'. If you repeat the vocative particle, you say: 'Ya la-Zaydin wa Ya la-Amrin' - opening both, because the speech becomes two sentences. The poet said regarding repetition:
'Oh for my people, who is for high ranks and endeavors... Oh for my people, who is for generosity and tolerance'
'Oh for 'Attaf and Oh for Riyah... And for Abu al-Hashraj, the generous youth'
It is narrated: 'Wa Abi al-Hashraj' [without repetition of Ya].

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'O Harith bin Ka'b, do no dreams (minds) restrain you... from us, while you are of the hollow, weak ones (Al-Jamakhir)?!'
This verse is by Hassan bin Thabit, and I have mentioned his name previously. The reason for saying this poem was that An-Najashi mocked Banu al-Najjar from the Ansar with a poem saying:
'You are not, Banu al-Najjar, equals like us... So go away from us, there, go away!'
'If you wish, we will compete with you citing your father... Against whomever you wish from Tihama or Najd'
'Was there not among us one who blows the bellows with his backside... As if on his cheeks is the dust of antimony?!'
The Ansar said to Hassan bin Thabit: 'O Abu al-Walid, will you mock An-Najashi?' He said: 'Where do you stand regarding the two sons of Abd al-Rahman?' They said: 'We wanted you, for Abd al-Rahman answered him but achieved nothing!' Hassan jumped and hit him [An-Najashi] with the door, splitting his eyebrow. He said: 'In the name of Allah, O Allah, compensate your Messenger today.' Then he recited his poem saying:
'O Banu al-Himas, is there no noble one among you... Indeed chivalry in Al-Himas is little'
Then he said: 'By Allah, I have not fulfilled what he said!!' Then he said: 'Listen:
O Harith bin Ka'b, do no dreams (minds) restrain you... from us, while you are of the hollow, weak ones (Al-Jamakhir)?!'

'There is no harm in the people regarding height or shortness... [But] bodies of mules and dreams (minds) of sparrows'
'Leave the strutting walk and walk a natural walk... Indeed men are possessors of strong nerves and masculinity'
'Height is of no benefit with the foolishness of hearts... Nor does God guide the path of the corrupt people'
'Indeed I will withhold my honor from your nobles... Indeed An-Najashi is a thing not mentioned [worthless]'
'He found his father, and found his grandfather held back... In isolation from the endeavors of glory and goodness'

Then he said: 'Write them as deeds and throw them to the boy scribes!' They did so. The news reached Banu Abd al-Madan, so they took An-Najashi, bound him, and brought him to Hassan, saying: 'This is our companion, we have brought him to you, so judge him, O Abu al-Walid!' Hassan said: 'Call out to the people.' The people flocked to the fortress of Hassan with weapons. A pulpit was placed for Hassan, he sat on it holding a baton, and said: 'Where is my companion?' An-Najashi was brought and made to sit before him. Abdullah bin Abd al-Madan said to him: 'This is he, judge him as you see fit, and withhold the sharpness of your tongue from us, for we used to boast to people about the size of our bodies and our height, and you have spoiled that for us.' Hassan said: 'Nay!! Are you not the one who said regarding you:
And we used to say when we saw... One of body who is counted, and of eloquence'
As if you, O one given eloquence... And a body, are from Banu Abd al-Madan?!'
Then he looked at An-Najashi for a while, then said to his son: 'Where are the dirhams remaining from Muawiyah's gift?' He brought them, and they were a hundred dinars. Then he said: 'Bring me the mule of my son Abd al-Rahman.' They brought it. He said: 'Untie his bonds.' They untied him. Hassan said: 'Take these dirhams and spend them, and this mule and ride it!' The group thanked him for that!!

'Al-Juf': Plural of 'Ajwaf', which is one with a large hollow (body). 'Al-Jamakhir': Plural of 'Jumkhur', which is one with a huge body but weak. 'At-Takhaju'': A walk with swagger. 'Al-Mashya as-Sujuh': The easy walk. 'Al-'Asb': Strength of creation; it is said: A man 'Ma'sub', strong of build. 'Al-Bur': Plural of 'Ba'ir', meaning the perished/corrupt. 'Al-Ma'zil': A place isolated from dwellings. 'Al-Masa'i': What a person strives for of good or evil. 'Al-Majd': Great honor. 'Al-Khayr': Generosity.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'O Harith, let me not be struck by a calamity from you... That no commoner (Suqah) before me nor king has met'
This verse is from the famous poetry of Zuhair bin Abi Sulma, addressing Al-Harith bin Warqa as-Saydawi al-Asadi. He had raided Banu Abdullah bin Ghatafan, took spoils, and took Zuhair's camels and his shepherd, Yasar. So he demanded them back, to return what he took. 'Suqah' refers to people other than the King.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'O 'Aisha, what is wrong with your family, I do not see them... Wasting the white camels (Al-Hijan) along with the wasted things (Al-Madi' with Fatha)'
This verse is by Ash-Shammakh, his name is Ma'qil bin Dirar, mentioned previously. After it:
'And how can the owner of [camels] kept warm waste them... [With fat/fur] on their backs protecting from the frost?'
'Hijan al-Ibil': The best of them. 'Al-Mudfa'at': Those with much fur. 'Al-Athbaj': The middles/backs, singular 'Thabaj'. 'As-Saqi'': Frost/Ice. He meant: Upon their backs is much fur protecting them from cold, by which they are warmed. He meant that 'Aisha said to him: Why do you not visit us, and busy yourself tending your camels and traveling with them? He said to her: If wasting wealth is correct, why don't your family do it?! Just as your family tends their camels and does not waste them, likewise I tend my camels and do not waste them. Then he said: And how can one waste his wealth who possesses camels that are protected and warmed by the abundance of fur on their backs?! Then he praised his camels and affirmed preserving them:
'Indeed a man's wealth repairs him and makes him free of need... His pardons are more chaste than begging (Qunu')'
'He blocks with it calamities that afflict him... From the days, like thirsty camels (Nuhal) entering the water (Shuru')'
'Al-Qunu'': Begging. 'An-Nuhal': Thirsty camels, singular 'Nahil'. 'Ash-Shuru'': Those entering the water.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'O Asma, patience upon what has occurred of events... Indeed events are [either] encountered or awaited'
This verse is by Abu Zubayd at-Ta'i, consoling Asma, mother of Abdullah bin Umar bin al-Khattab. He was killed at Siffin, being on Muawiyah's side. Therefore he said in this poem:

'How many a brother of mine, his perishing is the equal of death... Perished, so my share after him was remembrance'
'O bowl like the pool of the cistern, overturned... At the belly of Siffin, dust rising over it'
He says: Of events, there are those a human has encountered, and those he awaits, and he does not doubt he will meet them, since man is created for perishing, knowing there is no way for him but [not] remaining! 'Idl ash-shay'' (with kasra on Ayn): Its equal in kind. You say: I have the 'Idl' of your garment, i.e., a garment like it. And I have its 'Adl' (with fatha), i.e., its value.
'Mahlikuhu' is allowed with fatha on Meem, being a source meaning 'Ihlak' (destruction/causing death), and 'Mahlikuhu' with fatha, being a source meaning 'Halak' (perishing). 'Maf'al', if the verb is triliteral, its Meem is open. If from a verb exceeding three letters, its Meem is designated with damma. If you open the Meem of 'Mahlik', you may break the Lam or open it. It is recited: 'Ma shahidna mahlika ahlihi'.
'An-Nadih': The large cistern. 'Kufi'at': Overturned. 'Al-'Afr': Dust. It is said: 'So-and-so's bowl was overturned and his milk-skins became empty' if he died. This is because when a master died, the bowl he used to feed others in was broken, and his milk-skins were left empty, no milk churned in them. Therefore Imru' al-Qays said:
'And 'Ilba' escaped them by choking [on death]... And if I had caught him, the milk-skins would have been empty'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Stop, O Asma, do you know him?... Is this the Mughiri who used to be mentioned?'
This verse is by Umar bin Abi Rabi'ah, and we have mentioned his name and Kunya. This verse is from his Gilded Poem (Mudhahhabah), which is eighty verses. Before it:
'However, she said the morning I met her... At the stream of Aknan: Is this the famous one?!'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'O Marwan, indeed my mount is detained... Hoping for the gift, and its owner has not despaired'
This verse is by Al-Farazdaq, and we mentioned his name and Kunya previously. The reason for his saying this poem was that he was residing in Medina, and he was the most adulterous of people. He recited a poem saying:
'The two of them lowered me from eighty fathoms... Like a dark-feathered hawk swooping down'
'When my feet settled on the ground, they said:... Is he alive so hope is held, or a slain one we should beware of?'
'So I said: Raise the ropes so they do not sense us... And I turned back in the ends of the night hastening'
'Wary of two doormen entrusted with us... And a black [door] of teak whose nails glisten'
Jarir shamed him for that in a long poem of his, saying:
'When the mother of Al-Farazdaq gave birth to a debauchee... She brought a short-legged waddler'
'He connects his two ropes when his night darkens... To climb to his female neighbors by ladders'
'You lowered yourself to commit adultery from eighty fathoms... And you fell short of the span of glory and noble deeds'
'He is the filth, O people of Medina, so beware... The entrances of filth, knowledgeable of wicked women'
'Indeed, expelling Al-Farazdaq from among you... Would be a purification for what is between the Prayer Place and Waqim'

The nobles of Medina gathered to Marwan bin al-Hakam, who was its governor, and said to him: 'It is not proper that such poetry be recited among the wives of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and he has obligated the Hadd punishment upon himself!!' Marwan said: 'I will not punish him myself, but I will write to one who will punish him.' So Marwan ordered him to leave Medina and gave him a deadline of three days. Regarding that, Al-Farazdaq says:
'He threatened me and gave me a deadline of three... Just as Thamud was promised their destruction'
Then he wrote a letter for him to his agent, ordering him to punish and imprison him, while misleading him that he wrote for a prize! Then Marwan regretted what he did! So he sent a messenger to him saying: 'I have composed a poem, so hear it.' He recited:
'Say to Al-Farazdaq, and foolishness is its cup... If you are leaving what I ordered you, then sit'
'And leave Medina, for it is blamed... And aim for Mecca or Jerusalem'
'And if you avoid great matters... Then take for yourself the best dwellings!'
Al-Farazdaq understood what he intended, so he threw the scroll and said:
'O Marwan, indeed my mount is detained... Hoping for the gift, and its owner has not despaired'

'And you gifted me a sealed scroll... You fear for me regarding it the gift of Al-Niqras (calamity/trap)'
'Throw the scroll, O Farazdaq, do not let it be... An evil like the scroll of Al-Mutalammis'
He went out fleeing until he came to Sa'id bin al-As, and with him were Al-Hasan and Al-Husayn, peace be upon them, and Abdullah bin Ja'far. He told them the news, so each of them ordered him a hundred dinars and a mount, and he headed to Basra. It was said to Marwan: 'You erred in what you did; for you exposed your honor to the poet of Mudar!!' So he sent a messenger after him with a hundred dinars and a mount, fearing his satire!

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Leave me to a tiring worry, O Umayma... And a night I endure, slow of stars'
This verse is from the famous poetry of An-Nabigha adh-Dhubyani. He was nicknamed Abu Umamah and Abu Aqrab, after two daughters he had. There is disagreement on why An-Nabigha was named Nabigha. It is said: He was named so because he composed poetry after he became old - it is said 'Nabagha ar-rajul' if he didn't say poetry then said it. It is said: He was named Nabigha for his saying:
'A distant intention has distanced Su'ad from you... So she spent the night while the heart is held hostage by her'
'And she settled among Banu al-Qayn bin Jasr... For affairs have appeared (nabaghat) to us from them'
It is said: Derived from 'Nabaghat al-hamamah' (the pigeon cooed) if it sang. Al-Riyashi said this. Ibn Wallad narrated that he said: 'Naba'a al-ma' wa nabagha' (water welled up). As if they meant: He has a supply of poetry that does not run out, like the supply of welling water! 'An-Nasib': The tiring one. The analogy was to say 'Munsib', as Tufayl said: 'Ta'annaka nasbu man Umayyata munsibu'. But it came with the meaning of relation, or by deleting the addition from the verb, as said: 'Awrasa ash-shajaru fahuwa waris' (The tree leafed so it is leafy), and 'Abqala al-makanu fahuwa baqil' (The place sprouted herbs so it is herbal). His saying 'Bati' al-kawakib': He meant that the night, due to its length, makes the one awake in it imagine that its stars do not move!

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Banu Amir said: Leave (Khalu) Banu Asad... Oh misery for ignorance, harmful to peoples!'
This verse is from the famous poetry of An-Nabigha. 'Khalu Banu Asad': Abandon them. It is said: 'Khala ar-rajulu ahlahu', if he divorced her. Dhubyan wanted to oppose Banu Amir, so Banu Amir said: We will not oppose you until you leave the alliance between you and Banu Asad. So An-Nabigha attributed ignorance to them in what they said, and informed them that this would not happen; for that would harm them with Banu Asad and make them hateful towards them. 'Diraran' is accusative as a state (Hal). The Lam in 'Ya bu'sa li-l-jahli' is inserted (extra). We said previously regarding Jarir's poetry 'La abalakum': That the choice is for the Lam to be the preposition, not the addition (Idafa), even if it is extra. We said there what suffices repeating here, so refer to it you will see it, God willing!

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Oh misery for the war that put down... groups (Arahit), so they rested'
This verse is by Sa'd bin Malik al-Qaysi, saying it during the War of Basus when war raged between Bakr and Taghlib due to the killing of Kulayb. Al-Harith bin Abbad withdrew from the war, saying: 'This is a matter in which I have no she-camel nor camel.' He remained withdrawn until Muhalhil killed his son Bujayr. When informed, he said: 'My son is a slain one of great blessing: If Allah reconciles the two sons of Wa'il through him, restrains their foolishness, and saves their blood!' 'As-Safah': Lightness and recklessness. Then he was told that when he killed him, he said: 'Die for the shoelace of Kulayb's sandal!' He did not believe that, and sent to Muhalhil saying: 'If you killed my son for your brother and accepted that as vengeance, I have accepted it; to extinguish this turmoil!' Muhalhil said: 'I only killed him for his sandal's shoelace!' At that, Al-Harith became angry. Al-Harith said to his mother: 'Bring back your loads so I can join you to your people, for who am I compared to what you are?', and it became a proverb! And he said:
'Bring the tether of [the horse] An-Na'amah near to me... The war of Wa'il has conceived after being barren'
'I was not one of its perpetrators, Allah knows... And indeed today I am burning in its heat'
'No neighbor protected a slain one, nor did the group... Of Kulayb refrain from error'
'Bring the tether of An-Na'amah near to me... Indeed the killing of the boy for a shoelace is expensive'
He returned to Bakr bin Wa'il and witnessed the war. It was the day Arabs call: The Day of Shaving (Yawm at-Tahaluq). Sa'd bin Malik had said - when Al-Harith withdrew from the war, exposing him and those who followed his path:
'Oh misery for the war that... Put down groups so they rested'

'And war, there does not remain for its burning fire... Arrogance nor liveliness'
'Except the steadfast youth in hardships... And the strong-hoofed horse'
'Whoever turns away from its fires... Then I am the son of Qays, there is no departure [I will stay]'
'It revealed its leg to us... And the pure [truth/milk] appeared to us from it'
When the Day of Shaving ended, and the victory that day was for Bakr over Taghlib, Al-Harith said to Sa'd bin Malik: 'Do you see me among those whom war put down?' He said: 'No, but there is no perfume hidden after a bride!' It became a proverb. Meaning: If you don't help your people now, for whom are you saving your help?! Meaning of 'Wada'at arahita': Dropped them so they had no mention in this war, so they rested from enduring its evil and suffering its heat. 'Arahit': Plural of 'Raht'. 'Arahit' has been used based on 'Arhut', Ru'ba said: 'He is the humble one in number among his groups (Arhutih)'. Most grammarians consider 'Arahit' a plural of 'Raht' not by analogy. 'At-Takhayyul': Pride. 'Al-Marah': Activity. 'Jahimuha': Its fire. 'An-Najdat': Hardships. 'An-Na'amah': Name of Al-Harith bin Abbad's horse. 'Laqihat': Conceived. 'Al-Hiyal': When the stallion mates with the camel but she doesn't conceive. It is said: The war of Bakr and Taghlib before today was 'Hiyal' (barren), i.e., like the barren camel, so today it became like the fertile one! He used this as a metaphor for what is born of war, of matters that were not calculated! Then Al-Harith bin Abbad swore not to make peace with Taghlib until the earth spoke to him!! When his assaults on Taghlib increased, and Taghlib saw they could not resist him, they dug a tunnel under the earth, put a man in it, and told him: When Al-Harith passes by you, sing this poetry:
'O Abu Mundhir, you have annihilated, so spare some of us... Mercy! Some evil is lighter than others'
When Al-Harith passed that spot, the man broke into song in the tunnel with this verse. It was said to Al-Harith: 'Your oath has been fulfilled, so spare the rest of your people.' And he did!

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of What Poets Truncated (Rakhkhamu) Outside of Vocative by Necessity:
'Have not your ropes become rotten (Rimam)... And Umama has become distant (Shasi'ah) from you'
This verse is by Jarir bin al-Khatafi. He meant by 'Al-Hibal' (Ropes): The covenants and connection that were between them. 'Rimam': Plural of 'Rimm', which is the piece of worn-out rope. 'Ash-Shasi'ah': The distant. This is how Sibawayh recited it as evidence for the permissibility of truncation (Tarkhim) in poetic necessity according to the dialect of those who say: 'Ya Har' with a kasra on the Ra. Abu al-Abbas Muhammad bin Yazid claimed he read to 'Umara bin Aqil bin Bilal bin Jarir: 'Wa ma 'ahdun ka-'ahdiki ya Umama', which contains no necessity. After this verse:
'Mu'jadat (strong camels) cross the trackless desert with it... And every strong camel that clears away the foam'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Is there no excuse/distraction for this Time... Against the people? Whatever it wills with the people, it does!'
'And this is my cloak, it borrows it with him... To rob me of my soul, O Mali bin Hanzal'
This poetry is by Al-Aswad bin Ya'fur at-Tamimi. Al-Aswad: Name transferred from 'Al-Aswad' which is opposite of white, or 'Al-Aswad' meaning the snake, or 'Al-Aswad' meaning the core of the heart or pupil of the eye. Ya'fur: Transferred from future tense of 'Afara', like 'Yashkur' from 'Shakara'. It is said: 'Afartu az-zar'a' if you watered it first, 'Afartu an-nakhla' if you pollinated it, 'Afartu ar-rahla' in dust, and 'Afura ar-rajulu' (with damma on Fa) 'afaratan' if he became wicked and changed. It has three dialects: Ya'far (fatha on Ya, damma on Fa), Ya'fir (damma on Ya, fatha on Fa - unlikely, probably Ya'fir is Ya-open Fa-kasra, correction needed based on context or standard morphology, usually Ya'fur/Ya'fir), and Yu'fur. Whoever says Yu'fur (damma on Ya and Fa) declines it (makes it triptote), and in the other two ways it is diptote. Whoever narrates 'Ala ma li-hadha ad-dahri min muta'allili' breaks the Lam because it is the active participle of 'Ta'allala'. Whoever narrates: 'Ala hal...' opens the Lam of 'Muta'allal' because it is a source like 'At-Ta'allul'. He meant by 'Ar-Rida' (cloak) here: Youth. He says: Time takes my youth and compensates me with old age to lead me thereby to senility and death! Like Imru' al-Qays said:
'To the root of the earth my roots have intertwined... And this death robs me of my youth'
'Min muta'allili': In the narration 'Ala ma li-hadha ad-dahri', 'Min' here is estimated with the specification (Tamyiz). If dropped, the noun is accusative, like the other said:
'O horseman, what a horseman you are... Trodding the sides, wide of arm span!'

If 'Min' were dropped, you would say: 'Ala ma li-hadha ad-dahri muta'allalan' - and 'Ya farisan ma anta farisan'. If the accusative appears, it is possible to be Tamyiz (specification) or Hal (state).
As for the one who narrates: 'Ala hal li-hadha ad-dahri min muta'allal' - with fatha on Lam, 'Al-Muta'allal' is a source meaning 'At-Ta'allul', and 'Min' is extra like its addition in your saying: 'Hal li-Zaydin min khurujin?'. The place of the genitive word is nominative by inchoation (Mubtada).
His saying: 'Yasta'iruhu': A sentence in the place of Hal (state) from the Ha, which is the pronoun of 'Ad-Dahr' (Time), or from the pronoun of 'Ar-Rida' (cloak) hidden in the adverb, because the meaning is 'Settled with him in this state'. If it is a state from 'Ad-Dahr', it is a state flowing on what it belongs to. If it is a state from the pronoun of 'Ar-Rida', it is a state flowing on other than what it belongs to. If you made it a single noun, you would say if it was a state from Time: 'Musta'irahu' (borrowing it), so the subject does not appear. If it was from the pronoun of the cloak, you would say: 'Musta'irahu huwa' (borrowed by it [time]), so you show the subject pronoun.
His saying: 'Indahu' (With him): If you wish, make it in the place of Raf' (nominative), as you say: 'Hadha Zaydun muntaliqun'. If you wish, in the place of Nasb (accusative), as you say: 'Hadha Zaydun muntaliqan', which is the preferred way.
The Lam in 'Li-yaslubani' is Lam of Kai (purpose/cause), attached to 'Al-Istiqrar' (the hidden existence) or to 'Yasta'iruhu'.
In his saying: 'Nafsi' (My soul/self): It can be a second object, or a substitute (Badal) for the pronoun; because 'Salb' (robbing) is sometimes used transitive to two objects, and sometimes to one object.
It is allowed in 'Amali' (O Mali - truncated form of Malik) to break the Lam on the dialect of 'Ya Har', and to open it on the dialect of 'Ya Zayd bin Amr'. This is only on the school of those who make the truncated noun after truncation like a noun standing by itself with nothing deleted.
The Lam in 'Li-hadha' is attached to a deleted element, because it is in the place of the predicate of the subject which is 'Ma'. It is like 'Ma li-Zaydin'.
As for the Ba in 'Bi-an-nasi', it can be attached to 'Sha'a' (willed), as you say: 'Aradtu bi-Zaydin al-khayra' (I intended good for Zayd). Or attached to 'Yaf'alu' (Does), as you say: 'Fa'altu bi-hi al-jamil' (I did the beautiful thing to him). A parallel to the first view is the poet's saying:
'He intended for me that in which there is no good... But preventing hands stood between him [and it]'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
