'And the milk-camel's colt (young weakling), when tied in a rope... Cannot withstand the assault of the huge aged camels'
This verse is by Jarir bin al-Khatafi. The reason for saying it was: He entered upon Al-Walid bin Abd al-Malik bin Marwan, while Adi bin ar-Riqa' al-Amili was reciting his poem starting with:
'He recognized the dwellings by imagination and frequented them... After decay had encompassed their lands!'
When he finished reciting the poem, Al-Walid said to him: 'Do you hear, O Ibn al-Khatafi?!' He said: 'Who is he, O Commander of the Faithful?' He said: 'Adi bin ar-Riqa' al-Amili.' Jarir said to him: 'Is he one of those about whom Allah said: "Faces, that Day, will be humbled, working [hard] and exhausted. They will [enter to] burn in an intensely hot Fire"?' Al-Walid said to him: 'May you have no mother! Do you say this about one who praises our living and eulogizes our dead?!!' Jarir said:
'The reach of the Amili falls short of the heights... But the penis of the Amili is long?'
Adi said: 'Did your mother inform you of its length, or are you a man who doesn't know what to say?!' Al-Walid said: 'Rather, he is a man who doesn't know what to say!' Jarir became angry. Adi said: 'O Commander of the Faithful, protect me from his tongue!' Al-Walid said - to Jarir -: 'By Allah, if you mention him in your poetry, I will saddle you and ride you until the poets mock you for it!!' So Jarir did not mention him in his poetry, but he alluded to him in his poem starting:
'Greet Al-Hidamlah from Dhat al-Mawa'is... For the bend has become desolate, not inhabited'
He said in it:
'Indeed, when the deluded poet provokes me... [He is like] a neighbor to a grave at Marran, buried'
'He was squint-eyed, refusing [injustice], so he bequeathed to us... Trouble upon the people in his squint-eyed sons'
'Refrain, for a base branch and an unplanted root... Will never vie in glory with Nizar'
'The fungus of the soft ground cannot withstand... Between the two paths in the smooth deserts'
'And the milk-camel's colt, when tied in a rope... Cannot withstand the assault of the huge aged camels'
'Al-Hidamlah': From sand - according to Abu Ubayda - is what is thin and long. 'Al-Mawa'is': Smooth sands to tread on, singular 'Mi'as'. 'Harrabani': Provoked me/Angered me.

Marran: A place four stages from Mecca towards Basra, within the lands of Banu Tamim bin Murr. The meaning of being a neighbor to it: That he comes towards it, defending and shouting for his honor, taking pride in attributing himself to it, and boasting to people with it! 'Marmus': Buried. There is deletion in the speech; meaning: A neighbor to an owner of a buried grave, deleting the addition, because the grave is not described as buried. 'Al-Ashwas': The arrogant one who looks with one eye out of pride. 'Al-Abba'': One who refuses injustice greatly. 'Al-Qarqara': The level place of earth. 'Al-Bid': Deserts that destroy those who travel them, singular 'Bayda''. 'Al-Labun': The camel having milk. 'Luzza': Tied and bound. 'Al-Qaran': The rope with which a camel or bull is tied. 'Al-Buzl': Aged camels, singular 'Bazil'. The 'Bazil' among camels is like the 'Qarih' among horses. 'Al-Qana'is': Plural of 'Qin'as', which is huge. A parallel to this verse in meaning is the saying of Suhaym bin Wathil ar-Riyahi:
'I excused the aged camels (Al-Buzl) from betting on me... So what is my concern with the two sons of Labun?'

Abu al-Qasim recited this verse:
'We found Nahshal surpassed Fuqaym... Like the surplus of the Ibn Makhad (1-year old camel) over the weaned colt.'
This verse is by Al-Farazdaq. Nahshal and Fuqaym are two tribes. 'Ibn al-Makhad': The one whose mother became pregnant [again], so she is 'Makhad' (pregnant), which is in the second year of his birth. 'Al-Fasil': The one weaned from breastfeeding. There is no great difference between them, so he likened the difference between these two tribes to that. Many grammarians are fond of allowing 'Fadalat' (surpassed) in this verse with opening the Dad or breaking it, because linguists narrated that it is said: 'Fadala' and 'Fadila'. The two dialects are only regarding the 'Fadlah' (remainder/surplus) of a thing. It is said from that: 'Fadala yafdulu' on the pattern of 'Qa'ada yaq'udu', and 'Fadila yafdalu' like 'Sami'a yasma'u', and 'Fadula yafdulu' - with damma on Dad in past and future. 'Fadalat' mentioned in this verse is from their saying: 'Fadaltu ar-rajula fa-fadaltuhu', i.e., I defeated him in merit. The verb from this category - the category of overcoming and rivalry - is only open on the 'Ayn (middle radical), and it is regular in that.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'O many an envier of us, if he sought you ... He would meet distance from you and deprivation'
This verse is by Jarir bin al-Khatafi, and mention of it passed in the Chapter of the Active Participle.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Particles that Install Future Verbs:
'I love black people for her love, to the point... I love black dogs for her love.'
This verse: I do not know its author. The speaker described that since his beloved was black, he loved everything black for her sake, as Ali bin Hisham said - when blamed for loving a black woman:
'The mole is on an ugly face... And it clothes it with saltiness and beauty'
'So how can a lover be blamed for one whom... He sees entirely as a mole in the eye?!'
A contemporary poet has two verses reversing what this first one went to, saying:
'I fell in love with a black woman despite her malice... So a garment of madness settled upon me'
'My love for a black woman (Sawda') is the reverse of her name... Its beginning is evil (Saw'), and the rest is disease (Da')!'

His saying: 'Hatta uhibba': It is possible it is in the interpretation of the past, as Abu al-Qasim said, as if he said: 'Until I loved'. It is possible: That it is a verb of state (Hal) in the time he said the poetry, as if he said: 'I am now in this state', just as it is said: 'So-and-so became sick until they do not hope for him', i.e., until he is now not hoped for. The Lam in his saying 'Li-hubbiha' is attached to 'Uhibbu', and it is the Lam of cause and reason, and it has no grammatical place because it is attached to an apparent word.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of 'Aw' (Or):
'So I said to him: Let your eye not weep, for we only... Attempt a kingdom or die so we are excused.'
This verse is from the famous poetry of Imru' al-Qays, and its fame suffices us from mentioning discussion on it. It is narrated: 'Fa-nu'dhara' - with fatha on Dhal - i.e., people excuse us, and 'Nu'dhira' with kasra on Dhal - i.e., we present an excuse.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of 'Waw':
'Do not forbid a behavior and [then] do the like of it... Disgrace upon you, if you do, is great.'
People differed on the author of this poem. Some narrate it for Al-Akhtal. Some narrate it for Al-Mutawakkil al-Laythi. Some narrate it for Abu al-Aswad ad-Du'ali, which is the most affirmed narration. After it:
'And start with yourself and forbid it from its error... If it desists from it, then you are wise'
'And there, what you say will be heard, and followed... Is the action from you, and teaching will be beneficial!!'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Wearing a woolen cloak while my eye is cool (happy)... Is dearer to me than wearing sheer robes'
This verse is by Maysun bint Bajdal al-Kalbiyyah. Maysun and Bajdal are improvised names. As for Bajdal: I do not know a derivation for it. As for Maysun: It might be derived from 'Masannahu bi-s-sawt masnan', if he hit him, so its Meem is original, its Waw is extra, and its pattern is 'Fay'ul'. It might be derived from 'Masa yamisu' if he strutted, so the derivation of Maysun - for a woman - and Maysan - for the town - would be from one root. The most likely is that it is from 'Masana', because deriving it from 'Masa' requires the Nun in Maysun to be extra, and the Ya original, so its weight would be 'Fa'lun', and 'Sa'nun' and 'Fa'lun' is strange with no parallel known, except their saying: 'Zaytun' (Olive), for a group of grammarians argued for the addition of Nun in it due to the oil (Zayt) pressed from it, and some linguists narrated: 'Ard Zaytiyyah', if it had olives, which necessitates its weight be 'Fay'ul'.
'Al-Aba'ah' and 'Al-Abayah': The cloak/jubbah. 'Ash-Shufuf': Thin clothes through which what is behind is seen. Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan married this Maysun, brought her from the desert, and made her one of his favorites, but she hated him for his old age and senility, so she said this verse. After it:
'Indeed a house in which winds flutter... Is dearer to me than a lofty palace'
'Indeed a dog barking at guests at midnight... Is dearer to me than a friendly cat'
'Indeed a beardless youth from the youth of Banu Kilab... Is dearer to me than a violent sheikh'
So Muawiyah divorced her and said: 'Join your family!'
The estimation of this verse: 'Is dearer to me than wearing sheer robes', without 'happiness of my eye', so she deleted that because the meaning of the speech indicated it.
It is narrated that an old man approached a woman, and she said to him: 'I do not ride a gray horse (Ashhab)!!' An old man wrote to a literate woman proposing to her! - and he was gap-toothed, long-toothed - so she wrote back to him, signing on the back of his letter: 'Fear Allah regarding my blood, O one with the beautiful smile!'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: From the Issues of Fa:
'Did you not ask the empty quarter so it speaks... And does the smooth desert inform you today?'
This verse is by Jamil bin Ma'mar al-Udhri. Jamil, Ma'mar, and Udhrah are all transferred names. Jamil: The beautiful of everything. Al-Jamil: Fat/Grease. Abu Khurash said:
'We meet their hunger with crowned [bowls]... Of huge loaf bread, greased by fat (Al-Jamil)'
'Ar-Ra'ib': Fat/Grease. Al-Ma'mar: The place of habitation. Ma'mar: A specific place name. 'Udhrah' - of a girl: The closing of her vagina before marriage. 'Al-'Udhrah': Forelock hair. Imru' al-Qays said:
'She has locks (Udhar) like the horns of women... Fixed on a day of wind and cold'
'Ar-Rab'': The dwelling where it was. 'Al-Marba'': The dwelling specifically. 'Al-Qawa'': Empty. 'Al-Bayda'': The desert that destroys who travels it. 'As-Samlaq': That which has nothing in it. The meaning of 'Nutq ar-rab'' (speech of the quarter): What is evident from its traces. Arabs call every evidence 'Nutq' (speech) and 'Qawl' (saying). Thus Allah Almighty said: 'This Our Record speaks about you in truth.' From this is Zuhair's saying:
'Is it from Umm Awfa, a trace that did not speak... At Hawmanat ad-Darraj, then Al-Mutathallam?'
i.e., no speech or trace of news appeared from it; due to the age of the dwelling. Like saying: Have you not stood at the gardens and said: Who made your rivers flow, planted your trees, and harvested your fruits?! If they answer you not in dialogue, they answer you in consideration! Abu al-Ala al-Ma'arri went to this meaning saying:
'Do you reckon the full moon is not a speaker... eloquent, and that the sun does not speak?!'
'Indeed, everything that is fleeting has told us... But we are in a world that does not know!'

After Jamil's verse:
'Or it returns the saying: A house, as if... The length of its decay and aging is a parchment'
'I stood at it until my blindness cleared... And the trained Arhabi camel became weary of standing'

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: From the Issues of Idha:
'If Abd al-Aziz returns to me with the like of it... And enables me to have her, then I will not cancel it'
This verse is by Kuthayyir 'Azza al-Khuza'i. Abd al-Aziz - here - is Abd al-Aziz bin Marwan, father of Umar bin Abd al-Aziz. Kuthayyir 'Azza had praised him, and he liked his poetry, so he said: 'Ask your need!' He said: 'Make me in the place of your scribe Ibn Rummanah!' He said: 'Woe to you! That is a scribe, and you are a poet' - and considered him foolish.!

It is said: Rather, he offered him a slave girl to give to him, provided he leave flirting with 'Azza. He refused that, then regretted what he did, and recited his poem saying:
'Indeed the son of Layla uttered to me a saying... And if I had proceeded in it, I would be among those who attain it'
'When I considered matters, and his advice... Appeared, I bid farewell to it and its heavy consequences'
'I wondered at my leaving a plan of rectitude after... Its acceptance appeared to me from Abd al-Aziz'
'And indeed I tame the difficult matters... And on that day, their easy one was possible for me'
'I swore by the Lord of the camels trotting to Mina... Their pace and quick walk traversing the lands'
'If Abd al-Aziz returns to me with the like of it... And enables me to have her, then I will not cancel it'
'So are you, if I return the saying to you once... With better than it, returning and granting it?!'

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: Issues of the Lightened 'An' Installing the Verb:
'So I said to them: Assume [the presence of] two thousand heavily armed men... Their leaders in Persian woven mail'
This verse is by Duraid bin as-Simma. Duraid: A transferred name, possibly from 'Dard' - which is loss of teeth, or diminutive of 'Adrad' by truncation. As-Simma: Transferred name also from 'As-Simma' - meant as the lion - and As-Simma is also: The brave one.
This verse is from a poem mourning his brother: Abdullah. He had raided Ghatafan, took spoils, and returned. When he reached Munqata' al-Liwa, he camped. Duraid said to him: 'This is not a place to camp, for the owners of this spoil will not cease coming to you and seeking you!' Abdullah said to him: 'I will not leave until I prepare food (antaqi'), mix beverage (artasi'), and distribute arrows (divide spoils)!' Duraid could not disobey him, so he ordered a scout (Rabi'ah), who climbed a high ground, and said to him: 'Look and tell us what you see.' He stayed a while, then said: 'I see horses, upon them are men like boys, their spears between the ears of their horses!' Abdullah said: 'This is Fazara, and there is no harm!' Then the scout said: 'I see a people as if their clothes were dipped in red ochre (Ja'b).' Abdullah said: 'This is Ashja', and it is nothing!' 'Al-Ja'b': Red ochre. Then the scout said: 'I see a black people shaking the earth, their mounts are their blackness, dragging the earth with their feet and spears!' Abdullah said: 'This is Abs, and violent death has come! So ride!' The people caught up, and fought a fierce battle. Dhu'ab bin Asma' aimed at Abdullah and stabbed him, so he fell to the ground and called for help from his brother Duraid. Duraid advanced, defended him for a while and drove the horses away, but Duraid was stabbed and felled, Abdullah was killed, his companions defeated, and the spoils recovered. Duraid said - and this day is called Day of Al-Liwa -:
'And I said to Arid and the companions of Arid... And the group of Banu as-Sawda', and the people are witnesses'
'And I said to them: Indeed the allies are all... Sitting at the water of Al-Bulayl, resting'
'And I said to them: Assume [the presence of] two thousand heavily armed men... Their leaders in Persian woven mail'
'So when they disobeyed me, I was one of them, though I see... Their error, or that I am not guided!'
'I commanded them my command at Mun'araj al-Liwa... But they did not recognize the right path until the noon of the next day'
'And am I but of Ghawiyyah; if it errs... I err, and if Ghawiyyah is guided, I am guided'

'Al-Mudajjaj': Heavily armed. It is said with kasra on Jim and fatha. Some linguists differentiated: Mudajjij (kasra) is the knight, Mudajjaj (fatha) is the horse; because they used to armor horses. He meant by 'Farisi': Armor made in Persia. 'Al-Musarrad': Woven with rings. 'Saratuhum': Their nobles, singular 'Sari'. It seems to be the plural of 'Sarin', because it is said 'Sara ar-rajulu yasri wa yasru' if he became noble. The active participle of 'Sara' is 'Sarin', as 'Ghaza' is 'Ghazin'. The active participle of 'Saruwa Yasru' is 'Sariyy', like 'Zharufa' is 'Zharif'. The poet said:
'You meet the noble (Sariyy) of men when he travels... And the son of the noble when he travels, his night travel'
The analogy was to say: 'Suratuhum' - with damma on Sin - as 'Qudah' and 'Ghuzah'. 'Fa'il' is not pluralized as 'Fa'lah' with open Fa, except what is sound like 'Kafir/Kafarah', or weak-eyed like 'Kha'in/Khawanah', 'Ha'ik/Hawakah', 'Ha'iz/Hawazah'. But they treated the weak-lam like the weak-ayn due to their agreement in vowel change. It is narrated: 'Surah' - with damma on Sin.

It is permissible that 'Sarah' is the plural of 'Sariyy', and it was allowed to break 'Fa'il' into 'Fa'lah': because 'Fa'il' and 'Fa'il' share one meaning; it is said 'Alim' and 'Alim', 'Qadir' and 'Qadir'; so they shared in their plural as they shared in their singular, as they said 'Alim/Ulama'' and 'Sha'ir/Shu'ara''. The category of 'Fa'la'' in plural is indeed 'Fa'il', like 'Hakim/Hukama'' and 'Basir/Busara''. It is said: 'Sarah' is a collective noun (Ism Jam'). The proponent of this argued with their saying: 'Sarawatuhum qisar' (Their backs are short), like 'Qatah/Qatawat'. The argument of those who went to the first view: The plural may be pluralized.
The Ba in 'Bi-alfay mudajjaj' attaches to 'Zhannu', so it has no grammatical place as it attaches to an apparent word. As for the Ba in 'Bi-l-Farisi'; if you believe 'Saratuhum' is a subject (Mubtada) and 'Bi-l-Farisi' is its predicate, the Ba attaches to a deleted element and has a place, as if he said: 'Their leaders are armored with the woven Persian'. If you believe 'Saratuhum' is raised by 'Mudajjaj', the Ba attaches to 'Mudajjaj', and has no grammatical place as it attaches to an apparent word. Whoever believes this raises 'Saratuhum' as the object whose agent is not named (passive subject) if opening the Jim, and as the agent (subject) if breaking the Jim, as if he said: 'With two thousand Persian [armored], and their noses were armored with the Persian', deleting the object as An-Nabigha al-Ja'di said:
'Until we caught up to them, our horsemen make run (Tu'di)... As if we were the spur of a hill raising the mirage'
He meant: Our horsemen make the horses run. This has been mentioned before.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Verbs of Appropinquation (Af'al al-Muqarabah):
'Perhaps the distress I have ended up in... Behind it will be a near relief'
This verse is by Hudba bin al-Khashram al-Udhri. Hudba and Khashram are both transferred names. As for Hudba: It is from 'Hudb' of a garment, or 'Hudb' of the Arta tree, which is its leaves. The common term for Arta is to say: 'Hudbah' and 'Hudb', like 'Shajarah' and 'Shajar'. However, Ibn Jinni narrated it is said: 'Hudb' on the pattern of 'Hudb' of a garment. Al-Khashram: A group of bees, having no singular from its wording. Ibn Jinni recited for Ash-Shanfara:
'When the sent bees (Khashram) urged their swarm... Buzzing ones, thrown down by a honey-gatherer'
Hudba recited this poetry while imprisoned in Medina. The reason was: An altercation occurred between him and a man from his cousins: Ziyad bin Zayd, so Hudba killed him. His brother Abd al-Rahman took him to Muawiyah. Muawiyah questioned him. He said: 'If you wish I answer you in prose, and if you wish I answer you in verse.' Muawiyah said: 'Rather in verse, for it is more enjoyable!' So he recited a poem saying:
'We shot and shot back, so our arrow encountered... Deaths of men in a book and in a decree'
'And you are the Commander of the Faithful, so we have... No turning away from you nor falling short'
'If it [the blood money] is in our wealth, we are not distressed by it... An arm's length, and if it is patience [execution], we are patient for patience'
Muawiyah said: 'I see you have confessed to killing their companion!' He said: 'It is what you heard!' Muawiyah offered Abd al-Rahman the blood money to accept it, and the elders of Quraysh offered him seven blood monies, but he refused to accept! The killed Ziyad had a son named Al-Miswar who had not reached puberty. Muawiyah said: 'His son is more entitled to seek his blood, so let Hudba be imprisoned until his son comes of age, perhaps he will accept the blood money.' He was imprisoned for seven years until Al-Miswar reached puberty. The blood money was offered to him, but he refused anything but killing Hudba! A man from his relatives named Abu Numayr visited Hudba during his detention and showed sorrow for his state. Hudba said:
'The depression of Abu Numayr keeps me awake... And my heart is depressed from his depression'
'So I said to him: May Allah guide you, gently... And the best speech is the possessor of the correct mind!'
'So a fearful one may become safe, and a captive released... And the strange man may come to his family'
'For we have settled in a house of tribulation... The fates will strike us or afflict [us]'
'Oh would that the winds were subjected... For our need, coming early or returning'
It is narrated: 'Amsayta' (You ended up) with fatha on Ta addressing Abu Numayr, and 'Amsaytu' (I ended up) with damma on Ta reporting about himself. 'Kana' in this verse is complete (Tammah), having no predicate, because it means: occurs and happens. Most say: He deleted 'An' from the predicate of 'Asa' likening it to 'Kada'. My opinion is better: That 'Asa' was likened to 'La'alla' (Perhaps); because each is hope and expectation, just as they sometimes insert 'An' in the predicate of 'La'alla' likening it to 'Asa', as Mutammim bin Nuwayra said:

'Perhaps you, one day, a calamity will befall... Of those that leave you with a cut nose'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'It almost, from the length of decay, became effaced'
This verse is attributed to Ru'ba bin al-Ajjaj, but I did not find it in Ru'ba's poetry. Ru'ba: Transferred name, having eleven meanings which I mentioned in the book 'Al-Iqtidab' and 'Al-Muthallath'. Al-Ajjaj: Transferred name; because Al-Ajjaj is the stirrer of dust (Ajaj). It is said: Al-Ajjaj is for the one who cries out a lot (Ajij). It is said he was named Al-Ajjaj for his saying:
'Until whoever cried out (Aj'aja) cries out at it'
'Yamsaha': Its traces are obliterated. Describes a dwelling that decayed until almost no trace was visible.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: The Object Carried on Meaning:
'Like hedgehogs, shuffling, [their shame] has reached... Najran, or their disgraceful deeds reached Hajar'
This verse is by Al-Akhtal. His name is Ghiyath bin Ghawth, according to Ibn Qutayba. Others mentioned his name is Ghuwayth bin Ghawth. These are transferred names. His Kunya is Abu Malik, also transferred; because Abu Malik is the Kunya of hunger, old age, and the elder. The poet said:
'A miserable companion is a decrepit elder... Umm Ubayd, and Abu Malik'
Umm Ubayd: Kunya of the desert. Another said:
'O Abu Malik, the beautiful women have abandoned me... O Abu Malik, I think you are diligent [in pursuing me]'
Al-Akhtal: Name transferred from their saying: 'Rajulun Akhtal', if he has long ears, or is foul-mouthed. It is said he was nicknamed so because the two sons of Ju'ayl and their mother disputed and sought his judgment, so he said:
'By your life, I, and the two sons of Ju'ayl... And their mother, are surely low bottoms'
They said to him: 'You are indeed Akhtal (foul/long-eared)', so it stuck to him! This verse is from a poem mocking Jarir, saying before this verse:
'As for Kulayb bin Yarbu', they have no... Entering or leaving when boasting'
'Left behind, and people pass their affair... While they are absent and in blindness of what they perceived'
He likened them to hedgehogs for their walking at night for theft and debauchery, as hedgehogs walk. The hedgehog is proverbial for night travel. It is said: 'He travels by night more than a hedgehog', and 'more than Anqad' - which is the hedgehog. 'Haddajun': Shufflers/Walkers. It is said 'Hadaja yahdiju' if he hurried. The source: 'Hadaj' and 'Hadajan'. Al-Ajjaj said describing the male ostrich:
'And his traces were replaced by a swift one... Knock-kneed, shaking, never ceasing to shuffle'
i.e., frightened. 'As-Saw'at': Ugly deeds. Najran and Hajar: Towns. The norm was to raise 'As-Saw'at' (Subject) because they reach the towns, towns do not reach them. He inverted it out of necessity when the meaning was understood. The apparent meaning of Abu al-Qasim's words is that he considered the necessity only in 'Hajar', because he said: 'So he inverted, because the disgrace reaches Hajar, so he installed it and raised Hajar.' Abu al-Abbas al-Mubarrad recited it raising both Najran and Hajar, saying: Make the two verbs for the two towns by expansion - and this is the correct view!

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'The morning a stab by Husayn permitted for Ibn Asram... The fat fresh meats and the wine'
This verse is by Al-Farazdaq. 'Al-Abit': Fresh meat. 'As-Sada'if': Fat of the hump etc., dominated by fat. Husayn bin Asram had a relative killed, so he forbade himself wine and fresh meat until he killed his killer. When he stabbed and killed him, wine and meat became lawful for him. It should have been raised (permitted *by* the stab), and install 'Al-Abitat' and 'Al-Khamr' (permitted *the* meats/wine). But the poem has nominative rhymes, so he was forced to invert the speech. Al-Farazdaq said regarding this:
'And [horses] watered in the evening before the family, as if... They were locusts when dawn cleared the panic'
'Roaming, never ceasing under their bellies... Are shirts of heroes whose gores are red'
'They left the son of Dhu al-Jaddayn hiccuping, propped up... And he has no grave but his oleander tree'
'And they at Sarhaf caught up with Daliq... Umara of Abs, after the afternoon waned'
'And they, upon the cheeks of Shutayr bin Khalid... Raised dust from their hooves, dark'
'The morning a stab by Husayn permitted for Ibn Asram... The fat fresh meats and the wine'

He meant by 'Maghbuqa': Horses whose owners prefer them over their families, feeding them the 'Ghabuq' (evening drink) of milk etc. He meant by 'Ibn Dhu al-Jaddayn': Bistam bin Qays ash-Shaybani. Asim bin Khalifa ad-Dabbi killed him, and he fell on the 'Ala'ah' (oleander/rock), which is a small rock. Therefore Ibn Ghanma ad-Dabbi said:
'He fell on the Ala'ah, not pillowed... As if his forehead was a polished sword'
'Yanshiju': Blood coming out of his wound making a sound. 'Al-Musnad': One who nurses him and is gentle with his condition, checking for life. 'Daliq': Umara bin al-Wahhab al-Absi, nicknamed Daliq for his many raids. He killed him at Sarhaf ad-Dabbi.
It is narrated that Yunus bin Habib met Al-Kisa'i and said: 'O Abu al-Hasan, how do you narrate Al-Farazdaq's verse: "Ghadat uhillat li-ibn Asrama ta'natu... Husaynin 'abitat as-sada'ifi wa al-khamr"?' He said: 'I raise "At-Ta'natu" according to analogy, install "Al-Abitat", and cut "Al-Khamru" (start new sentence) carrying it on the meaning: as if he said: "And wine became lawful for him."' Yunus said: 'How excellent is what you said, but Al-Farazdaq recited it to me inverted!'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'And the bite of time, O Ibn Marwan, has not left... Of wealth except what is eradicated (Mushatan) or stripped away (Mujallafu)'
This verse is by Al-Farazdaq, praising Abd al-Malik bin Marwan and mocking Jarir. Before it:
'To you, O Commander of the Faithful, the concerns of hopes... And the trackless desert traveled without guidance have thrown us'
'Al-Hawjal': The desert with no landmarks to guide. Abu at-Tayyib al-Mutanabbi went to this meaning saying:
'Deserts, neighing horses, spearheads... Slim spears, threats and intimidation'
'Al-Muta'assaf': Traveled without a guide. 'Al-'Add' and 'Al-'Att': Severity of time. 'Al-Mushat': Eradicated, with no remainder. 'Al-Mujallaf': Whose majority is gone, leaving a little. In this verse are three narrations, all necessities:
1. Opening Ya and Dal of 'Yada'' (Yada'a - leave), installing 'Mushatan'.
2. Opening Ya, breaking Dal, raising 'Mushatun'.
3. Damma on Ya, opening Dal, raising 'Mushatun'.
Regarding the first narration - mentioned by Abu al-Qasim, the famous one - there are four opinions:
1. 'Mujallafu' is raised by a hidden verb indicated by 'Lam yada'' (did not leave), as if saying: 'Or remained stripped'.
2. Al-Farra's view: 'Mujallafu' is a subject whose predicate is deleted: 'Or stripped is likewise'.
3. Hisham from Al-Kisa'i: Coordinate it with the pronoun in 'Mushatan'.
4. Found in Abu Ali al-Farisi's speech: Coordinated with 'Al-'Add'. He says it is a source in the form of a passive participle, as Allah says: 'And We tore them every tearing (Mumazzaq)', as if saying: 'And the bite of time, or stripping'.
Regarding the narration breaking the Dal of 'Yada'' and raising 'Mushatun': He made it from 'Wada'a' (stayed/remained) in his house, so he is 'Wadi'', and raised 'Mushatun' with it. There is deletion: 'Because of it/its cause'.
Whoever narrates opening Dal and damma on Ya - passive voice - raises 'Mushatun' also, as the deputy subject. He should have said 'Lam yuda'', but deleted the Waw as deleted from 'Yada''. We discussed this verse more in the first book.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'The snakes made peace with his foot... The viper (Uf'uwan) and the brave large snake (Shuja')'
'And the one with two horns, silent, aged'
This Rajaz is by Musawir al-Absi. After it:
'They murmured at his two legs when he slept... Then they went early and he became safe'
Musawir: Transferred name, active participle of 'Sawarahu' if he leaped on him. He mocked a man for the thickness and hardness of his feet due to walking barefoot long; mentioning he treads on snakes and scorpions killing them, so they made peace with his feet for that! The analogy was to raise 'Al-Uf'uwan' and what follows as a substitute (Badal) for 'Al-Hayyat' (snakes). However, he carried it on a hidden verb indicated by 'Salama' (made peace); because making peace involves two or more. If you say 'Zayd made peace with Amr', it is known Amr made peace with him. As if he said: 'And the foot made peace with the viper'.
'Al-Uf'uwan': Male viper. 'Ash-Shuja'': Male snake. Amr bin Sha's al-Asadi said:
'He lowered his head like the lowering of the snake, and if... The snake saw a path for his fangs, he would bite'

'Ash-Shaj'am': The bold one. Or the long one (more likely derivation). 'Dhat qarnayn': The scorpion. 'Damuz': Silent/No sound. 'Dirzim' (kasra on Dad and Zay): Aged (more malicious poison). Al-Farra' narrated: 'Qad salamat al-hayyata' installing 'Al-Hayyat' as object, making 'Al-Qadam' the subject. He said he meant 'Al-Qadaman' (two feet) but deleted the dual Nun out of necessity, as Imru' al-Qays said:
'She has two flesh-ridges (Matnatan) firm (Khazhata), as... The leopard crouched on its forearms'
He meant 'Khazhatan'. Evidence is Abu Du'ad al-Iyadi's saying:
'And two flesh-ridges firm (Khazhatan)... Like the slope of a hill'
He substituted 'Al-Uf'uwan' and what follows for 'Al-Hayyat'. 'Hamhamna': Made sounds. 'Hamhamah': Hidden confusing sound. 'Hawwama': Slept.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Jussive (Jazm):
'When you come to him, seeking the light of his fire... You find the best fire, at which is the best kindler'
This verse is by Al-Hutay'a - name mentioned previously - praising Baghid bin Ammar bin Shammas bin Lu'ay. Before it:
'You visit a man who gives his wealth for praise... And whoever gives the prices of praises is praised'
'He sees stinginess not leaving wealth for a man... And knows that man is not immortal'
'An earner and a spender; if you ask him... He beams and shakes like the shaking of Indian swords'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Indeed, whoever enters the church one day... Will meet (Yalqa) therein wild calves and gazelles'
This verse is by Al-Akhtal. He was Christian, hence mentioning the church. 'Ja'adhir': Calves of wild cows, singular 'Ju'dhar' (damma or fatha on Dhal). Basrans don't recognize opening Dhal because 'Fa'lal' is unused for them. Kufans narrated many words on 'Fa'lal': 'Ju'dhar', 'Burqa'', 'Tuhlab', 'Difda'', 'Jakhdab'. He says: Whoever enters the church sees among Christian women those resembling wild calves and gazelles!!

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'And whatever nature a man possesses... Even if he thinks it hidden from people, it will be known (Tu'lami)'
This verse is from the famous poetry of Zuhair bin Abi Sulma. 'Al-Khaliqah': Nature. 'Khalaha': Thought/reckoned it. This poetry parallels Salim bin Wabisa:
'O you who adorn yourself with other than your feature... Indeed affectation, true nature comes beneath it'
'Min khaliqatin': In the place of Raf' (nominative) by 'Kana'. 'Min' is extra, not attached to anything. 'Wa in khalaha': i.e., Even if he thought it. 'In' is conditional with no answer; because 'Mahma' and its condition/answer sufficed. Parallel in hanging one condition on another is Imru' al-Qays:
'And I was certain that if I met him, his day... At Dhu ar-Rimth - if I missed him - was a day of souls (death)'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'When you come to the Messenger, say to him:... A truth upon you when the assembly is at ease'
This verse is by Al-Abbas bin Mirdas as-Sulami. Al-Abbas: Transferred from the man who frowns much (Abus). Mirdas: Transferred; 'Mirdas' is the stone, 'Mirdas' is what is thrown/crashed with, or thrown in a well to determine water. Al-Ajjaj said:
'He sheaths the enemies with a crushing head (Mirdasa)'
He meant by Messenger: The Prophet (PBUH). Narrated: 'Imma atayta'. After it:
'O best of who rode mounts and who walked... Upon the dust when souls are counted'
'Through you the tyrant submitted and followed guidance... And through you the intense dark darkness cleared from us'
'Idha ma atayta': Addressing a man mentioned before:
'O man who is carried by... A thick-cheeked, hard-hoofed, strong she-camel'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'So you have become such that however you approach it, you get entangled in it... Both its riding places are crooked (Shajir) under your legs'
This verse is by Labid bin Rabi'ah al-Amiri. Kunya: Abu Aqil. 'Al-Labid': Sack. 'Ar-Rabi'ah': Iron helmet.

This poem addresses his uncle Amir, 'Mula'ib al-Asinna'. Labid had a neighbor from Banu Abd al-Qays who sought refuge with him. His uncle struck him with a sword. Labid got angry, enumerating his services to his uncle, threatening him, and denouncing his action against his neighbor! Then he said:
'To me belongs victory among you and loyalty over you... And I was not a truffle grown by soft lands'
'And you are poor, you will not be exchanged for a successor... Other than me, and your younger sons have not reached [maturity]'
'So I said: Restrain the sides of your recklessness and know... That if you advance your leg, you stumble'
'And indeed the humiliation of a neighbor by a neighbor is painful... And a calamity to which calamities flock'
'So you have become such that however you approach it, you get entangled in it... Both its riding places are crooked under your legs'
'If you advance, you encounter a front part of it... Thick, and if you delay, the rear is sinful (difficult)'
'Tashtajiru': Entangle/Confuse. Narrated: 'Taltabisu'. 'Shajir': Entangled. Narrated: 'Rijlaka' and 'Rahlaka'. 'Ar-Rahl' for camel is like 'Sarj' for horse. 'Al-Kifl': Cloth wound behind the saddle for the pillion rider. It is said: 'Arhaltu al-ba'ir wa akfaltuhu' - put saddle and Kifl on it. These are the two riding places mentioned. Meaning: He tells his uncle: You have embarked on a matter from which there is no escape. You are like one riding a difficult she-camel, unable to dismount safely because his legs are entangled in the stirrups. He cannot stabilize on either seat; if he rides the back (Kifl), he finds it hard; if the front (Rahl), it leans and throws him! 'Ash-Shajir': Leaning, not straight. Arabs liken engaging in grave matters to riding difficult mounts. They say: 'You rode a great matter from me', 'You rode a difficult mount', 'So-and-so is a rider of calamities'. Al-Asha said:
'If the causes of severance become serious between us... You will depart from me on the back of a porcupine (Shayham)'
Al-Akhtal said:
'Qays bin Aylan has made our war... Upon a dry backbone, humped of back'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'If our swords fall short, their connection is... Our steps towards our enemies, so we strike'
This verse is by Qays bin al-Khatim. We mentioned his and his father's name previously. From a poem mentioning the Day of Bu'ath. After it:
'And the Day of Bu'ath, our swords handed it... To a lineage in the root of Ghassan, dominant'
'They unsheathe white [swords] when we meet our enemy... And sheathe red ones, thin of blades'
Narrated: 'Ila a'da'ina' by convergence (Taqarub), no witness in this narration. Narrated: 'Wa in qasurat... fa-nudharibu' (Raf') by Ijwa' (rhyme flaw). 'Khuta': Plural of 'Khutwah' (distance between feet). 'Khatwah' (fatha): The action/source (Al-Farra'). Others: Synonymous. Parallel to Abu Qays bin al-Aslat:
'And the sword, if a maker shortened it... My arm span lengthened it on the day of meeting!'
The witness: Coordinating 'Fa-nudhariba' on the place of 'Kana' because it is jussive in place (Condition response). As if: 'Nakun fa-nudhariba'. Like: 'Fa-assaddaqa wa akun...'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: What Declines (Triptote) and What Does Not:
'Da'd did not wrap herself with the surplus of her waist-wrapper... And Da'd was not given drink in rough leather bowls (Al-'Ulab)'
This verse is by Jarir bin al-Khatafi. Narrated: Ibn ar-Ruqayyat. Nicknamed Ar-Ruqayyat for saying: 'Ruqayya, no Ruqayya, O man!'. 'At-Talaffu'': Wrapping with garment. 'Al-'Ulab': Leather bowls for milking/drinking. Narrated: 'Fi al-'ulab'. 'Fi' fits here (milk *in* bowls). If narrated so, it has a grammatical place (State/Hal). If 'Bi-l-'ulab', no place (attached to apparent).

The Ba in 'Bi-fadli' attaches to 'Tatalaffa'', no place either. Meaning: Praising Da'd; not a Bedouin wrapping in sheets and drinking from leather bowls, but a city woman raised in luxury, wearing fine clothes, drinking from expensive vessels, living in comfort! Narrated: 'Wa lam tusqa'. 'Da'd' (first): Allowed triptote/diptote. Second: Only triptote to avoid breaking meter. Repetition of Da'd is for fame and enjoyment of the name. As the other said:
'Sweet on the mouths are those whom no enemy tasted... And on the mouths, their names are sweet'
Abu at-Tayyib al-Mutanabbi clarified this praising Adud ad-Dawla:
'Abu Shuja' of Fars, Supporter of the State... Fanna Khusra, and Shahanshah'
'Names that did not increase him in recognition... But only in pleasure we mentioned them'
Ibn ar-Ruqayyat's verse contradicts the other:
'By my life, a Bedouin woman with a cloak... Dwelling in sands of Suwayqa or Fard'
'Is dearer to the heart insistent on passion... Than the wearers of silk, showing ingratitude'

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: Names of Tribes, Neighborhoods, Towns, and Chapters:
'If Sadus is stingy with its two dirhams... Then indeed the wind is good, blowing from the east (Qabul)'
This verse is by Al-Akhtal. Name mentioned. Sadus: Tribe of Banu Shayban (open Sin). Tribe of Tayy (damma Sin - Kalbi). Dispute between Sibawayh and Mubarrad discussed in Book 1. 'Al-Qabul': East wind. Narrated: 'Shamul' (North wind). 'Shamal' patterns: 'Qadhal', 'Ma'l' position, 'Fals', 'Asad', 'Shumul'. Imru' al-Qays:
'So Tudih then Al-Miqrat, its trace not effaced... By what south and north winds wove'
Al-Ba'ith al-Mujashi'i:
'Ruins of a dung-heap excited longing in you... At Nasifat al-Khuwayn or Janib al-Hajal'
'Eternity came between the newness of its era... And every gusting north wind dragged [dust] on it'
'Malik stayed in enemy lands... North winds blow on him'

Specific mention of 'Two Dirhams': Some thought it meant plural. Incorrect. It has a specific meaning. Al-Akhtal came to Al-Ghadban bin al-Qaba'thari ash-Shaybani in Kufa after the Bakr-Taghlib strife ended, asking for contribution (Hamalah). Al-Ghadban said: 'If you wish, I give you two thousand. If you wish, two dirhams?' Al-Akhtal: 'What about them?' Al-Ghadban: 'If two thousand, only few give. If two dirhams, every Kisra (Persian/Rich) in Kufa will give, and I write to our brothers for the same.' Al-Akhtal: 'Two dirhams is better!' He imposed two dirhams on every Bakri in Kufa. Then wrote to Suwayd bin Manjuf as-Sadusi in Basra (Leader of Sadus): 'Abu Malik came for Hamalah. I imposed two dirhams on Kufa Bakris. Do same for Sadus.' Al-Akhtal came to Basra, stayed with As-Salt bin Hurayth al-Hanafi, then went to Suwayd. Suwayd gathered Sadus: 'This is Abu Malik asking help. He is the one who said:
'If I say I made peace with Bakr... Grudges refuse, not the distant lineage'
'And spiller of blood with striking swords... Incidents perish but they do not perish'
'They are two brothers warming at a fire... The cloak of death between them is new'
'The milk-camel's colt lifts its tail if it sees me... And the huge lion of the highland fears me'
'My hands did not wound Banu Sulaym... Nor my poetry, so Ash-Sharid would mock me'

'And were it not that I roughen the chest of Ma'n... And Utbah, the poem would have spread in the Sacred Precinct'
Banu Sadus said: 'By Allah, we will not give him a dirham after what he said!' Al-Akhtal said:
'If Sadus is stingy with its two dirhams... Then indeed the wind is good, blowing from the east'
'The sons of co-wives among them abandoned me... And a ghoul destroyed Malik and Yazid'
'The two stallions of Wa'il perished together... As if the earth after them is barren'
'So what do I seek from them after... When all of them are brothers of darkness (Daghlas), stingy'
He mocked Suwayd (who was ugly, ignored): 
'And a trunk of evil whose inside the weevil destroyed... When Wa'il burdened him, he was not capable'
Suwayd said: 'Abu Malik wanted to mock me but praised me, making Wa'il burden me with its affairs, while I had no hope in Taghlib, let alone Bakr bin Wa'il.'
'For indeed the wind is good...': A proverb for independence. 'Wind blows': Success/Power. 'Wind still': Loss of power. Quran: 'And your wind (power) departs'. Poet: 
'If your winds blow, seize them... For the consequence of every storm is calm'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'The silk wept because of Rawh and denied his skin... And the embroidered cloaks cried out a loud cry because of Judham'
This verse is by Hind bint an-Nu'man bin Bashir al-Ansari, mocking her husband Rawh bin Zinba' al-Judhami. After it:
'And the Aba (cloak) said: I was for a time your clothing... And slit garments and velvet'
'Al-'Ajij': Loud crying for help. 'Al-Matarif': Silk cloaks with borders (singular Mitraf). 'Al-'Aba': Known cloaks. 'Al-Madrujah': Slit/Torn (singular Aba'ah/Abayah). 'Al-Qata'if': Woolen clothes. She says: Rawh and his tribe were not fit for silk, being Bedouins wearing torn cloaks and velvet. Rawh ennobled them without ancient lineage. Rawh was Abd al-Malik's wazir. Parallel: Mudrik al-Faq'asi:
'Abs resembles Hashim if it clothed itself... In shirts of silk which their skins denied'
Narrated: 'Kurdish cloaks'. Rawh replied:
'Hind refused but to be humiliated... And she had a companion from us compatible'
'If we reward her with humiliation, she is worthy... And if we love her, she loves the base scoundrels'
Hind: Transferred or Improvised? Some say improvised from 'Handathu al-mar'ah' (she enslaved him with love). Appears transferred (used for other than humans). 'Hind' = 100 camels. 'Hind' = India. 'Hind' = Name of calamity. Ibn al-A'rabi:
'You are not a land of protection... But you are the Hind of the severe ones (calamity)'
Bashir: Transferred (Announcer). An-Nu'man: Name of blood. Or related to Nu'man bin al-Mundhir (Anemones). Rawh: Transferred from 'Rawh' (Rest/Mercy). Zinba': Heavy person. Story: Man asked Abu Ubayda about 'Zanba'ah'. He said 'Heaviness'. Man fled because Abu Ubayda called his companion Zinba'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Of them are days of truth (strength) you were known by... The days of Wasit and the days of Hajar'

This verse has two errors: 1. Attributed to Al-Akhtal, but is Al-Farazdaq's (mourning Abdullah bin Ma'mar). 2. Recited 'Urifta' (damma on Ta), but is 'Urifta' (fatha) addressing him. Before it:
'As for Quraysh and its highest, they were afflicted... In Syria when the hearing and sight separated from you'
'How many a coward I approached war with... On the day of meeting, and were it not for you, he wouldn't have been patient'
'Sidq' here means Strength/Hardship. 'Rajul Sidq' (Strong man).

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: The Changed Form 'Fa'ali':
'And excellent is the filling of the armor, you are, when... "Dismount!" (Nazali) is called out and terror is plunged into'
This verse is by Zuhair bin Abi Sulma. 'Hashw ad-Dir'': Filling of the armor (wearer). 'Lujja': Persisted/Plunged. 'Adh-Dhu'r': Terror. 'Anta': Predicate of hidden subject 'Huwa'. Ugly to be Subject with 'Ni'ma...' as predicate due to Lam entering 'Ni'ma' (Lam enters Subject). But predicate being a sentence eases it ('Zaydun la-huwa qa'imun'). If single ('Zaydun la-qa'imun'), difficult. Az-Zajjaj allowed 'Inna hadhani la-sahirani' as 'Hadhani' subject, 'La-[huma]-sahirani' predicate.
'Idha': Adverb, operator is the meaning of praise in 'Ni'ma'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'We divided our two plans between us... So I carried "Barrah" (piety/loyalty), and you bore "Fajar" (treachery)'
This verse is by An-Nabigha, addressing Zar'ah bin Amr al-Fazari. 'Fajar': Treachery. Named like 'Hizam' (female name). Proofs: 1. 'Fa'ali' indicates feminine gender ('Du'iyat Nazali'). Zayd al-Khayl:
'Salama knew that my sword... Is hateful whenever "Nazali" is called'
Another:
'Death (Halaqi) caught up to them at their rear...'
2. Nabigha named loyalty 'Barrah' (feminine) and treachery 'Fajarah'. 'Ihtamalta': Increased form (Ifta'ala) for 'Fajar' (treachery). Arabs use 'Fa'ala' for few/many, 'Ifta'ala' for many specifically. He mocked Zar'ah for excessive treachery. If he said 'Hamalta Fajar', could be once. Quran: 'Laha ma kasabat (good - easy) wa 'alayha ma iktasabat (evil - hard/accumulated)'. Good is rewarded for little/much. Evil only for great sins (accumulated). This applies to verbs used with/without Ta. Verbs only with Ta ('Istawaytu', 'Iktaraytu') don't imply 'many' specifically.

Saying 'Ihtamalta Fajar' implies 'Ifta'ala' is for evil is wrong. Example: 'Istawaytu', 'Iktaraytu', 'Irtawaytu' (neutral/good). Quran: 'Ar-Rahman 'ala al-'arsh istawa'. Poet: 'Qad istawa bishrun...'. Claims that 'Ifta'ala' is strictly for evil are invalid ('Iktasaba', 'Iqtadara'). It indicates exaggeration/thoroughness.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'So I said: Stay until ease [wealth] comes... She said: A year and the next?!'
Unknown author. Companion asked to Hajj. He said: Wait till wealth comes. She asked: Wait this year and next? 'Ma'an': Hal (State) or Adverb. 'A-'aman': Hamza of denial.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Exception:
'And I do not see a doer among people resembling him... Nor do I exclude (Uhashi) from the peoples anyone'
This verse is by An-Nabigha adh-Dhubyani. 'Yushbihuhu': Sentence in place of Nasb (Adjective for Fa'il). 'An-Nas': Second object of 'Ara'. 'Min' (first) attached to 'Uhashi'. 'Min' (second) extra for emphasis. Witness: 'Uhashi' behaves as a verb (conjugated), unlike particles.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Preposed Exception:
'And I have no faction (Shi'ah) except the family of Ahmad... And I have no path except the path of Truth'
This verse is by Al-Kumayt bin Zayd al-Asadi. Kunya: Abu al-Mustahill. Deaf. Shi'a. Praising Banu Hashim. 'Shi'ah': Supporters. 'Mash'ab': Path. Story: Kumayt recited to Al-Farazdaq. Al-Farazdaq: 'Recite.' Kumayt: 'I rejoiced, and not for white women do I rejoice...'. Farazdaq: 'What excites you?' Kumayt: 'Not a house... not a tooth...'. Farazdaq: 'What then?' Kumayt: 'Not bird augury...'. Farazdaq: 'Stop looking!' Kumayt: 'But to the people of virtues...'.

Farazdaq: 'Who are they?' Kumayt: 'To the white group through whose love... we draw near to Allah'. Farazdaq: 'Relieve me, who?' Kumayt:
'Banu Hashim: The folk of the Prophet, for I am... With them and for them I am pleased and angry repeatedly'
'I lowered the wing of my affection to them... To a shelter whose sides are family and welcome'
'By which book or which Sunnah... Do you see loving them as a shame on me and reckon it?'
'And I have no faction except the family of Ahmad... And I have no path except the path of Truth'
'And who other than them would I be pleased with as a faction... And who other than them from whom I hope and fear?'
'Ignorant people shame me for loving them... While some of them are closer to shame and more ruined'
'They point with hands at me saying... Lo, he failed, and the pointers are bigger failures!'
'A group called me disbeliever for loving them... And a group said: A sinner and guilty!'
'The Takfir of those did not harm me... Nor the faulting of those, for it is more faulty'
'I remain among them where they accuse me... And I remain turning among their factions'
'Do you not see me in the love of the family of Muhammad... Going and coming, fearful, watching?'
'People through whom Quraysh became mighty... And in them is the extended gift of noble deeds'
Farazdaq: 'O nephew, spread this! You are the most poetic of past and remaining!'

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'And I have no Lord except Allah, no Lord other than Him... And I have no helper except Allah, other than You'
By Al-Kumayt. First half no witness (Allah raised as Subject). Second half: 'Ghayraka' (acc) and 'Nasiru' (nom). 'Ghayraka': Exception or Hal. 'Illa Allah': Hal (if presented). Al-Farazdaq: 'Fa-asbahu... idh ma mithlahum basharu'.
Discussion on 'Illa Zaydan ahadun' (Hal). Requires noun to be descriptive/verb-like. 'Illa' + Noun = Description -> Hal.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Disconnected Exception (Munqati'):
'I stood in it a short evening (Usaylanan) asking it... It was incapable of an answer, and there was no one in the quarter'
'Except stable markers (Awariya) of hard ground (Liyan), I do not clarify them... And the trench (Nu'y) like the cistern in the rocky ground (Jalad) wronged [by digging]'
These two verses: By An-Nabigha adh-Dhubyani. 'Usaylan': Diminutive of 'Asil' (evening), irregular (based on plural 'Aslan'). Narrated: 'Usaylalan'. Narrated: 'Usaylan'. 'Jawaban': Accusative. 1. Deletion of preposition ('Bi-jawabin'). 2. Dropping of preposition causes Nasb (Kufan). Basrans reject (some nouns raise after drop). 3. Tamyiz transferred from Subject ('Ayiya jawabuha' -> 'Ayyat jawaban'). Like 'Tfaqqa'a Zaydun shahman'.
'Usa'iluha': Hal (state). From 'Tu' of 'Waqaftu' (subject) or 'Ha' of 'Fiha' (object). Allowed because of pronouns returning to both. 'Ayyat jawaban': Sentence no place. 'Wa ma bi-r-rab'i min ahadin': Sentence no place or Hal. 'Min': Extra. 'Ahad': Genitive in word, Nominative in meaning.
'Illa Awariya': Accusative (Exception) or Nominative (Badal for 'Min ahadin'). Kisa'i allowed Genitive (Badal for 'Ahadin' word). Basrans reject (Min only extra in negative). 'Al-La'y': Hardship/Intensity. 'Ma ubayyinuha': 'Ma' negative or extra ('La'yan ubayyinuha'). 'An-Nu'yu': Nominative or Accusative. 'Nu'y': Barrier against water.

'Al-Mazhluma': Land dug where no digging existed. Or reached by flood. Or rained out of season. Al-Huwaydirah: 'Zhalama al-bitaha biha...'. Here: Dug land. 'Al-Jalad': Hard ground. 'Ka-l-hawdi': Hal (if Nu'y raised/installed). 'Bi-l-mazhlumati': Hal from 'Hawd'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Negation:
'Whoever turns away from its fires... Then I am the son of Qays, there is no departure [I will stay]'
This poetry: By Sa'd bin Malik al-Qaysi. Alluding to Al-Harith bin Abbad who withdrew from the war. 'Miserable are the successors after us... Children of Yashkur and the Liqah'. 'Liqah': Banu Hanifa (paid no tribute). Only Al-Find az-Zimmani (Shahl bin Sayyar) joined from Hanifa. Old warrior sent to aid Bakr. 'I am a Find (mountain piece) for you'. 'Ishbah/Ishmah': Very old man.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'And when there is a hateful event (war), I am called for it... And when the Hays (food) is mixed, Jundab is called'
'This, by your grandfather, is the humiliation itself... No mother for me if that is so, nor father!'
Sibawayh: Man from Madhhij. Abu Riyash: Humam bin Murrah (brother of Jassas). Isbahani: Damra bin Abi Damra. Ibn al-A'rabi: Pre-Islamic by 500 years. Narrated: 'La-amrukum'. Speaker had a brother Jundab favored over him. Before it:
'Is it equity that when you are counted... And secured, I am the distant stranger?!'
'And when there is a hateful event...'
'For Jundab is the easy land and its sweet water... And for me the salty water and their rugged barren parts?!'
'Wonder at that judgment, and my staying... Among you upon that judgment is more wonderful!'
'This, by your grandfather...'

'As-Sawiyyah': Justice. 'Al-Ajnab': Stranger/Distant. 'Al-Hays': Dates, cheese, butter. 'As-Saghar': Humiliation.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Interrogative Alif entering La:
'Is there no piercing? Are there no charging knights?... Except your belching around the clay ovens?!'
This verse: By Hassan bin Thabit mocking Banu al-Harith bin Ka'b. Narrated: 'Ghadiyah' (morning) or 'Adiyah' (running/aggression). 'Tajashshu'ukum': Raised as Badal from place of 'La ta'ana'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'You count the hamstringing of old camels as your best glory... O sons of the stupid woman, why not [confront] the masked armed warrior?!'
This verse: By Jarir. Mocking Al-Farazdaq. Al-Farazdaq's father (Ghalib) competed with Suhaym bin Wathil in slaughtering camels at Sawar. Famine time. Ghalib slaughtered, sent food. Suhaym overturned bowl, struck messenger. Competition escalated (1, 2, 3, 100 camels). Suhaym withdrew. Later slaughtered 300 at Kufa trash heap. Ali bin Abi Talib forbade eating it (slaughtered for other than Allah). Jarir: Glory is killing heroes, not camels. 'An-Nib': Old camels. 'Dawtara': Stupid woman. 'Al-Kami': Brave. 'Al-Muqanna'': Masked/Helmeted.
Al-Mahalli said supporting Jarir:
'It pleased me that Mujashi counts... Of glory only slaughtered camels at Sawar'

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Tamyiz:
'Does Layla abandon her lover due to separation... While a soul (Nafsan) was not pleased with separation?'
This verse: By Al-Mukhabbal as-Sa'di (Rabi'ah bin Malik). Or Al-Asha Hamdan (Abd al-Rahman bin Abdullah). Nicknamed 'Taliq Atharihi' (Freed of his bond). Captured by Daylam. Daylamite woman freed him after intimacy. Poem:
'The Daylamite woman had a lust... By which her prisoner was freed from the bond'
'Whoever ransoms his captivity with money... Hamdan ransoms it with their penises'

This verse: Cited by Al-Mazini for advancing Tamyiz on its operator ('Nafsan' before 'Tatibu'). No proof because: 1. Poetry necessity only. 2. Az-Zajjaji narrated: 'Wa ma kana nafsi...' (My soul was not...). 

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Diminutive:
'A little before (Qudaydimata) the graying and forbearance, indeed I... see the heedlessness of life [best] before experiences'
This verse: By Al-Qatami. Before it:
'As if a downpour from a fresh cloud... On thirst, Umm Ghalib brought it'
'To a consumer almost dying from intensity of passion... From the length of distressing enemies'
'A victim of beauties who pleased him and he pleased them... Since he grew up until the black locks turned gray'
'Qadidimata': Diminutive of 'Quddama'. 'Innani': With kasra (new sentence) or fatha (object of cause). 

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Diminutive of Ambiguous Nouns:
'Lo, say to Tayya before her passing: Be safe... The greeting of one longing for her, enslaved by love'
This verse: By Al-Asha. Mocking Bistam bin Abdullah. 'Tayya': This beloved (Diminutive of 'Allati' or name). 'Mirratiha': Her passing/mode of passing. Or 'Mirratiha': Her resolve. 'Tahiyyata': Accusative source (emphatic). 'Mutayyam': Enslaved. Some said 'Tayya' is proper name. Arguments on 'Tayyak'. Dhu al-Rumma: 'Ala za'anat Mayyu fa-hatika daruha...'. Story of Bedouin denying his wife's child. 'You sit far from me... Or swear... I am father of that little boy (Dhayyalika)'. She replied: 'No, by Him who returned you... No human touched me... Except a boy... After two from Banu Adi...'. He silenced her. 
'Ala qul li-Tayya': Addressing himself.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'With every Qurayshi upon whom is dignity... Swift to the caller of generosity and honor'
This verse: I do not know its author. Before it:
'I am not a shepherd [of sheep] with lowliness... When he goes out, he goes with bow and arrows'
'But I go out, upon me is a wide armor... Smooth, like the eyes of the locusts, arranged'
'Shawi': Sheep herder. 'Damamah': Lowliness. 'Dilas': Smooth/shiny armor.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'And an old Abs-Shamsi woman laughs at me... As if she had not seen a Yemeni captive before me!'
This verse: By Abd Yaghuth bin Waqqas al-Harithi. Captive at Yawm al-Kulab. Lamenting himself. After it:
'And the women of Taym remained around me sitting... Seeking from me what our women want'
'And my wife Mulaykah knew that I... I am the lion, attacked and attacking'
'And I was a slaughterer of camels and worker of... Mounts, and I pass where no living one passes'
'Ka'an lam tara': Shift from reporting to address (or reporting 'tara' - she). Should be 'tara' (jussive). Kept Alif for necessity or dialect (Ra'a -> Ra' -> Tara). 'Ka'an': Lightened, subject hidden.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: Declinable and Indeclinable:
'And he neighs in [a chest] like the inside of a walled well... A neighing that became clear to the Arab [horses/expert]'
This verse: By An-Nabigha al-Ja'di. Name: Hibban bin Qays (or Abdullah bin Qays). Named Nabigha because he said poetry after 30 years silence (or after hiatus). Lived 120 (or 180) years. Umar asked him about his poetry. 
'Yashalu': Neighs. 'At-Tawi': Walled well. 'Al-Mu'rib': One who knows Arab horses (or owns them). 'Tabayyana li-l-mu'ribi': Sentence adjective for 'Sahil'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Satire:
'For indeed death, whoever fears it... It will encounter him wherever [he is]!'
This verse: By An-Nimr bin Tawlab al-Ukli. 'An-Nimr': Transferred from Leopard. 'Tawlab': Donkey foal. 'Ukli': Improvised. Before it:
'And if you meet in hardship... Let it not frighten you to advance'
'La tatahayyabka': The Kaf is address particle (according to some), not object. 'An taqdima': To advance.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: Rules of Hamza in Writing:
'Indeed Sulayma - and may Allah protect her - was stingy with a thing that would not have diminished her'
This verse: By Ibrahim bin Harma. 'Harmah': Transferred from 'Haram' (plant). 'Yakla'uha': Protects her.

'Dhannat': Was stingy. 'Ma kana yarza'uha': Adjective for 'Shay''. 'Wallahu yakla'uha': Parenthetical. Poem chosen by Al-Asma'i. After it:
'And she accustomed me... to intervals of thirst...'
'And I see her ceasing not to be unjust... Causing a wound and peeling it'
'La araha tazalu': Preposed 'La'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: Masculine and Feminine:
'A Kaf, two Meems, and an effaced Seen.'
Rajaz: Unknown. Comparing ruins to writing. Arabs mostly illiterate. Writing attributed to Jews/Christians. 'Tasim': Effaced.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'... As a Kaf appearing and its Meem were made clear'
This verse: By Ar-Ra'i. Start: 'Ashaqatka atlal...'. 'Buyyinat' (Passive) or 'Bayyanat' (Active).

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Ams (Yesterday):
'I have seen a wonder since yesterday... Five old women like ghouls'
After it: 'Eating what they gathered crunching...'. 'Hams': Hidden sound. 'Ta's': Falling on face.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: Particles raising what follows (Prepositions? No, 'Bayna'):
'While he was embracing [fighting] the brave ones and dodging... One day a daring, bold one was destined for him'
This verse: By Abu Dhu'ib. Before it: 'And Time does not spare...'.
'Khawsa'': One-eyed (horse). 'Yafsimu': Breaks. 'Ar-Rahalah': Saddle part. 'Al-Jur'': Boldness. 'Ta'anuqihi': Correct form (not 'Ta'anuq'). Fighting stages: Arrows, Spears, Swords, Embracing (wrestling). Meaning: Bravery does not save from death.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of What is Installed by Hidden Verb:
'... Striking like "this after that" (quickly) and stabbing penetratingly'
This verse: By Al-Ajjaj (Abdullah bin Ru'ba). 'Hadh': Cutting quickly. 'Hadhdha dhayka': This after that. 'Wakhd': Penetrating stab.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'If a garment was torn, a like garment was torn for it... In turn (Dawalayka), until all of us were without clothes!'
This verse: By Suhaym, slave of Banu al-Has'has. 'Suhaym': Diminutive of 'Asham' (Black). 'Has'has': Improvised or Transferred. 'Burd': Garment. 'Dawalayka': Dual of 'Dawal' (Turn/Alternation). Meaning: Lovers tearing each other's clothes implies lasting love.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Pause (Waqf):
'... I am the son of Mawiya when the clicking/matter becomes serious'
This verse: Unknown (likely Ubayd bin Mawiya). 'Naqr': Clicking tongue to horse. 'Ana Ibn Mawiya': Boast.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'I feared that I would see drought/misfortune... In this year of ours after it had been fertile'
Rajaz. 'Jadayya' (Double Ya): Necessity for pause (Waqf) requiring vowel before last letter. 'Akhsabba': Doubled Ba. Poem about locusts ('Daba'). 'Sabsaba': Barren land. 'Islahabba': Flowed. 'Buwayzil': Diminutive of 'Bazil'. 'Iqr'abba': Shrunk/Lean.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of 'Ma':
'[Because of] what is in our heart of worry and passion... So that the broken-hearted, lovesick one may heal'
This verse: By Al-Farazdaq. Poem: 'Azafta...'. 'Al-Ayad': Strength. 'Al-Warid': Jugular. 'Zamanah': Illness. 'Yujbar'/'Yabra'': Heal. 'Minhad': Broken bone reset then broken again. 'Mushghaf'/'Mush'af': Lovesick.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'And two deserts, high, barren... Their backs are like the backs of two shields'
Rajaz: By Khitam al-Mujashi'i. 'Jubtuhuma bi-n-na'ti...': Crossed them by description (skill).

'Mahmah': Desert (from 'Mahmah' - sound of rebuke). 'Qadhaf': High. 'Mart': Barren. 'Zhahrahuma...': High/Bare like shields.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: Divisions of Objects:
'So he and she were like a thirsty man who did not cease... From the water when he met it until he split'
This verse: By Ka'b bin Ju'ayl. 'Harran': Thirsty. 'Taqaddada': Split. Likening love to thirst.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'So I swore I would not cease composing a poem... That would clothe me and her as a proverb after me'
This verse: By Abu Dhu'ib. Addressing Khalid (nephew). Khalid stole his mistress (Umm Amr). 'Alaytu': Swore. 'Ahdhu': Compose/Make (like sandals). 'Takunu': Adjective for 'Qasida'. 'Biha': Returns to poem. 'Iyyaha': Returns to woman. Khalid's reply: 'Do not panic... I learned it from you'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'Jarm tasks me with the "meal of the vine" (wine)... And what is Jarm, and what is that meal?!'

This verse: By Ziyad al-A'jam (Ziyad bin Jabir). Named 'A'jam' for lisp/accent. Mocking Jarm tribe. 'Sawiq al-Karm': Wine. 'Ma Jarmun...': Belittling. Jarm couldn't afford wine in Jahiliyya, only drank when cheap/forbidden. Witness: 'Ma' repeated prevents accusative. 'Ma anta wa dhaka...'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'So what am I to do with looking around Najd... When Tihama has been choked with saddles/travelers?'
This verse: By Miskin ad-Darimi. 'At-Taladdud': Looking left/right (bewilderment/hesitation). 'Najd': Highland. 'Tihama': Lowland. 'Ghussat': Choked/Full. Meaning: People moved to Tihama, I should too.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'So what am I to do with traveling in a wasteland... That exhausts the strong male camel?'
This verse: By Usama bin Habib. 'Matlaf': Dangerous desert. 'Yubarrihu': Exhausts. 'Adh-Dhakara ad-Dabit': Strong male camel. Refusing to travel with companions to Egypt/Syria. Poem describing camels and hardships.

'Al-Buzl': Aged camels. 'Dammaha': Covered. 'Al-A'it': Non-pregnant. 'Al-Gha'it': Low ground. 'Al-Ayn': Fatigue. 'Al-Wasit': Saddle part. 'Al-Haffan': Ostriches. 'Taghya': Wild cow (or sound). 'Al-Lahaq': White bull. 'Al-Himyagh': Sudden death. 'Adh-Dha'it': Slaughtering. 'Al-Murbi'': Fevered. 'Al-Azil': Distressed. 'Al-Murtadikh': Crushing date stones.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'And I forgive the slip/bad word (Awra') of the noble to save him... And I turn away from the insult of the base out of honor!'
This verse: By Hatim at-Ta'i. 'Awra'': Ugly word. Tarafa: 'Awra' came from a brother...'. Contrast in poetry (Blind vs Sound). Al-Akhtal using 'Qasi'a' (Rat hole) for 'Yarbu''. Al-Ma'arri: 'Farqad' (Star/Calf). Hatim's generosity. Story of Abu Khaybari dreaming of Hatim killing his camel.

'Awrah' (Slip) vs 'Salimat al-aynayn' (Sound of eyes). 'Farqadayhi' (Stars/Calves). Hatim's verses to Abu Khaybari. Adi replacing the camel.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of 'Min' positions:
'So it suffices us as merit over others... The love of the Prophet Muhammad for us.'
This verse: By Ka'b bin Malik. 'Ka'b': Ankle/Cube/Knot. 'Bi-na': Ba is extra. 'Fadlan': Tamyiz.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: The Saying (Al-Qawl):
'As for the departure, it is before the day after tomorrow, so when... Do you say the house will gather us?'
This verse: By Umar bin Abi Rabi'ah. 'Tajma'una': Second object of 'Taqulu'. 'Shi'uhu': The day following tomorrow.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'When do you say: The fast young camels... Will bring Umm Qasim (Umm Hazim) and Qasim (Hazim) near?'
This verse: By Hudba bin al-Khashram.

Correct names: Umm Hazim and Hazim. Story of Hudba and Ziyada bin Zayd. Ziyada flirted with Hudba's sister Fatima. Hudba responded with poem threatening Ziyada. 'Nuzji': Drive gently. 'Al-Ghayahim': Good natured camels. 'Al-Qamaqim': Voices. 'Al-Ma'akim': Hips. 'Al-Limam': Visit. 'Al-Lizam': Hugging. 'Al-Fiqam': Kissing. 'Al-Mufaghama': Smelling. Conflict led to killing.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'I heard people seeking rain/grass... So I said to [my camel] Saydah: Seek Bilal.'
This verse: By Dhu al-Rumma praising Bilal bin Abi Burda. 'Yantaji'un': Seeking. 'Ghayth': Rain/Grass. Bilal's reaction (Dates/Fodder). 'An-Nas' (Accusative/Nominative). Grammar of 'Sami'a' (Transitive to one object vs two). Abu Ali's view (Physical vs Abstract hearing).

Refutation of Abu Ali. 'Sami'a' acts like other senses (one object). 'Yaqulu' is Hal.
After Dhu al-Rumma's verse: 'Tunakhi 'inda khayri fatan...'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: Tales of Indefinites with 'Man':
'They came to my fire, so I said: Who are you?... They said: The Jinn. I said: Good darkness to you (Imu Zhalaman).'
Abu al-Qasim corrected 'Imu Sabahan' to 'Imu Zhalaman' based on Ibn Duraid. However, he erred in rejecting 'Imu Sabahan'. That verse is in the 'Book of Sadd Ma'rib' attributed to Jidh' bin Sinan (Legendary). Both poems are fabrications. 'Mim' rhyme attributed to Shamir/Ta'abbata Sharran. 'Ha' rhyme to Jidh'. Poem of Jidh':
'They came to my fire... I said: Good morning (Imu Sabahan)'
'I descended the valley of Jinn...'
'They came unveiling...'
'I slaughtered for them...'
'He warned me of matters...'

'I will execute what they said... Nor seek arrows [divination] for that'
'I suspected it [divination]...'
'Death comes in clothes of safety...'
Explaining the poems. 'Hada'tu': Kindled. 'Mahda'': Poker. 'Wahm': Midnight. 'Ayr': Pupil of eye. Narrated: 'Sarat al-Jinn' (Nobles). 'Imu': Imperative of 'Wa'ama/Na'ima'. Meaning of 'Imu Sabahan' at night: Metaphor for good state or 'morning' of the next day. 'Zhalaman': Tamyiz or Adverb. 'Ila at-ta'am': Ellipsis (Come). 'Za'im': Leader.
Jidh' bin Sinan story. 'Tahaytu': Cooked. 'Qidah': Divination arrows. Imru' al-Qays breaking arrows before the idol Dhu al-Khalasa when they forbade vengeance for his father. 'If the killed one was your father...'. 'Adh-Dhubah': Poisonous plant.

'Yutihu': Destines. 'Al-Ijtiyah': Extermination.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of 'Madha':
'Do you not ask the man what he attempts... Is it a vow (Nahb) to be fulfilled, or error and falsehood?'
This verse: By Labid. 'Nahb': Vow/Obligation. Questioning man's greed. 'Ma': Subject. 'Dha': Predicate. 'A-Nahbun': Predicate of hidden subject.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Connections (Silat):
'Come, for if you covenant with me not to betray me... We will be like two who accompany each other, O wolf.'
This verse: By Al-Farazdaq. Sharing food with a wolf.

'And a dust-colored (Atlas) shaker... I called to my fire...'
'When he came...'
'I spent the night cutting the food...'
'So I said to him when he grinned laughing... And my sword hilt was in my hand'
'Eat...'
'And you, O wolf, and treachery are... two brothers nursed by one milk'
'Atlas': Dusty/Wolf. 'Assal': Shaking walker. 'Da'awtu li-nari': Called him to my fire. 'Takashshara': Grinned. 'La takhununi': Hal. Al-Farazdaq imitated Imru' al-Qays or An-Najashi in describing the wolf.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Broken Plural:
'And when men see Yazid, you see them... Submissive (Khudda') of necks, lowering (Nawakis) the eyes.'
This verse: By Al-Farazdaq praising Yazid bin al-Muhallab. 'Jasha'na': Rose in fear/heaving. 'Nawakis': Plural of 'Nakis'. Analogy 'Nukkas', but followed 'Fawa'il' (usually feminine) because 'Fa'il' with Alif 3rd is hard to break otherwise. 'Khudda' ar-riqab': Hal.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: Breaking of 'Fa'lah':
'- And when they saw us, with our knees (Rukabatuna) showing... In a state that does not mix seriousness with jest.'
Unknown author. 'Rukabat' (damma/fatha). 'La nakhlitu...': Hal (State). Or Adjective for 'Mawtin' (hidden). 'Badiyan': Hal.

Abu al-Qasim recited in this Chapter:
'As for the slave girls, they do not call me a son... When the sons of slave girls hurl shame at each other.'
This verse: By Al-Qattal al-Kilabi (Ubayd bin al-Mudharrih). Named 'Killer' for killing his cousin over a woman. Fled to mountains (Amayah). 'Banu al-Imwan': Sons of slave girls. Boasting of free lineage. 'La arda'u...': I do not suckle (seek help) except from a clear [breast/source].

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: Forms of Verbs:
'And huge camels (Kum) that delight (Tun'imu) the guests' eyes... And become heavy in their resting places [from milk/fat]!'
This verse: By Al-Farazdaq. 'Kum': Huge camels. 'Tun'imu...': Gladden the guests' eyes (by meat/milk). 'Thiqalan': Heavy with milk. 'Tun'imu...': Adjective for 'Kum'. Narrated 'Al-Adyafa' (Nasb): 'Tun'imu [bi] al-adyaf'.

'I commanded you good...'. Meaning: Owners delight, attributed to camels. 'Hawwas': Glutton.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter of Conjugation:
'Did it not come to you (Ya'tika), and news spreads... Of what the milk-camels of Banu Ziyad encountered?'
This verse: By Qays bin Zuhair al-Absi. Conflict with Ar-Rabi' bin Ziyad over armor 'Dhat al-Hawashi'. Qays raided 400 camels. 'Ya'tika': Jussive, kept Ya (necessity/dialect). Should be 'Ya'tika'.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the Chapter: Anomalies of Idgham:
'Except that the noble riding camels... Sensed (Hasayna) him, so they looked at him with the corner of their eyes (Shus).'
This verse: By Abu Zubayd at-Ta'i. Describing lion stalking camels. 'Hasayna': Dialect/Anomaly for 'Hasisna'. 'Shus': Looking with fear/side-eye.

Abu al-Qasim recited in the end of the book:
'The Qaysi was not outstripped due to bad conduct... But the uncircumcised foreskin (Ghurlah) of Khalid floated on the water.'
This verse: By Al-Farazdaq.

Meaning: Comparing Umar bin Hubayra (Al-Qaysi) and Khalid al-Qasri. Khalid replaced Umar. Umar wasn't beaten by bad policy, but Khalid's vileness floated to the top like scum/corpse, while pearls (noble Umar) sank. 'Ghurlah' (Foreskin): Khalid's mother was Christian, he was accused of weak faith. Built church for mother, destroyed minarets. 'Ala qabbaha ar-Rahman...'. 'Litani fi al-mu'adhdhinin...'. Floating foreskin test for gender (legend). Abu Ali al-Farisi: Verse seen in Sibawayh's handwriting. Al-Mazini: Said about a race between a Qaysi and an Anazi named Khalid. Narration 'Su' Sayrihi' (running) supports race theory. Another narration: 'Ghuliba... gurlatu Qanbari'.

This concludes the explanation of the verses of Al-Jumal. Praise to Allah... Printed for the first time after 9 centuries... Author Abu Muhammad Abdullah ibn as-Sid.
